ProjectTitle: RSP award in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2020, the USAID-funded RSP (Rapid Stabilization Program) provided critical humanitarian support to conflict-affected communities across Anbar, Diyala, Ninewa, and Salah al-Din governorates in Iraq. The program focused on delivering essential services, including health care, water, sanitation, hygiene (WASH), shelter, and protection, to facilitate the safe return and reintegration of internally displaced persons (IDPs) and support host communities. These efforts were part of broader stabilization initiatives aimed at rebuilding infrastructure and restoring basic services in areas liberated from ISIS control.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: UNITED NATIONS CHILDREN'S FUND (UNICEF) IN IRAQ FOR EDUCATIONAL
ProjectTitle: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) in Iraq for Educational
LongDescription: UNICEF's 2016 education initiative in Iraq, supported by U.S. funding, provided access to education for approximately 682,000 children, including displaced individuals and host communities. The program encompassed the construction of 45 schools, deployment of over 1,500 temporary learning spaces, rehabilitation of 405 schools, and training for more than 2,775 education personnel. A significant project site was Hanin School in Khalidiya, Anbar Governorate, which received six prefabricated classrooms to accommodate 1,050 students.

ShortDescription: UNICEF BASE MACRO AWARD 2015 - ASSISTANCE AND RECOVERY
ProjectTitle: UNICEF Base Macro Award 2015 - Assistance and Recovery
LongDescription: The 2015 UNICEF Base Macro Award in Iraq, funded by the United States, supported emergency humanitarian assistance for children and families affected by conflict. Key interventions included health services, water, sanitation, hygiene (WASH), education, and child protection, with a significant focus on Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) distributions to newly displaced populations.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: ESTABLISHMENT OF MULTIMEDIA LANGUAGE LABORATORIES IN 18 UNIVERSITIES
ProjectTitle: Establishment of Multimedia Language Laboratories in 18 Universities
LongDescription: The Establishment of Multimedia Language Laboratories in 18 Universities project, initiated in 2013 with support from the Republic of Korea, aimed to enhance English language education across Iraq's higher education institutions. This initiative involved equipping 18 universities with modern multimedia language laboratories, providing essential educational equipment, facilitating the invitation of trainees, and dispatching Korean specialists to train local faculty and staff. The project was aligned with Iraq's broader educational reform efforts to improve language proficiency and teaching methodologies in universities.

ShortDescription: IRAQ DURABLE COMMUNITIES AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES (DCEO) 100 SOLUTIONS FOR STABILITY SOCIAL COHESION TASK ORDER
ProjectTitle: Iraq durable communities and economic opportunities (DCEO) 100 Solutions for Stability social cohesion Task Order
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: Iraq Durable Communities and Economic Opportunities (DCEO) 100 Solutions for Stability Task Order aims to support vulnerable communities in Iraq to build community resilience against destabilizing factors and advance economic well-being in target communities in Iraq by addressing underlying drivers of conflict, increasing community leadership of inclusive local development, improving private sector networks, and increasing micro, small, and medium enterprise development.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: DDG/MAG GLOBAL, AFGHANISTAN AND IRAQ MINE ACTION PROGRAMME 2018-2021 - DDG/MAG IRAQ MINE ACTION PROGRAMME 2018-2021
ProjectTitle: DDG/MAG Global, Afghanistan and Iraq Mine Action Programme 2018-2021 - DDG/MAG Iraq Mine Action Programme 2018-2021
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: Danish Demining Group (DDG) and Mines Advisory Group (MAG) have submitted a joint programme proposal to address the problems posed by the presence of anti-personal mines, cluster ammunition, Explosive Remnants of War (ERW), Improvised Explosive Devices (IED) and Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW). This 4-year programme will be conducted during 2018-2021 with a total budget of 320 MSEK, which will be evenly divided between the financial years. This contribution will be financed by three Swedish strategies: Sustainable Peace, Afghanistan and Iraq. The Sustainable Peace strategy will provide 200 MSEK while the other two bilateral strategies will contribute 60 MSEK each. The funding from the Sustaining Peace strategy has a tentative allocation of 160 MSEK to mine action and 40 MSEK to SALW.  DDG is an integral part of the Danish Refugee Council (DRC) and DRC is therefore the legal entity signing the agreement for this project and will be responsible for the funds transferred to MAG. The country focus of the Sustainable Peace component finance will be determined on an annual basis to provide flexibility for adapting changing needs. DDG/MAG does, however, have long term strategies for most of the countries they are active in, since mine action require a long-term focus. The contributions that will be implemented through Sustainable Peace will focus on mines, cluster ammunition and other explosive remnants in the following eleven countries during 2018:-DDG is planning on implementing contributions in Algeria (with focus on West Saharan refugee camps), Colombia, Libya, Syria, Ukraine and Yemen.   -MAG is planning on implementing contributions in Bosnia Herzegovina, Lebanon, Myanmar, Sri Lanka and Zimbabwe.When deciding on where to work the aim has been to include both contexts with a focus on facilitating humanitarian response and contexts more focused on supporting the commitments toward the mine- and cluster conventions. This is also done to balance the risk profile of the intervention since countries with on-going conflicts pose higher risks in a number of areas. Regarding SALW, DDG plan to focus on Guinea (as well as one additional country in West Africa) while MAG will work with SALW in Somalia.The contribution in Afghanistan will be implemented by DDG alone since MAG is not active there, and Iraq will be the only country where both DDG and MAG will be implement the programme during 2018. This programme is a continuation of earlier support from Sida where the Sustainable Peace strategy has contributed to DDG and MAG during 2015-2017 as well as earlier Sida support to DDG in Afghanistan during 2010-2016. The programme aims to address the problems posed by the presence of anti-personnel mines, cluster ammunition, ERW, IED's and SALW. Landmines, ERWs and IEDs poses a direct threat to innocent human beings, can hamper economic and social development, hinder or complicates humanitarian support to be delivered and make it hard for people (IDPs and refuge

AgencyName: Federal Government Commissioner for Culture and the Media
ShortDescription: PERSIAN EDITORIAL DEPARTMENT
ProjectTitle: Persian editorial department
PurposeName: Media and free flow of information
LongDescription: The Persian Editorial Department project delivers radio and online content in the Persian language, providing timely information on politics, economics, environment, and current affairs to Persian-speaking audiences, aiming to enhance awareness and engagement through reliable media services.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Government Commissioner for Culture and the Media

ShortDescription: COVID-19 MITIGATION ASSISTANCE
ProjectTitle: COVID-19 Mitigation Assistance
LongDescription: To meet the critical basic needs of vulnerable conflict-affected households and reduce negative coping strategies exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic while promoting coordinated and harmonized MPCA through the consortium model.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: USAID ADVISORY AND ASSISTANCE SERVICES
ProjectTitle: USAID Advisory and Assistance Services
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: The "USAID Advisory and Assistance Services in 2019" project in Iraq encompassed administrative costs and operational expenses associated with USAID's advisory and assistance initiatives. These services were integral to supporting USAID's broader humanitarian and development efforts across Iraq, particularly in response to the challenges posed by the rise of the Islamic State and the resulting displacement of populations. Between 2014 and 2019, USAID provided $2.2 billion in aid to Iraq, with a significant portion allocated to advisory services, third-party monitoring, and program oversight to ensure effective implementation and accountability of aid programs.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PEOPLE - 2016 / LA CRISE EN IRAK - AIDE FINANCI횊RE POUR LES PERSONNES D횋PLAC횋ES - 2016
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Financial Assistance for Internally Displaced People - 2016
LongDescription: March 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 3.2 million people from their homes. An estimated 10 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. The capacity of the Government to respond to the basic needs of its citizens has been overwhelmed. In 2016, more people will be displaced by the conflict, while many will remain displaced in camps and host communities. However, there will also be growing numbers of people returning to areas no longer under the control of ISIL who will also need assistance to help restart their lives.   With GAC's support, this project is providing emergency multi-purpose cash assistance to up to 30,912 newly displaced people, people experiencing protracted displacement, people returning to areas of origin, and particularly vulnerable host community households. This project will be implemented by a consortium of the four leading international organizations in Iraq: Mercy Corps, the Norwegian Refugee Council, the Danish Refugee Council and the International Rescue Committee. The amounts and frequency of payments will vary depending on well-defined vulnerability criteria and whether a family is newly displaced, in need of assistance to support their return to areas no longer under the control of ISIL, in a situation of protracted displacement, or a host community household experiencing the stresses of protracted crisis.

ShortDescription: SYRIA CRISIS - ASSISTANCE FOR REFUGEES AND DISPLACED PERSONS IN MULTIPLE COUNTRIES - UNHCR MULTI YR / CRISE EN SYRIE - AIDE AUX R횋FUGI횋S ET PERSONNES
ProjectTitle: Syria Crisis - Assistance for Refugees and Displaced Persons in Multiple Countries - UNHCR Multi Year
LongDescription: September 2016 - The Syria Crisis has undermined security and stability in the Middle East and has resulted in unprecedented humanitarian needs. Now in its sixth year, the conflict in Syria has led to the worst displacement crisis in the world. Millions of internally displaced persons (IDPs), refugees, stateless persons and asylum seekers in Syria, Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, Egypt and Turkey are vulnerable to violence, food and income insecurity, health risks, and sexual and gender-based violence. Canada is helping to reduce the vulnerability of millions of crisis-affected people, especially women and children, through a broad spectrum of humanitarian assistance activities across Syria and in refugee hosting countries.   GAC's multi-year humanitarian support to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey is contributing to improved living conditions, livelihoods and protection for vulnerable populations, especially women and girls. In Egypt, project activities include: (1) improving freedom of movement for people of concern, (2) supporting the enrollment of up to 35,000 registered children in primary education, (3) providing cash assistance to people of concern, and (4) supporting the resettlement of refugees in third countries.   In Jordan, project activities include: (1) providing cash assistance to Syrian refugee and asylum-seeker families, (2) providing medical referrals to secondary and tertiary care for Syrian refugees and asylum-seekers, and (3) supporting the enrollment of up to 15,000 registered non-Syrian refugee children in primary education.   In Lebanon, project activities include: (1) registering up to 18,000 non-Syrian refugees, (2) supporting access to secondary and tertiary medical care for Syrian refugees and asylum seekers, (3) supporting the enrollment of up to 118,980 Syrian refugees and asylum-seekers in primary education, (4) providing basic domestic items to Syrian refugee and asylum-seeker households, and (5) providing legal assistance and protection services.   In Turkey, project activities include: (1) providing psychological support to vulnerable persons, (2) providing cash-based assistance conflict-affected families, (3) providing core relief items to Syrian and Iraqi families, and (4) supporting the resettlement of up to 7,300 refugee families.   In Iraq, project activities include: (1) registering Syrian refugees in Iraq, (2) providing protection services and psychosocial support, and (3) providing legal and cash assistance to conflict-affected people, including asylum seekers and stateless persons.

ShortDescription: PROMOTING RESILICENE FOR RETURNEES AND HOST COMMUNITIES IN NINEWA - PROMOTING RESILICENE FOR RETURNEES AND HOST COMMUNITIES IN NINEWA IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Promoting Resilicene for returnees and host communities in Ninewa - Promoting Resilicene for returnees and host communities in Ninewa Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: Mercy Corps has submitted a proposal to Sida for funding for the project  Promoting Resilience for Returns and Host Communities in Ninewa  in Iraq for a three-year grant support amounting to SEK 64 200 000.The overall aim of the project is to support local development and peaceful environments, as well as the well-being of returnees and host societies in conflict-affected districts and sub-districts of Ninewa through psychosocial work for increased resilience, social cohesion and livelihood.The project is divided into three result areas.Objective 1: Improved psychosocial well-being for vulnerable adolescents and adolescents aged 10-24 years.Objective 2: Increased social cohesion between communities, including increased integration of women and youth in Ninewa.Objective 3: Increased economic resilience for young people through improved livelihood opportunities in three districts in Ninewa.

ShortDescription: PROVISION OF HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE TO NEW AND PROTRACTED IDPS AND COMPREHENSIVE COMMUNITY STABILIZATION IN AREAS OF RETURN
ProjectTitle: Provision of Humanitarian Assistance to New and Protracted IDPs and Comprehensive Community Stabilization In Areas of Return
LongDescription: Provision of Humanitarian Assistance to New and Protracted IDPs and Comprehensive Community Stabilization In Areas of Return

ShortDescription: CASH ASSISTANCE TO MEET HUMANITARIAN NEEDS OF CONFLICT-AFFECTED POPULATIONS IN IRAQ.
ProjectTitle: Cash assistance to meet humanitarian needs of conflict-affected populations in Iraq.
LongDescription: In 2017, USAID, in partnership with the Cash Consortium of Iraq (CCI), provided multi-purpose cash assistance to over 26,000 conflict-affected households across Iraq. This initiative aimed to address urgent humanitarian needs by enabling vulnerable families to purchase essential items such as food and hygiene products. The program operated in several governorates, including Ninewa, Salah al-Din, Anbar, Kirkuk, and Diyala, focusing on areas with high displacement and returnee populations. The cash assistance was delivered through a harmonized approach, ensuring consistency and efficiency in aid distribution
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: IRAQ EMERGENCY RESPONSE
ProjectTitle: Iraq Emergency Response
LongDescription: United States Population Migration and Refugee Assistance, Appropriation 1143. Protection and assistance needs of refugees, migrants and conflict vicitms worldwide. [United Nations Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: WATER SUPPLY AND SEWAGE WATER DISPOSAL FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES
ProjectTitle: Water supply and sewage water disposal for Syrian refugees
LongDescription: The planned interventions subdivide to themselves into three spheres of activity (1) conversion of priority measures in the water supply and sanitary care, (2) installations of a new drinking water care system of the district Faida, and (3) strengthening of the capacities of partner organisations.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: COUNTER TERRORISM AND VIOLENT EXTREMISM IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Counter terrorism and violent extremism in Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: Supporting a network of advocates and 'champions' to enhance reconciliation and undermine the Daesh narrative, leading to the integration and wellbeing of local communities.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE WINTER HELP / WINTERIZATION SHELTER
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance Winter Help / winterization shelter
LongDescription: The Humanitarian Assistance Winter Help project provides critical winter aid, including shelter winterization, water, and sanitation services, to internally displaced persons (IDPs) living in camps across Iraq. The initiative aims to protect vulnerable populations from harsh winter conditions and improve living standards in displacement settings.

ShortDescription: SWIFT IV TASK ORDER WORLDWIDE
ProjectTitle: SWIFT IV Task Order Worldwide
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: In 2014, USAID launched the Support Which Implements Fast Transitions IV (SWIFT IV) program to provide rapid, flexible assistance in politically sensitive environments. While SWIFT IV was a global initiative, specific task orders under this program were implemented in various countries, including Iraq.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: UNICEF 2017 HUMANITARIAN ACTION FOR CHILDREN APPEAL FOR IRAQ
ProjectTitle: UNICEF 2017 Humanitarian Action for Children Appeal for Iraq
LongDescription: In 2017, UNICEF's Humanitarian Action for Children Appeal in Iraq, supported by U.S. Migration and Refugee Assistance funds, aimed to address the urgent needs of children affected by conflict. The program provided essential services such as clean water, education, and psychosocial support to displaced and vulnerable children across Iraq. One of the key implementation sites was the Jadaa camp in Ninewa Governorate.

ShortDescription: PROVISION OF FOOD ASSISTANCE TO CRISIS-AFFECTED PEOPLE IN IRAQ, INCLUDING INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS AND RETURNEES, TO MEET THEIR BASIC FOOD AND NUT
ProjectTitle: Provision of food assistance to crisis-affected people in Iraq, including internally displaced persons and returnees, to meet their basic food and nutrition needs
LongDescription: In 2022, the World Food Programme (WFP) continued its critical support for crisis-affected populations in Iraq, including internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and refugees. The assistance aimed to meet their basic food and nutrition needs through various modalities such as cash-based transfers, food distributions, and e-vouchers. This support was particularly vital in the context of rising food prices and economic challenges exacerbated by global events. WFP's efforts also included enhancing social protection systems and promoting resilience through livelihood programs. The initiative was part of a broader strategy to transition from emergency response to long-term development, focusing on sustainable solutions for vulnerable communities.

ShortDescription: ASSISTANCE TO ADDRESS THE FOOD INSECURITY OF INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS (IDPS) AND ENHANCE RESILIENCE OF VULNERABLE IRAQIS AFFECTED BY THE COVID-19
ProjectTitle: Assistance to address the food insecurity of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and enhance resilience of vulnerable Iraqis affected by the COVID-19 pandemic
LongDescription: In 2021, Japan provided funding to support food assistance initiatives aimed at addressing food insecurity among Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and enhancing the resilience of vulnerable Iraqis affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Implemented by organizations such as the World Food Programme (WFP), these projects focused on delivering essential food aid to those in need. For instance, WFP provided food assistance to 73,786 beneficiaries through unconditional in-kind food assistance during the period from May to July 2021

ShortDescription: NEAR TERM FUNDING FOR UNITED NATIONS HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR REFUGEES (UNHCR) IRAQ - RRP6
ProjectTitle: Near Term Funding for United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) Iraq - Rrp6
LongDescription: The Near Term Funding for UNHCR Iraq under the 2013 RRP6 supported Syrian refugees and conflict-affected individuals, focusing on protection, shelter, and essential services. A key site was the Qushtapa Refugee Camp in Erbil Governorate, established in August 2013 to accommodate Syrian Kurdish refugees

ShortDescription: SUPPORT TO IRAQ'S ELECTORAL PROCESS
ProjectTitle: Support to Iraq's Electoral Process
LongDescription: This 18-month action will support efforts to organise transparent elections that respond to the legitimate aspirations of the Iraqi population. The capacity of IHEC will be strengthened inter alia through the deployment of additional electoral advisors who will help meet the ambitious calendar for the elections. IHEC efforts to adequately inform the public about the roles and responsibilities of all actors involved in the elections will also be strengthened.

ShortDescription: DEMINING IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Demining in Iraq
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: The Demining in Iraq project focuses on clearing landmines and unexploded ordnance to improve safety for communities, alongside providing rehabilitation services and support for mine victims and people with disabilities. The initiative aims to reduce risks and facilitate safer living conditions in affected areas.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN NEEDS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian needs in Iraq
LongDescription: The project addresses urgent humanitarian needs of internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees across Iraq by providing essential relief such as food, shelter, water, sanitation, and healthcare services to improve their immediate living conditions and support recovery.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: PROMOTION OF DIALOGUE AND PARTICIPATION IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Promotion of Dialogue and Participation in Iraq
LongDescription: The Promotion of Dialogue and Participation in Iraq project fosters inclusive dialogue and participatory processes to develop comprehensive reform proposals across the country. It aims to strengthen democratic engagement by involving diverse stakeholders in decision-making and policy development.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: IRAQ COVID-19 ASSISTANCE
ProjectTitle: Iraq COVID-19 Assistance
LongDescription: USAID allocated over $10 million in 2020 to support Iraq's COVID-19 response, funding the rehabilitation of healthcare facilities, provision of medical equipment, and establishment of isolation rooms across multiple governorates. A notable project was the rehabilitation of the East Mosul Medical Fluid Factory, a critical facility for producing medical supplies, severely damaged during the ISIL conflict .
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: IRAQ COVID-19 WASH AWARD
ProjectTitle: Iraq COVID-19 WASH Award
LongDescription: New COVID-19 Supplemental Award for WASH and Health/WASH in Health Facilities in Anbar, Baghdad, Erbil, Kirkuk, Ninewa, Salah al-Din, and Sulaymaniyah Governorates
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: WFP IRAK 2023-2027 - WFP IRAK
ProjectTitle: WFP Irak 2023-2027 - WFP Irak
LongDescription: The project aim is to support people in Iraq to increase their resilience to climate change and contribute to food security. Access to water and a more efficient use of water in agriculture is central to increase food security in Iraq. In addition to water scarcity and inefficient use of water, lack of wastewater treatment is a problem in Iraq. Discharge of untreated wastewater from households and drainage water from agriculture as well as lack of management of latrines lead to contamination of surface and groundwater.The project addresses this problem in an innovative way for Iraq. The project's budget is SEK 65 million and is to be implemented over four years. The objective of the project is for smallholder farmers to increase their resilience to climate change by using local nature-based solutions for wastewater treatment and to reuse treated wastewater and nutrients in agriculture.The project will pilot NBS in ten locations in five governorates (Ninewa, Diyala, Basra, Thi-Qar and Muthanna). The project will, in cooperation with the local population, construct wetlands for treatment of sewage and drainage water so that the treated wastewater can be reused in agriculture. Residual products will be used for the production of biogas and organic fertilizer. Two knowledge centers under the Ministry of Agriculture will be established with expertise on nature-based solutions for wastewater treatment

ShortDescription: USAID PAY AND BENEFITS
ProjectTitle: USAID Pay and Benefits
LongDescription: The "USAID Pay and Benefits" entry for 2023 refers to administrative costs covering salaries and benefits for USAID personnel, including those at the Iraq Mission. These expenses are categorized under the Operating Expenses account, which funds both domestic and overseas staff compensation, mission operations, and related administrative functions . While these costs support various programs, they are not tied to a specific project or location within Iraq.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: UNICEF BASE MACRO AWARD - ASSISTANCE AND RECOVERY
ProjectTitle: UNICEF base Macro Award - Assistance and Recovery
LongDescription: The 2016 UNICEF Base Macro Award for Assistance and Recovery in Iraq focused on restoring access to education for children affected by conflict and displacement. UNICEF supported over 682,000 children with educational services, including the provision of learning materials, teacher training, and the construction of prefabricated classrooms. A significant implementation site was the Rubar School in Erbil, where displaced children received educational support.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - WATER, SANITATION, HYGIENE, HEALTH AND LIVELIHOODS ASSISTANCE - OXFAM-QU횋BEC 2017-2019 / CRISE EN IRAK - AIDE EN EAU, ASSAINISSEMENT, SA
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Water, Sanitation, Hygiene, Health and Livelihoods Assistance - Oxfam-Qubec 2017-2019
LongDescription: December 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 3 million people from their homes. The capacity of the Government to respond to the basic needs of its citizens has been overwhelmed. While Daesh has lost considerable territory in 2016, it is expected that humanitarian needs will remain significant in the coming years. More people will be displaced by the conflict, while many will remain displaced in camps and host communities. However, there will also be growing numbers of people returning to areas no longer under the control of Daesh who will also need assistance to help restart their lives.   With GAC's support, Oxfam Qu챕bec is providing water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH), health, protection and livelihoods assistance to vulnerable internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees and host communities in Iraq. Project activities include: (1) constructing and/or rehabilitating water networks and train WASH committees on the operation and maintenance of WASH facilities, (2) constructing latrines and bathing facilities, and improve solid waste management for up to 18,000 beneficiaries, (3) providing hygiene kits to up to 6,000 individuals and providing health and hygiene sessions to up to 12,200 beneficiaries, (4) providing emergency sanitation facilities, and water trucking in situations of sudden displacement for up to 1,000 households, (5) providing multi-month cash transfers and one-time emergency cash transfers to vulnerable households, (6) improving livelihoods and income generation opportunities for returnees, internally displaced persons (IDPs), and host communities, including through the restoration of agricultural activities, and (7) improving access of IDPs and returnees to health and protection services at the community level.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - HEALTHCARE AND SEXUAL HEALTH ASSISTANCE - INTERNATIONAL MEDICAL CORPS 2017-2019 / CRISE EN IRAK - AIDE EN SANT횋 ET SOINS DE SANT횋 SEXUEL
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Healthcare and Sexual Health Assistance - International Medical Corps 2017-2019
LongDescription: December 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 3 million people from their homes. The capacity of the Government to respond to the basic needs of its citizens has been overwhelmed. While Daesh has lost considerable territory in 2016, it is expected that humanitarian needs will remain significant in the coming years. More people will be displaced by the conflict, while many will remain displaced in camps and host communities. However, there will also be growing numbers of people returning to areas no longer under the control of Daesh who will also need assistance to help restart their lives.   With GAC's support, International Medical Corps is providing healthcare, mental health, sexual and reproductive health, and case management services to conflict-affected Iraqis. Project activities include: (1) providing health services through multi-service centres, including medical consultations, to up to 104,000 beneficiaries and integrated community health and outreach services to up to 112,000 beneficiaries, (2) delivering training in mental health and psychosocial services (MPHSS) case management to up to 195 healthcare workers, and awareness-raising and information sessions on MHPSS, (3) providing training and mentorship to up to 144 health workers at Multi-Service Centres on sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) case management and screening, (4) providing case management services to up to 2,100 SGBV survivors, (5) conducting recreational and skills-building activities for up to 6,300 women and girls, and (6) conducting safety audits of risk mitigation efforts, and frequent gender dialogue sessions for conflict-affected communities.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - EMERGENCY HEALTHCARE - M횋DECINS DU MONDE CANADA 2017-2019 / CRISE EN IRAK - SOINS DE SANT횋 D'URGENCE - M횋DECINS DU MONDE CANADA 2017-201
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Emergency Healthcare - Mdecins du Monde Canada 2017-2019
LongDescription: December 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 3 million people from their homes. The capacity of the Government to respond to the basic needs of its citizens has been overwhelmed. While Daesh has lost considerable territory in 2016, it is expected that humanitarian needs will remain significant in the coming years. More people will be displaced by the conflict, while many will remain displaced in camps and host communities. However, there will also be growing numbers of people returning to areas no longer under the control of Daesh who will also need assistance to help restart their lives.   With GAC's support, Mdecins du Monde Canada is providing up to 61,000 conflict-affected people per year with comprehensive primary healthcare, including sexual and reproductive health care, mental health care, health promotion, essential medication, and emergency referral systems through static and mobile clinics. The project is also building capacity of national health actors to provide health services to Iraqis in a time of crisis though training and coaching for medical and paramedical staff, the provision of medical inputs, and the monitoring of and provision of feedback on national partners' activities.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - EMERGENCY NON-FOOD ITEMS AND SHELTER IN IRAQ - IOM MULTI YEAR / CRISE EN IRAK - ABRIS D'URGENCE ET ARTICLES DE SECOURS EN IRAK - OIM PLU
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Emergency Non-Food Items and Shelter in Iraq - IOM Multi Year
LongDescription: September 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate as armed clashes between Daesh and government forces drive displacement. Since January 2014, over 3.3 million people have been displaced and an additional 887,000 previously displaced people have returned to their homes that have often been destroyed, making it one of the largest cases of internal displacement in the world. The impending battle to retake Mosul - Iraq's second biggest city - from Daesh could result in over a million more IDPs. Persecution of minority groups is an ongoing concern as well as the protection of women and children who are at an increased risk of (and in some cases targeted for) sexual violence such as rape, as well as child, early and forced marriage. Canada is helping reduce the vulnerability of hundreds of thousands of crisis-affected people, especially women and children, through a broad spectrum of humanitarian assistance activities across Iraq.   GAC's multi-year humanitarian support to the International Organization for Migration (IOM) in Iraq is contributing to meeting the needs of vulnerable displaced populations. Project activities include: (1) providing life-saving emergency non-food item (NFI) and shelter support for vulnerable conflict-affected persons, including IDPs, (2) upgrading critical shelters through technical, cash and material support for vulnerable IDPs, returnees and host communities, and (3) supporting replacement NFI/shelter assistance for vulnerable displaced persons.

ShortDescription: IRAQ HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE JUNE 2015: IN RESPONSE TO THE CRISIS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Iraq Humanitarian Assistance June 2015: In Response To The Crisis In Iraq
LongDescription: Funding under this investment provides humanitarian assistance in response to the crisis in Iraq. The humanitarian situation in Iraq is rapidly deteriorating as people continue fleeing attacks by Daesh and other armed opposition groups. Since the start of 2014, 3.2 million people have been displaced. Funding is being provided to the World Food Programme (WFP) for urgent food assistance, to the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) to provide targeted assistance to displaced women, girls and victims of gender-based violence, to the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) for shelter and non-food items and to Plan International Australia for medical assistance. The total value of this investment is $18 million, starting 2014-15.

ShortDescription: THE PROJECT FOR CAPACITY BUILDING OF THE KURDISTAN INSTITUTE
ProjectTitle: The Project for Capacity Building of the Kurdistan Institute
PurposeName: Public sector policy and administrative management
LongDescription: The Project for Capacity Building of the Kurdistan Institute of Public Administration (KIPA), initiated in December 2013 with support from the Korea International Cooperation Agency (KOICA), aimed to enhance the administrative capabilities of the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG). Implemented by the Korea Institute for Development Strategy (KDS) in partnership with Konkuk University, the project focused on developing a comprehensive master plan for KIPA, restructuring its organizational framework, and creating specialized training programs and curricula. The project also involved dispatching Korean experts to Erbil and organizing invitational training programs in South Korea for KRG officials and KIPA staff. The initiative was officially launched in February 2014 with a kick-off meeting attended by key KRG officials, including Dr. Ali Sindi, the Minister of Planning, and representatives from KOICA

ShortDescription: UNICEF 2019 APPEAL FOR SYRIA REGIONAL REFUGEE AND RESILIENCE PLAN (3RP)
ProjectTitle: UNICEF 2019 Appeal for Syria Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP)
LongDescription: The 2019 UNICEF Syria Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP) in Iraq focused on supporting Syrian refugee children and their families, primarily in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KR-I). The program provided essential services including education, child protection, health, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) interventions. A key implementation site was the Darashakran Refugee Camp in Erbil Governorate, which hosted a significant number of Syrian refugees.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CHILD PROTECTION AND GBV SERVICES
ProjectTitle: Iraq Child Protection and GBV Services
LongDescription: To ensure sustained and enhanced preventive and responsive Child Protection and GBV services for conflict-affected, displaced children and women in and outside of camps
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: UN-HABITAT PROMOTING PEACE AND STABILITY IN IRAQ BY FACILITATING SUSTAINABLE RETURNS
ProjectTitle: UN-HABITAT Promoting peace and stability in Iraq by facilitating sustainable returns
PurposeName: Facilitation of orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobili
LongDescription: In 2022, UN-Habitat, with support from the Korea International Cooperation Agency (KOICA), launched a two-year initiative aimed at facilitating the sustainable return of displaced populations to Sinjar, Iraq. This project focused on protecting housing, land, and property (HLP) rights, providing adequate housing, and ensuring access to essential water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) facilities to prevent the spread of COVID-19. A significant achievement of the project was the issuance of 180 land occupancy certificates to Yazidi households in Sinjar, granting them formal recognition of their land rights for the first time. Additionally, the rehabilitation of 578 houses in the Zanjili neighborhood of Mosul was completed, and vocational training was provided to 153 returnees, including 46 women. The project directly benefited 55,800 vulnerable individuals in Sinjar, contributing to the broader efforts of the Kurdistan Regional Government to support the return and reintegration of displaced communities.

ProjectTitle: Modernization of Public Procurement System in Kurdistan, Establishing E-Government Procurement

LongDescription: The activities of this proposed project are fully aligned with KRG 2020 Vision of `Effective, transparent, trusted and honest Government through effective use of information technologies and establishment of E-GP. This project consists of, (1)Development, pilot and rollout of E-Government Procurement, (2)Preparation of regulatory instruments, (3)Communication, Behavioral Change, and Capacity Building, (4) Renovation of current MoP`s building(Procurement Department)

ProjectTitle: Convention Weapons Destruction

IMCO's operations were crucial in mitigating the risks posed by explosive remnants of war, thereby enhancing civilian safety and facilitating the rehabilitation of affected areas

The project will implemented in collaborate with a local organisation.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - WATER AND HYGIENE ASSISTANCE FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PEOPLE - CARE CANADA 2017-2019 / CRISE EN IRAK - AIDE EN EAU ET HYGI횊NE POUR LES P
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Water and Hygiene Assistance for Internally Displaced People - CARE Canada 2017-2019
LongDescription: December 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 3 million people from their homes. The capacity of the Government to respond to the basic needs of its citizens has been overwhelmed. While Daesh has lost considerable territory in 2016, it is expected that humanitarian needs will remain significant in the coming years. More people will be displaced by the conflict, while many will remain displaced in camps and host communities. However, there will also be growing numbers of people returning to areas no longer under the control of Daesh who will also need assistance to help restart their lives.   With GAC's support, CARE Canada is implementing and extending water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) in camps and new and existing vulnerable host communities, improving overall services, and building the local capacity to continue providing WASH services to conflict-affected Iraqis. Project activities include: (1) providing water and repairing and/or maintaining water networks and sanitation facilities in camps, schools and host communities for up to 117,500 vulnerable conflict-affected people, (2) providing vouchers to allow families to procure needed hygiene supplies, (3) providing technical support and training to water management committees and local authorities to ensure the maintenance of water systems, and (4) providing training (or refresher training) sessions for volunteers on hygiene promotion, early marriage, referral systems for sexual gender-based violence (SGBV) and other protection issues.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - WINTER EMERGENCY HELP
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - winter emergency help
LongDescription: The Humanitarian Assistance winter emergency help project provides urgent winter relief specifically aimed at protecting children in Iraq from harsh cold conditions. It delivers shelter improvements, warm clothing, heating supplies, and health support to vulnerable children living in displacement camps and affected communities.

ProjectTitle: Support of the stabilization process in Iraq through coherent prevention of violence and extremism

ShortDescription: INTERNATIONAL NARCOTICS CONTROL AND LAW ENFORCEMENT: UNSPECIFIED LAW ENFORCEMENT ACTIVITIES
ProjectTitle: International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement: Unspecified Law Enforcement Activities
LongDescription: International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement (INCLE) advances U.S. national security interests by supporting bilateral, regional, and global programs that enable partners and allies to manage and address transnational threats at their source. INCLE programs mitigate security threats posed by all forms of transnational crime, including production and trafficking of narcotics, and strengthen partner countries' criminal justice systems. These programs improve the ability of partner countries to cooperate effectively with U.S. law enforcement, and address the underlying conditions, such as corruption and weak rule of law, that foster state fragility.

ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance Iraq Humanitarian Pooled Fund

ShortDescription: COVID-19 SUPPORT
ProjectTitle: Covid-19 Support
LongDescription: In 2021, the UK government committed £3 million (approximately US$4.1 million) to support Iraq's response to the COVID-19 pandemic. This funding aimed to bolster Iraq's health infrastructure and enhance its capacity to manage and mitigate the effects of the virus. The assistance was directed towards strengthening the country's health systems, improving preparedness and response mechanisms, and supporting the delivery of essential health services to vulnerable populations. By focusing on these areas, the UK aimed to contribute to Iraq's efforts in combating the pandemic and safeguarding public health.

ProjectTitle: Water, sanitation and hygiene services for conflict-affected populations in Iraq.

A key implementation site was the Salamiyah 2 Camp in Ninewa Governorate, where interventions included the provision of safe drinking water, sanitation facilities, and hygiene promotion activities to support the health and well-being of internally displaced persons.

ShortDescription: ENHANCING EMPLOYABILITY FOR VULNERABLE YOUTH IN NINAWA, IRAQ(UNESCO)
ProjectTitle: Enhancing employability for vulnerable youth in Ninawa, IRAQ(UNESCO)
LongDescription: In 2022, UNESCO, with support from the Republic of Korea, launched a project aimed at enhancing the employability of vulnerable youth in Nineveh Governorate, Iraq. The initiative focused on improving the quality of technical education at three vocational education and training (TVET) institutions based on labor market demands. Key activities included curriculum development aligned with industry needs, capacity building for educators, and the establishment of linkages between training programs and employment opportunities. The project sought to equip youth with relevant skills to increase their employability and contribute to the region's socio-economic development. As of September 2024, 100 youth had benefited from the program, with plans for expansion to reach more beneficiaries in the future.

ShortDescription: BRITISH COUNCIL - IRAQ
ProjectTitle: British Council - Iraq
LongDescription: Contributing to development through projects which support the skills and employability of young people, strengthen English language teaching and learning and increase collaboration in higher education and research.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - ASSISTANCE FOR PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES - HANDICAP INTERNATIONAL CANADA 2017-2019 / CRISE EN IRAK - AIDE AUX PERSONNES HANDICAP횋ES - HAN
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Assistance for People with Disabilities - Handicap International Canada 2017-2019
LongDescription: December 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 3 million people from their homes. The capacity of the Government to respond to the basic needs of its citizens has been overwhelmed. While Daesh has lost considerable territory in 2016, it is expected that humanitarian needs will remain significant in the coming years. More people will be displaced by the conflict, while many will remain displaced in camps and host communities. However, there will also be growing numbers of people returning to areas no longer under the control of Daesh who will also need assistance to help restart their lives.   With GAC's support, Handicap International Canada is improving the accessibility of physical rehabilitation, psychosocial support services and community awareness of environmental risks for vulnerable conflict-affected Iraqis. Project activities include: (1) providing physical and functional rehabilitation services, and psychosocial support services to people with functional limitations, psychosocial distress and their caregivers, (2) providing training, equipment and assistive devices to local structures providing physical rehabilitation services, (3) conducting awareness activities on chemical weapons (CW) and improvised explosive devices (IED), and (4) improving the accessibility of local structures.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - IMPROVING HEALTH, LIVELIHOODS AND PROTECTION - ICRC 2016-2019/CRISE EN IRAK - AM횋LIORER LA SANT횋, LES MOYENS DE SUBSISTANCE ET LA PROTEC
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Improving Health, Livelihoods and Protection - ICRC 2016-2019
LongDescription: September 2016 ??The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate as armed clashes between Daesh and government forces drive displacement. Since January 2014, over 3.3 million people have been displaced and an additional 887,000 previously displaced people have returned to their homes that have often been destroyed, making it one of the largest cases of internal displacement in the world. Persecution of minority groups is an ongoing concern as well as the protection of women and children who are at an increased risk of (and in some cases targeted for) sexual violence such as rape, as well as child, early and forced marriage. Canada is helping reduce the vulnerability of hundreds of thousands of crisis-affected people, especially women and children, through a broad spectrum of humanitarian assistance activities across Iraq.GAC's multi-year humanitarian support to the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) is contributing to improved health, living conditions, livelihoods and protection in conflict-affected regions of Iraq. Project activities include: (1) providing food assistance and non-food essential relief items to conflict-affected people, (2) providing emergency cash assistance and support of productive inputs for livelihoods, (3) providing water and shelter support, (4) providing medical services through direct support to health centres and hospitals, and (5) providing physical rehabilitation and support to vulnerable persons.

ShortDescription: PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT AND SUPPORT PROGRAM (PMSP)
ProjectTitle: Performance Management And Support Program (PMSP)
LongDescription: IBTCI is supplementing the monitoring and program management efforts of USAID/Iraq staff to verify, monitor and support USAID program performance evaluation in Iraq. Information gathered and program support services being provided by IBTCI are assisting the Mission to make informed decisions and better manage Implementing Partners (IP) performance throughout the reporting of USAID/Iraq activities and projects. Services IBTCI is currently providing to the USAID/Iraq Mission include supporting the development and implementation of USAID/Iraqs Performance Management Plan (PMP), providing independent monitoring of the implementation of USAID/ Iraqs programs and activities and progress in achieving intended results, and providing evaluation services. IBTCI is integrating gender considerations, mitigation of environmental impacts, and future sustainability of results into its work.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: PROVIDE MULTI-SECTORAL AREA-BASED HUMANITARIAN RESPONSE
ProjectTitle: Provide multi-sectoral area-based humanitarian response
LongDescription: In 2019, a multi-sectoral humanitarian response in Iraq focused on providing essential services—including Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH), Economic Recovery and Market Systems (ERMS), Health Care Information Management (HCIM), and Shelter—to conflict-affected populations. A key implementation site was the Qayyarah Airstrip Emergency Site in Ninewa Governorate, offering critical support to internally displaced persons.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE - UNHCR 2015 / CRISE EN IRAQ - AIDE D URGENCE - HCR 2015
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Emergency Assistance - UNHCR 2015
LongDescription: March 2015 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 2.4 million people from their homes. An estimated 5.2 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. As fighting and human rights violations persist and international efforts remain to free territory controlled by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), the situation is expected to deteriorate and to cause additional displacement.   With DFATD s support and other donors, UNHCR is providing assistance and protection to people of concern in Iraq. Project activities include: (1) providing 1,350,000 conflict-affected people with access to legal assistance, (2) increasing the capacity of local authorities to establish and maintain camps for internally displaced people, (3) providing 50,000 emergency shelters, clothing and other essential relief items to 120,000 families, (4) providing healthcare and support services to survivors of sexual and gender-based violence in camps, and (5) working with local Iraqi organizations to increase their capacity to provide safe, confidential, non-discriminatory and compassionate comprehensive services to women and girls.

ShortDescription: SUPPORT TO THE COMMUNITY REINTEGRATION OF IRAQI RETURNEES FROM SYRIA
ProjectTitle: Support to the community reintegration of Iraqi returnees from Syria
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: The action seeks to support the reintegration of Iraqis into local communities after they have been repatriated from Syria and gone through the Iraqi security screening process in the Jeddah camps. The action will benefit both the repatriated Iraqis as well as the receiving communities in line with the Iraqi community integration programme. Activities will be identified to meet local needs with an emphasis on conflict prevention, dialogue and social cohesion and legal rights for children.&nbsp &

ShortDescription: BROADENING PARTICIPATION THROUGH CIVIL SOCIETY (BPCS) - SOCIAL SERVICES
ProjectTitle: Broadening Participation through Civil Society (BPCS) - Social Services
LongDescription: The overall goal of the project is for the Iraqi political system to function through a more sustainable, participatory democratic model by the end of the three-year effort. The project will pursue the overarching objective of increasing citizen input into Iraq s development through the following planned results: 1) democratic engagement of citizens increased, 2) institutional capacity of civil society organizations (CSOs) increased, 3) impact of civil society on public policy increased, and 4) enabling environment for civil society improved.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: CONTRIBUTION TO INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR MIGRATION ACTIVITIES IN IRAQ IN SUPPORT OF THE SYRIA REGIONAL REFUGEE AND RESILIENCE PLAN (3RP)
ProjectTitle: Contribution to International Organization for Migration Activities in Iraq in Support of the Syria Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP)
LongDescription: The 2015 U.S.-funded contribution to the International Organization for Migration (IOM) supported activities under Iraq's chapter of the Syria Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP). IOM provided assistance to Syrian refugees in Iraq, including livelihood support, shelter assistance, and mental health services. A key implementation site was the Darashakran Camp in Erbil Governorate, which housed a significant number of Syrian refugees during that period.

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY FOOD ASSISTANCE OVER CASH ASSISTANCE IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Emergency food assistance over cash assistance in Iraq
LongDescription: The Emergency Food Assistance over Cash Assistance project provides immediate food aid to vulnerable populations in Iraq, prioritizing direct food supplies over cash transfers to ensure timely nutritional support during crises and reduce market dependency.

ShortDescription: LONG-TERM ASSISTANCE AND SERVICES FOR RESEARCH (LASER)
ProjectTitle: Long-term Assistance and Services for Research (LASER)
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: Long-term Assistance and Services for Research (LASER) will leverage and support international university networks, inclusive of universities from both the United States (U.S) and lower-middle income countries (LMIC), to undertake novel and innovative development research, collaborate with Missions and local actors to design and undertake research projects, and create connections that accelerate the uptake of research outputs by development actors and policy makers. The resulting LASER network will not only generate new knowledge for USAID, but also initiate long term, sustainable collaborations between U.S. and developing country institutions that are characterized by equitable university partnerships.  Services this mechanism will provide: Co-creation and implementation of research activitiesResearch design, primary data collection and analysis, Technical reports with potential for USAID co-authorshipTranslation of research findings into policy and program relevant recommendations, Academic-style program evaluation (answers a sector relevant, hypothesis-driven question), Sustained engagement with research faculty.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: CAPACITY BUILDING FOR REDUCTION OF IMPROVISED EXPLOSIVE DEVICE (IEDS)
ProjectTitle: Capacity building for reduction of improvised explosive device (IEDs)
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: The Capacity Building for Reduction of Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs) project supports stabilization and humanitarian efforts by training Iraqi civil authorities in identifying, mitigating, and safely managing explosive hazards. This training enhances local capacity to reduce IED threats, facilitating safer conditions for civilians to return to their communities.

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY ACTIVITIES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Emergency Activities in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2017, Japan continued its humanitarian support to Iraq through a comprehensive emergency assistance package totaling approximately $100 million. This initiative aimed to address the immediate needs of communities affected by conflict, particularly internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host populations. Implemented in coordination with UN agencies, international organizations, and Japanese NGOs, the assistance encompassed various sectors, including food security, water, sanitation, hygiene, health, nutrition, shelter, non-food items, livelihood support, vocational training, protection, gender-based violence prevention, mine action, and infrastructure rehabilitation. The focus was on areas such as Mosul and its surrounding regions, where significant displacement had occurred due to the ongoing conflict. This support was part of Japan's broader commitment to Iraq's stabilization and recovery efforts.

ShortDescription: ENHANCING HOST COUNTRY'S RULE OF LAW
ProjectTitle: Enhancing Host Country's Rule of Law
LongDescription: Aim: strengthen Iraq civilian criminal justice bodies ability to investigate, prosecute and convict criminals in accordance with human rights and international law by identifying where reform is needed to mitigate societal and economic impact.
Name_of_Donor: United Kingdom, Conflict stability and security fund

ShortDescription: PROVIDE ASSISTANCE IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Provide assistance in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2018, humanitarian organizations provided assistance in Iraq, including health services, water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH), protection, non-food items (NFIs), shelter, and multi-purpose cash assistance (MPCA). A key implementation site was the Qayyarah Airstrip Emergency Site in Ninewa Governorate, offering critical support to internally displaced persons.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: CONFLICT MITIGATION AND STABILIZATION
ProjectTitle: Conflict Mitigation and Stabilization
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: Reduce the threat or impact of violent conflict and promote the peaceful resolution of differences, mitigate violence if it has already broken out, or establish a framework for peace and reconciliation. This is done by identifying the causes of conflict and state failure, supporting early responses that address the causes and consequences of instability and conflict, and developing long lasting solutions to the problems that drive conflict. This includes support for processes and mechanisms for reconciliation and conflict mitigation no matter what the source of the conflict may be, though this may require integration with other elements.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: SUPPORTING THE KOREA-IRAQ VOCATIONAL TRAINING CENTER IN IRQ (II)
ProjectTitle: Supporting the Korea-Iraq Vocational Training Center in Irq (II)
LongDescription: n 2014, the Republic of Korea, through the Korea International Cooperation Agency (KOICA), launched the second phase of the Supporting the Korea-Iraq Vocational Training Center in Iraq project. This initiative aimed to enhance vocational education and training (TVET) infrastructure in Iraq by renovating the training center, supplying modern equipment, and building the capacity of local officials. Key activities included dispatching Korean experts to provide technical assistance and conducting invitation programs to train Iraqi personnel in South Korea. These efforts were designed to improve the quality of vocational training and align it with labor market needs, thereby supporting economic development and employment opportunities in Iraq.

ShortDescription: ICRC OPERATION IN IRAQ IN 2015
ProjectTitle: ICRC operation in Iraq in 2015
LongDescription: In 2015, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) intensified its humanitarian operations in Iraq, responding to the escalating conflict and displacement crisis. With over 3 million people displaced due to ongoing hostilities, the ICRC focused on providing essential aid to those in hard-to-reach and conflict-affected areas. Their efforts included distributing food and essential household items, offering cash assistance, and improving access to clean water and healthcare services. Additionally, the ICRC supported physical rehabilitation services for individuals with disabilities and worked to restore family links disrupted by the conflict. Their operations were particularly concentrated in regions such as Anbar, Mosul, and Sinjar. Despite challenges in accessing certain areas, the ICRC remained committed to alleviating the suffering of affected populations through its comprehensive humanitarian response.

ShortDescription: SUPPORT TO OXFAM'S INTEGRATED FOOD SECURITY AND WASH RESPONSE TO DROUGHT AFFECTED COMMUNITIES OF SOMALI REGIONAL STATE, ETHIOPIA.
ProjectTitle: Support to Oxfam's integrated food security and WASH response to drought affected communities of Somali Regional State, Ethiopia.
LongDescription: In 2017, Oxfam implemented an integrated food security and WASH response in Iraq to assist communities affected by conflict and displacement. The program provided emergency water, sanitation, hygiene services, and food assistance to vulnerable populations, particularly internally displaced persons (IDPs). A key implementation site was the Golat Camp in Debaga, Erbil Governorate, where Oxfam and partners delivered critical support to mitigate the impact of the crisis.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

AgencyName: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade
ShortDescription: FUNDING FACILITY FOR STABILIZATION IN IRAQ_UNDP
ProjectTitle: Funding Facility for Stabilization in Iraq_UNDP
LongDescription: In 2018, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) of the Republic of Korea contributed $5 million to the United Nations Development Programme's (UNDP) Funding Facility for Stabilization (FFS) in Iraq. This contribution aimed to support the stabilization and recovery efforts in areas liberated from the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), particularly in the governorates of Anbar, Salah al-Din, Diyala, Kirkuk, and Ninewa. The funding was utilized to rehabilitate essential infrastructure, repair damaged houses, and facilitate the return of internally displaced persons (IDPs) to their homes. By the end of 2018, UNDP had implemented over 2,800 projects across these regions, focusing on sectors such as water, electricity, education, health, and municipal services. This initiative marked Korea's fifth contribution to the FFS since its inception in 2015, reflecting the country's ongoing commitment to supporting Iraq's recovery and stabilization efforts.
Name_of_Donor: Korea, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

ShortDescription: PROTECTION AND ASSISTANCE TO INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS (IDPS), IDP RETURNEES, AND REFUGEES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Protection and assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs), IDP returnees, and refugees in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2022, the Government of Japan continued its vital support for internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and refugees in Iraq through a significant contribution to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). This funding enabled UNHCR to provide essential legal assistance to over 8,500 individuals, including survivors of gender-based violence, facilitating their access to justice and protection services. Additionally, Japan's support facilitated the provision of civil documentation to more than 9,000 IDPs, ensuring their access to rights and services. These efforts were crucial in addressing the challenges faced by displaced populations in Iraq, contributing to their protection and well-being.

ShortDescription: SESAME WORKSHOP AHLAN SIMSIM IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Sesame Workshop Ahlan Simsim Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: In 2021, Sesame Workshop launched the Ahlan Simsim Iraq initiative, a USAID-funded program aimed at supporting children affected by conflict and displacement. Collaborating with partners like Save the Children and Mercy Corps, the program provided early childhood education through engaging content, including storybooks and activity guides, and trained educators to deliver social-emotional learning. A key implementation site was Mosul, where the program helped children transition into formal schooling
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: OFFICE OF WEAPONS REMOVAL AND ABATEMENT - NPA ERW CLEARANCE ANBAR IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Office of Weapons Removal and Abatement - NPA ERW Clearance Anbar Iraq
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: U.S. Department of State: Office of Weapons Removal and Abatement. New award obligating $4,674,268 for 18 month POP. No pre-award costs. See terms and conditions below. Required form DS-7655 is attached.

ShortDescription: IRAQ COVID-19 PREVENTION AND RESPONSE
ProjectTitle: Iraq COVID-19 Prevention and Response
LongDescription: The "Iraq COVID-19 Prevention and Response" project, funded by the U.S. through USAID in 2020, aimed to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 among both camp and non-camp populations in Iraq. Implementing partners, including organizations like GOAL, focused on enhancing preparedness and response measures in vulnerable communities. Key activities encompassed risk communication, community engagement, and the provision of essential health services and supplies to support the Iraqi health system's capacity to manage the pandemic effectively.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: COVID-19 ASSISTANCE
ProjectTitle: COVID-19 Assistance
LongDescription: The 2021 "COVID-19 Assistance" project aimed to curb the transmission of COVID-19 within Iran and prevent its spread to other countries. This initiative focused on enhancing Iran's capacity to manage the pandemic through the procurement of essential medical equipment, strengthening healthcare infrastructure, and supporting public health interventions. Efforts included bolstering diagnostic capabilities, improving treatment facilities, and facilitating the distribution of critical supplies to healthcare providers across the country.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: REHABILITATION OF THE DAMAGED DISTRIBUTION TRANSFORMERS AND RELATED SERVICES
ProjectTitle: Rehabilitation of the Damaged Distribution Transformers and related services
PurposeName: Electric power transmission and distribution (centralised grids)
LongDescription: Provided the equipment required for rehabilitating damaged transformer to meet demand of quantity and quality, Trained the skills and operation technique for rehabilitating the damanged transformer, Provided new transformers for public facililty and new service area, Provided consultation on the transformer and the distribution network management, Participated electricity policy incumbent and concerned officials in the invitational tainining on the distribution network manangement and police enhancement

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE- ASSISTANCE AND PROTECTION ACTIVITIES
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance- Assistance and protection activities
LongDescription: The "Humanitarian Assistance – Assistance and Protection Activities" project, funded by Germany in 2015, aimed to provide comprehensive support to vulnerable populations in Iraq, including internally displaced persons (IDPs), refugees, and host communities. Implemented by the German Federal Foreign Office (AA) and executed by various partners, the project focused on delivering essential humanitarian aid, protection services, and preventive measures to alleviate the suffering of affected individuals and promote their safety and well-being.

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY AND REHABILITATION ACTIVITIES FOR?IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Emergency and Rehabilitation Activities for Iraq
LongDescription: Japan provided significant support to the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in 2020 to aid emergency and rehabilitation efforts in Iraq. This funding addressed urgent needs arising from conflict and displacement, especially amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The initiatives emphasized social stability and resilience through community-based reconciliation, livelihood assistance, and infrastructure rebuilding. These efforts helped facilitate the safe return and reintegration of displaced populations while bolstering stability across affected regions such as Anbar, Ninewa, and Salah al-Din governorates.

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: FIRST ALLOCATION OF SDC FUNDING (EUROPE AND MEDITERRANEAN REGION DIVISION) TO ICRC OPERATIONS IN 2014 IRAQ, JORDAN, LEBANON, SYRIA
ProjectTitle: First Allocation of SDC Funding (Europe and Mediterranean Region Division) to ICRC Operations in 2014 Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, Syria
LongDescription: In line with the Good Humanitarian Donorship (GHD) principles, Switzerland recognizes the necessity of predictable and flexible funding to respond to changing needs in humanitarian crises. SDC funding to ICRC operations allows the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) to respond proactively and to provide immediate protection and assistance for people affected by armed conflict and other situations of violence.혻혻
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: SUSTAINABLE SHELTERS  CAMP INFRASTR[AWARDS-  COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS]
ProjectTitle: Sustainable Shelters  Camp Infrastr[Awards-  Cooperative Agreements]
LongDescription: Enhance durable solutions, safety, and self-reliance for vulnerable Syrian refugees in Iraq by improving shelters, infrastructure, and livelihoods

ShortDescription: OPPORTUNITIES FORAS PROJECT - STRENGTHEN MICROENTERPRISE PRODUCTIVITY
ProjectTitle: Opportunities Foras Project - Strengthen Microenterprise Productivity
LongDescription: The "Opportunities Foras Project," initiated in 2013, was a USAID-funded economic growth initiative aimed at enhancing microenterprise productivity and employment opportunities in Iraq. Implemented by FHI 360 in partnership with ACDI/VOCA, the project focused on improving job matching, workforce development, and entrepreneurship support, particularly targeting youth, women, and internally displaced persons. Key activities included vocational training, business development services, and the establishment of an online employment portal to connect job seekers with employers. The project operated in five major economic hubs: Baghdad, Basra, Karbala, Najaf, and Erbil.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: SUPPORT TO IRAQ'S ELECTORAL PROCESS
ProjectTitle: Support to Iraq's Electoral Process
LongDescription: The overall expected result of the project is a more credible and transparent electoral commission (IHEC) that promotes inclusion and participation in electoral processes.

ShortDescription: BUREAU OF NEAR EASTERN AFFAIRS - AMERICAN STYLE HIGHER EDUCATION IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs - American Style Higher Education in Iraq
LongDescription: The "Reconciliation and Prosperity in Iraq through American-Style Higher Education" project, funded by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs in 2021, aimed to bolster American-style higher education in Iraq. This initiative focused on enhancing institutional capacities, promoting liberal arts education, and fostering international academic partnerships. Key beneficiaries included the American University of Iraq – Baghdad (AUIB), which commenced its inaugural class in 2021 on the historic grounds of Saddam Hussein’s former Al Faw Palace, and the American University of Kurdistan (AUK) in Duhok, supported through capacity-building programs facilitated by the Center for International Stabilization and Recovery (CISR) at James Madison University.

ShortDescription: BUREAU OF NEAR EASTERN AFFAIRS - SUPPORTING AMERICAN STYLE HIGHER ED
ProjectTitle: Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs - Supporting American Style Higher Education
LongDescription: U.S. Department of State: Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs. This award will support American-style Higher Education in Iraq.[Covers awards where the principle purpose of the relationship is the transfer of money, property, services, or anything of value to the state, local government, or other recipient to accomplish a public purpose of support or stimulation authorized by the Federal statute.]

ShortDescription: IMPROVING SUSTAINABLE SHELTERS, CAMP INFRASTRUCTURE, AND LIVELIHOODS FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES IN KURDISTAN REGION OF IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Improving Sustainable Shelters, Camp Infrastructure, and Livelihoods for Syrian Refugees in Kurdistan Region of Iraq
LongDescription: The "Improving Sustainable Shelters, Camp Infrastructure, and Livelihoods for Syrian Refugees in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq" project, launched in 2020 by Peace Winds America with funding from the U.S. Department of State’s Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM), aimed to enhance living conditions and promote self-reliance among Syrian refugees. Focusing on vulnerable groups such as individuals with disabilities, the elderly, and female-headed households, the initiative upgraded over 4,500 shelters across multiple camps, including Domiz 1, Domiz 2, Gawilan, Basirma, Darashakran, Kawergosk, and Qushtapa. The project also improved accessibility in public facilities and established tool service centers offering vocational training and cash-for-work opportunities, thereby fostering skill development and economic empowerment within the refugee communities.

ShortDescription: MOSUL DAM PREPARATION
ProjectTitle: Mosul Dam preparation
LongDescription: The "Mosul Dam Emergency Preparedness Programme," initiated in 2019 by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) with funding from the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), aimed to enhance the safety and operational readiness of the Mosul Dam in Iraq. Recognizing the dam's structural vulnerabilities due to its foundation on soluble gypsum rock, the project focused on developing a comprehensive Safe Operational Plan and conducting specialized training for technical staff to mitigate the risk of catastrophic failure. These efforts were part of a broader strategy to protect millions of people living downstream along the Tigris River, including residents of Mosul and Baghdad, from potential flooding hazards.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT AND EVALUATION SUPPORT
ProjectTitle: Performance Management and Evaluation Support
LongDescription: The USAID/Iraq Performance Management and Evaluation Services (PMES) program, launched in 2020, is a five-year initiative designed to enhance the effectiveness of USAID's development efforts in Iraq. Implemented by Management Systems International (MSI), a Tetra Tech Company, with support from Integrated International, PMES focuses on improving performance management practices, conducting evaluations and assessments, and building monitoring and evaluation (M&E) capacity among USAID staff and implementing partners. Key components include increasing the frequency and quality of project monitoring, utilizing evaluation results for informed decision-making, and promoting a culture of collaboration, learning, and adaptation (CLA) within USAID/Iraq. The program also provides third-party monitoring services, especially in challenging environments, to ensure accountability and transparency in USAID-funded activities.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: CAPACITY BUILDING FOR REDUCTION OF IMPROVISED EXPLOSIVE DEVICES (IEDS)
ProjectTitle: Capacity building for reduction of improvised explosive devices (IEDs)
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: The project will contribute to the stabilisation of Iraq and the strengthening of its authorities in dealing with explosive devices. Thereby the security in Iraq will be increased and the return to liberated areas is enabled. Government strategic coordination mechanisms will be strengthened to support the establishment of a common approach to clearance of explosive hazards.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: SAFE SPACES FOR REFUGEE CHILDREN AND YOUTH, IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Safe spaces for refugee children and youth, iraq
LongDescription: Improvement of the precarious living conditions, in particular of the child protection, as well as strengthening of the resilience of 5,000 children and youngsters in four refugee camps and five municipalities plus measures for inclusion. 25 psychologists qualified in Iraq are trained in the project course as trauma therapists and 5 already practising therapists in the locations of Dohuk and Erbil. (Jiyan foundation) In Erbil 3,200 children receive informal school lessons and language teaching to be prepared for the integration in the school system.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: PROVISION OF INTEGRATED EMERGENCY REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH AND GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE RESPONSE SERVICES TO IDP AND REFUGEE WOMEN IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Provision of integrated emergency reproductive health and gender-based violence response services to IDP and Refugee women in Iraq
