ShortDescription: IMPROVING SAFETY AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR VULNERABLE INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS AND RETURNEES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Improving Safety and Economic Opportunities for Vulnerable Internally Displaced Persons and Returnees in Iraq
LongDescription: The "Improving Safety and Economic Opportunities for Vulnerable Internally Displaced Persons and Returnees in Iraq" project, funded by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM) and implemented by the International Rescue Committee (IRC), aimed to enhance the safety and economic well-being of vulnerable populations in Iraq. The IRC operated in six Iraqi governorates, establishing seven offices and 23 community centers across both Federal Iraq and the Kurdistan Region. Their programs focused on legal case management, protection monitoring, women's and child protection, education, early childhood development, cash transfers, and income-boosting livelihoods activities. The IRC's strategy prioritized improving outcomes in safety, education, economic well-being, and empowerment, particularly for internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, Syrian refugees, and vulnerable host communities in underserved areas.

ShortDescription: THE PROJECT FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT AND CAPACITY BUILDING OF ICU(INTENSIVE CARE UNIT) IN MEDICAL CITY, BAGHDAD, REP. OF IRAQ
ProjectTitle: The Project of Building ICU unit in the Medical City
LongDescription: ICU construction. Equipment support upon demand. On-the-spot training(capacity enhancement). Dispatch of skilled personnel. Project oversight

ShortDescription: WORLD BANK -IRAQ REFORM AND RECONSTRUCTION FUND - IRAQ REFORM AND RECONSTRUCTION FUND
ProjectTitle: World Bank -Iraq Reform and Reconstruction Fund - Iraq Reform and Reconstruction Fund
LongDescription: The World Bank s Iraq Reform, Recovery and Reconstruction Fund (I3RF) aims to create a platform for coordinated funding and dialogue for the reconstruction and development of Iraq, with focus on improving the effectiveness of public investment in socio-economic recovery, reconstruction, supporting national reform efforts for economic diversification and private sector growth. After years of armed conflict, the need for funding for the recovery and reconstruction of Iraq is big. In total, the cost of recovery and reconstruction is estimated at $ 88 billion.The Iraqi government has developed a Recovery, Reconstruction and Development Plan (RRDP), which includes the establishment of a Multi Donor Trust Fund (MTDF). Its aim is to effectively co-finance international partners to support effective investment, facilitate dialogue, share information and coordinate Iraq s reform program, which forms the basis of the I3RF, whose objectives, structure and scope are closely aligned with the RRDP.The work takes place in close contact with the Iraqi government, donors and INGOs. I3RF s activities will be carried out by the Iraqi government, organizations, and VB to enable maximum response to reforms and reconstruction needs and to ensure national political ownership. To ensure that there is also a sense and will for ownership within the framework of the fund s results, the I3RF Secretariat has facilitated the creation of a policy document (White Paper) by the Iraqi government, with feedback from donors, which will be a leading document for the government s plan to tackle reform issues within the framework of the fund.The fund has three overall areas of activity, Socio-economic recovery, with a focus on the reconstruction of urban areas, institution building, development of social capital, rehabilitation of cultural heritage, improving the provision of services to people in poverty and vulnerability, and the creation of job opportunities for vulnerable groups. Economic diversification and private sector development, including technical advice and dialogue in trade and investment policy reforms, support for the financial sector and banking reform, improving the environment for small and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups by increasing the availability of borrowing opportunities. Coordination and program support, support for strengthened capacity of the Iraqi government to plan, coordinate and follow up reconstruction programs.Within the strategy for Sweden s cooperation with the World Bank Group (VBG) 2020-2023, which Sida s support will follow, there are four priority areas:1. Inclusive, sustainable economic growth and development,2. Environment and climate,3. Gender equality,4. Peace and state building.All four areas are integrated within the framework of I3RF, and Sida will, through dialogue with VB, work to ensure that these areas are prioritized in the projects. Within the Iraq strategy, Sweden must also prioritize co-operation that promotes peaceful an

ShortDescription: SAVE THE CHILDREN SWEDEN HUM 2021-2025
ProjectTitle: Save the Children Sweden HUM 2021-2025
LongDescription: During 2020, Sida s Unit for Humanitarian Assistance conducted an overview of ongoing strategic partnerships in order to ensure that partnerships were established with the most relevant and effective humanitarian actors to carry out Sida s Humanitarian Strategy.혻As a result of the overview, Sida has decided to appraise a new contribution and enter into a new strategic partnership agreement with Save the Children Sweden (SCS) for the period 2021-2025 (see archive number 2021-000057).In 2021, the following is proposed in support to SCS:혻Annual Projects in line with Humanitarian Response Plans (12 months) -혻SEK 63혻million, Rapid Response Mechanism support - SEK 25혻million,혻Capacity Building and Method Development support - SEK 5.593혻million, Surge Support - SEK 800,000, and Operational and Technical Support to SCS s HQ - SEK 5 million.혻This means that the혻total initial contribution to SCS in 2021 would amount to SEK 99,393,000.혻The overall objective of the intervention is to contribute to the promotion of three Breakthroughs in the way children are treated in the world:혻Survive, Learn혻and혻Be Protected.혻These혻are part of the Save the Children movement s Vision for 2030 and are defined as remarkable and sustainable shifts from current trends that Save the Children aspires to work to achieve for children. Their respective objective is the following:1. Survive: No child dies of preventable causes before their fifth birthday.혻2. Learn: All children learn from quality basic education.3. Be Protected: Violence against children is no longer tolerated.혻One of the main comparative advantages of Save the Children is its competence in addressing protection-related concerns. For this reason, Centrality of Protection has been proposed as the thematic frame, making the혻Be Protected혻Breakthrough particularly central for its interventions during the agreement period. Finally, in addition to these three Breakthroughs, the proposed contribution also aligns with Sweden s newly adopted  Strategy for Sweden's humanitarian assistance provided through the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida) 2021??025 .

ShortDescription: INNOVATE
ProjectTitle: Innovate
LongDescription: Mercy Corps' 2018 "Innovate" project in Iraq, funded by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, aimed to enhance economic opportunities for conflict-affected youth through innovative employment and livelihoods programming. The project focused on providing vocational training, supporting small businesses, and facilitating access to financial services, thereby fostering economic resilience among internally displaced persons, host communities, and Syrian refugees. The initiative was implemented in the Erbil and Sulaymaniyah governorates, addressing the pressing need for sustainable livelihoods in these regions.

ShortDescription: ICASS COSTS
ProjectTitle: ICASS Costs
LongDescription: The "ICASS Costs" entry for 2022 refers to the International Cooperative Administrative Support Services (ICASS) system, a U.S. government framework that manages and funds shared administrative services at overseas posts. In Iraq, ICASS supports the operations of U.S. government agencies by providing essential services such as human resources, financial management, procurement, and facility maintenance. These services are primarily coordinated through the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, ensuring efficient and cost-effective support for diplomatic and consular activities across the country. While ICASS is not a traditional project with a specific site, its implementation is centralized at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, located at the following coordinates:
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: PROMOTING EQUITABLE ACCESS TO LIFE-SAVING CHILD PROTECTION, HEALTH, NUTRITION AND EDUCATION SERVICES FOR AL-HOL RETURNEES
ProjectTitle: Promoting equitable access to life-saving child protection, health, nutrition and education services for Al-Hol returnees
LongDescription: Promoting equitable access to life-saving child protection, health, nutrition and education services for Al-Hol returnees

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance
LongDescription: In 2017, Germany provided €4.1 million in humanitarian assistance to support the provision of essential life-saving primary and secondary health care services in the Iraqi governorates of Ninewa, Dohuk, and Erbil. This funding was allocated through the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Iraq Humanitarian Fund, aiming to address the critical health needs of internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities affected by ongoing conflict and displacement.

ShortDescription: BILATERAL DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION
ProjectTitle: Bilateral development cooperation
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: The 2017 bilateral development cooperation program in Iraq focused on strengthening peace and security as part of Sweden’s international development efforts. This cooperation aimed to support stability, conflict prevention, and security sector reform by collaborating with Iraqi government institutions, civil society, and international partners. Key activities included capacity building for security forces, promoting human rights and rule of law, and fostering dialogue to prevent conflict escalation.

ShortDescription: PREVENTION OF FURTHER SPREAD OF THE NOVEL CORONAVIRUS (COVID-19) INFECTION IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Prevention of Further Spread of the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) Infection in Iraq
LongDescription: Japan's 2020 initiative, "Prevention of Further Spread of the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) Infection in Iraq," provided critical support to Iraq's COVID-19 response through UNICEF. The project focused on enhancing public health measures, including the distribution of personal protective equipment (PPE), strengthening health systems, and conducting risk communication and community engagement (RCCE) activities. These efforts aimed to prevent the spread of COVID-19, protect vulnerable populations, and ensure the continuation of essential services during the pandemic

ShortDescription: ERW CLEARANCE IN IRAQI KURDISTAN
ProjectTitle: ERW Clearance in Iraqi Kurdistan
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: In 2019, the Mines Advisory Group (MAG), supported by U.S. funding, conducted extensive clearance of explosive remnants of war (ERW) in Iraqi Kurdistan. The operation focused on areas heavily contaminated due to past conflicts, aiming to enhance the safety and livelihoods of local communities. MAG's efforts included the removal of landmines and unexploded ordnance, facilitating the return of displaced persons and the restoration of agricultural and residential lands. These activities were coordinated with local authorities to ensure effective and sustainable outcomes.

ShortDescription: NRC AGREEMENT HUM 2017-2019
ProjectTitle: NRC agreement HUM 2017-2019
LongDescription: UPDATED 2018This is a supplementary decision to the agreement with the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) for their humanitarian program 2017-2019. The decision is made in accordance with Sida's contribution management rule, paragraph 3.11.3 and corresponds to the second year of a three year agreement.In accordance with Sida's humanitarian allocation process 2018, Sida proposes to support NRC's humanitarian programs in the following 21 countries, Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Democratic Republic of Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Nigeria, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Syrian Arab Republic, Uganda, Ukraine and Yemen. Sida will contribute with an unearmarked allocation per country, which will give NRC the flexibility to meet the most acute humanitarian needs in ever-changing contexts. However, in the specific case of Palestine, Sida will earmark the contribution to the ICLA-component, as this sector is considered high priority and as contributory to the HRPs focus on protection. The support to Central African Republic and the Democratic Republic of Congo is suggested to span over a two-year period. This is in line with Sida's ambition to increase our partner's predictability, and allow for their long-term planning and alignment with a multi-year HRP.Sida assesses NRC's country programs as relevant in relation to the Swedish strategy for humanitarian assistance 2017-2020, as well as the humanitarian needs identified in Sida's humanitarian crises analyses for 2018. Sida is also suggesting a multi-year contribution to NRC's Rapid Response Mechanism, to allow for a timely response to sudden onset situations or escalating crises. Furthermore, Sida suggests a two-year financial contribution to the NRC-led Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC), which strives to increase knowledge on the needs of internally displaced, and one-year contributions to the NRC/NORCAP managed project Strengthening capacity for use of cash- and market based responses in humanitarian action, to NRC's internal work on 'Digital Transformation' and to NRC's work on humanitarian policy, which includes work to strengthen the global humanitarian system and NGO participation in the system.Sida also proposes to channel funds through NRC for the support of three NGO platforms, the Jordan INGO Forum (JIF), the Lebanon Humanitarian INGO Forum (LHIF) and the International Association of Development Agencies (AIDA). In regard to AIDA, the Consulate General in Jerusalem has the intention to provide support for AIDA within the framework of the cooperation strategy for Palestine. Efficiency gains can be achieved by providing the support through the NRC-Sida humanitarian unit cooperation agreement, and it is thus suggested that Sida/HUM channels this limited development funding, with funding delegated from Palestine Strategy, decision number XXX XXXXNRC's target group is mainly comprised of refugees and internally displaced per

ShortDescription: SECOND TRANCHE - SYRIA HUMANITARIAN RESPONSE PLAN (3RP) IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Second Tranche - Syria Humanitarian Response Plan (3RP) Iraq
LongDescription: The "Second Tranche - Syria Humanitarian Response Plan (3RP) Iraq" project, implemented by UNICEF in 2016, aimed to address the protection and assistance needs of Syrian refugees and vulnerable host communities in Iraq. Funded by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, the initiative focused on delivering essential services such as education, child protection, health, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) across key governorates, including Erbil, Duhok, Sulaymaniyah, and Anbar. The project was part of the broader Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP), which coordinated multi-sectoral responses to the Syrian crisis in Iraq.

ShortDescription: CONTRIBUTION TO INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR MIGRATION NEEDS DEFINED IN THE SYRIA REGIONAL RESPONSE PLAN 5 - IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Contribution To International Organization for Migration Needs Defined in The Syria Regional Response Plan 5 - Iraq
LongDescription: The "Contribution to International Organization for Migration Needs Defined in the Syria Regional Response Plan 5 - Iraq" in 2013 involved U.S. funding to support IOM's humanitarian efforts for Syrian refugees and vulnerable Iraqi returnees. The initiative focused on providing emergency shelter, non-food items, transportation, and health services. IOM conducted vulnerability assessments and distributed aid in various locations, including Erbil, Anbar, and Nineveh governorates. One significant site of operation was the Al-Qaim refugee camp in Anbar Governorate, which served as a critical location for sheltering Syrian refugees during that period.

ShortDescription: INTERNEWS IRAQ PROGRAMME 2019-2021 - ASWATOUNA - OUR VOICES. ELEVATING AND AMPLIFYING WOMEN'S VOICES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Internews Iraq programme 2019-2021 - Aswatouna - Our voices. Elevating and Amplifying Women's Voices in Iraq
PurposeName: Women's rights organisations and movements, and government institutions
LongDescription: Internews Europe has applied to Sida for funding of 32 150 000 SEK to carry out the Aswatouna - Our Voices. Elevating and Amplifying Women's voices in Iraq during the period 2019-2021.The goal of the intervention is to empower women to participate equally as citizens and decision-makers by strengthening and expanding  women's voices in Iraq. The project will also contribute to Internews ongoing efforts globally to improve access to information as a root solution to enable women and men to make informed decisions, participate in dialogue and stand up for their rights

ShortDescription: PROMOTING GOVERNANCE (NON-SECURITY AND JUSTICE)
ProjectTitle: Promoting Governance (non-security and justice)
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: The UK's 2018 "Promoting Governance (non-security and justice)" programme in Iraq aimed to enhance governance structures and public service delivery in post-conflict regions. Implemented by the Department for International Development (DFID), the initiative focused on strengthening local government capacities, improving transparency, and fostering civic engagement to rebuild trust between citizens and the state. Key activities included supporting the planning and implementation of reconstruction efforts, enhancing public financial management, and promoting inclusive political processes. The programme was particularly active in areas such as Anbar, Nineveh, and Salah al-Din governorates, where governance institutions were severely impacted by conflict.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: BUILDING SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES, INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS, VULNERABLE MEMBERS OF THE HOST SOCIETY AND RETURNEES
ProjectTitle: Building sustainable livelihoods for Syrian refugees, internally displaced persons, vulnerable members of the host society and returnees
LongDescription: Support of the development of a sustainable livelihood for returnees, internally displaced persons and vulnerable members of the host society through technical training in agricultural activities, as well as access to means of production in the northern Iraqi province of Ninewa. Capacities of local administrations in the field of sustainable agriculture will also be established.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - SUPPORTING HUMANITARIAN COORDINATION
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Supporting humanitarian coordination
LongDescription: In 2017, Germany contributed €5.48 million to support humanitarian coordination and advocacy efforts in Iraq, specifically through the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). This funding aimed to enhance the effectiveness of humanitarian response by strengthening coordination mechanisms among various actors and ensuring that aid reached those most in need. The support facilitated improved planning, resource allocation, and information sharing, thereby optimizing the overall humanitarian response in the country .

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING THE RESILIENCE BY CONSTRUCTION OF LIFE BASES AND IMPROVED SANITARY AND HYGIENE CARE IN THE PROVINCE OF AL-ANBAR
ProjectTitle: Strengthening the resilience by construction of life bases and improved sanitary and hygiene care in the province of al-Anbar
LongDescription: The aim of the project is by improved sanitary and hygiene care to contribute the construction of life bases and to the revival of the local markets to the strengthening of the resilience of the population affected by the conflict in the province of Al-Anbar.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: SUSTAINABLE REINTEGRATION OF INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS THROUGH LIVELIHOOD CAPACITY BUILDING AND RECONSTRUCTION IN THE AL ANBAR GOVERNORATE
ProjectTitle: Sustainable reintegration of internally displaced persons through livelihood capacity building and reconstruction in the Al Anbar Governorate
LongDescription: In 2018, Germany supported the sustainable reintegration of internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Al Anbar Governorate, Iraq, through a comprehensive development initiative. Implemented by Arbeiter-Samariter-Bund (ASB) with funding from the German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ), the project focused on rebuilding livelihoods and housing for returnees and host communities. Key activities included restoring irrigation systems, rehabilitating wells, and introducing resource-efficient farming techniques to enhance agricultural productivity. Additionally, the project provided training in modern irrigation methods and supported smallholder farmers with livestock and agricultural inputs, benefiting over 64,000 families. These efforts aimed to improve food security, create income opportunities, and strengthen the resilience of communities affected by conflict and displacement
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: IMPROVEMENT OF THE HEALTH CARE SYSTEM IN UNDERSERVED REGIONS OF ANBAR GOVERNORATE, IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Improvement of the health care system in underserved regions of Anbar Governorate, Iraq
LongDescription: The measures to strengthen the health system in line with Iraq's National Health Policy are primarily aimed at improving the state of health, especially of the most vulnerable population groups, creating more resilient health structures and also contributing to stabilising the livelihoods in underserved regions of Anbar Province.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: BRITISH COUNCIL IRAQ
ProjectTitle: British Council Iraq
LongDescription: In 2016, the British Council's initiatives in Iraq focused on enhancing cultural and educational development by building skills, fostering connections with the UK, and promoting social cohesion. A notable project was the TAHAWER programme, which aimed to create safe spaces for young people from diverse backgrounds to engage in thoughtful debate and discussion. This initiative encouraged respect and tolerance, promoted social cohesion, and fostered a positive sense of Iraqi identity. The programme was implemented in various cities across Iraq, including Erbil, Basrah, and Najaf, and continued until October 2020

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY WASH AND NFI SUPPORT IN SYRIA - ASSISTANCE AND RECOVERY
ProjectTitle: Emergency WASH and NFI support in Syria - Assistance and Recovery
LongDescription: To alleviate suffering to vulnerable populations by making essential repairs to water supply and sanitation infrastructure and provide non food items in conflict affected areas in northeastern Syria
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: ENHANCE CIVILIAN SECURITY IN AREAS SECURED FROM ISLAMIC STATE - ERW THREATS AND CONTAMINATION
ProjectTitle: Enhance Civilian Security in Areas Secured from Islamic State - ERW Threats and Contamination
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: In 2015, the Mines Advisory Group (MAG), with support from the U.S. Department of State, initiated a project to enhance civilian security in areas of Iraq liberated from the Islamic State by addressing threats posed by explosive remnants of war (ERW). The project focused on surveying and clearing ERW to facilitate the safe return of displaced populations and the restoration of essential services. One of the key locations for this project was the town of Sinjar in the Nineveh Governorate, which had experienced significant conflict and contamination.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: ESTABLISHING GENDER PEDAGOGICAL AND THERAPEUTIC EDUCATIONAL STRUCTURES FOR THE (RE)INTEGRATION OF DISPLACED CHILDREN AND YOUTH
ProjectTitle: Establishing gender pedagogical and therapeutic educational structures for the (re)integration of displaced children and youth
PurposeName: Promotion of mental health and well-being
LongDescription: Qualified service structures for gender pedagogical and therapeutic offers for psychological stabilisation and school (re-)integration of 3000 children and adolescents have been established in Ramadi, Falluja, Kirkuk, Mosul.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: MITIGATING THE RESURGENCE OF ISIS IN ANBAR PROVINCE
ProjectTitle: Mitigating the Resurgence of ISIS in Anbar Province
LongDescription: In 2022, the U.S. government implemented a comprehensive initiative to mitigate the resurgence of ISIS in Iraq's Anbar Province. This effort encompassed joint operations between U.S. and Iraqi forces, including targeted airstrikes and ground raids in the Anbar Desert, resulting in the elimination of key ISIS leaders and the disruption of their operational capabilities . Additionally, the program provided training, equipment, and logistical support to Iraqi Security Forces (ISF) under the Counter-ISIS Train and Equip Fund (CTEF), enhancing their capacity to independently manage and counter ISIS threats . These combined efforts aimed to stabilize the region, prevent ISIS from re-establishing a foothold, and support the broader goal of regional security.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: REHABILITATION OF SOCIAL BASIC INFRASTRUCTURE THROUGH ACCESS TO WATER AND ELECTRICITY AS WELL AS SANITATION OF SCHOOLS AND BASIC HEALTH CARE SERVICES
ProjectTitle: Rehabilitation of social basic infrastructure through access to water and electricity as well as sanitation of schools and basic health care services
LongDescription: The project aimed to rehabilitate social basic infrastructure in the Zumar area of Dohuk Governorate, Iraq, focusing on improving access to clean water, electricity, and sanitation in schools and basic health care facilities. Key activities included upgrading water and sewage systems, connecting local communities to essential utility networks, and renovating dilapidated primary and secondary schools to create safer, healthier environments for education and healthcare.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING FOOD AND NUTRITION SECURITY AND RESILIENCE OF WOMEN AND VULNERABLE POPULATIONS OF IDPS, RETURNEES, REFUGEES AND HOST COMMUNITIES
ProjectTitle: Strengthening food and nutrition security and resilience of women and vulnerable populations of IDPs, returnees, refugees and host communities
LongDescription: The project focuses on strengthening food and nutrition security and building resilience among women and vulnerable groups, including internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, refugees, and host communities in Iraq. By supporting sustainable livelihoods, it promotes economic stability and peaceful coexistence within affected communities through targeted assistance such as agricultural support, nutrition programs, and social cohesion initiatives.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY GRANT AID FOR IDPS AND RETURNEES TO LIBERATED AREAS IN IRAQ (THROUGH UNHCR)
ProjectTitle: Emergency Grant Aid for IDPs and returnees to liberated areas in Iraq (through UNHCR)
LongDescription: Japan's Emergency Grant Aid in 2016 allocated $3 million to support internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees in newly liberated areas of Iraq, in collaboration with UNHCR and other partners. The assistance focused on providing essential services such as shelter, education, livelihood support, health services, and protection for vulnerable populations. This initiative aimed to facilitate the safe and sustainable return of displaced communities and contribute to the stabilization of the affected regions.

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY GRANT AID FOR IDPS AND RETURNEES TO LIBERATED AREAS IN IRAQ (THROUGH UNICEF)
ProjectTitle: Emergency Grant Aid for IDPs and returnees to liberated areas in Iraq (through UNICEF)
LongDescription: Japan's Emergency Grant Aid in 2016 allocated $10 million to support internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees in newly liberated areas of Iraq. Implemented through UNICEF, this assistance focused on providing essential services such as shelter, education, livelihood support, health services, and protection for vulnerable populations. The initiative aimed to facilitate the safe and sustainable return of displaced communities and contribute to the stabilization of the affected regions.

ShortDescription: REDUCING THE VULNERABILITY OF CONFLICT-AFFECTED YOUTH IN IRAQ THROUGH INCREASED LIVELIHOOD OUTCOMES, UTILIZING AN APPROACH THAT FOSTERS PSYCHOSOCIAL W
ProjectTitle: Reducing the Vulnerability of Conflict-Affected Youth in Iraq Through Increased Livelihood Outcomes, Utilizing An Approach That Fosters Psychosocial Wellbeing
LongDescription: In 2017, Mercy Corps launched a program in Iraq aimed at reducing the vulnerability of conflict-affected youth by enhancing livelihood opportunities and fostering psychosocial well-being. This initiative, funded by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, combined vocational training with psychosocial support to address the complex needs of young people impacted by conflict. The program operated in various locations, including Erbil and Sulaymaniyah governorates, providing participants with skills development, mentorship, and community engagement activities designed to promote resilience and economic self-sufficiency. By integrating mental health support with livelihood training, the program sought to empower youth to rebuild their lives and contribute positively to their communities.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: STRENGHENING WASH BASIC INFRASTRUCTURE, RESILIENCE AND LIVELIHOODS IN RETURN AREAS IN NINEWA, IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Strenghening WASH basic infrastructure, resilience and livelihoods in return areas in Ninewa, Iraq
LongDescription: The project aims to strengthen WASH (Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene) basic infrastructure and enhance the resilience and livelihoods of vulnerable host communities and returnees in conflict-affected areas of Ninewa Governorate, Iraq. Focusing on Talafar and Sinjar districts, the initiative supports sustainable reintegration by rehabilitating water supply systems, improving sanitation facilities, and promoting hygiene practices to improve living conditions and community resilience.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: CONSTRUCTION AND REMOVAL OF CIVIL STRUCTURES AND EMERGENCY SERVICES STRUCTURES UNDER INCLUSION OF CIVIL-SOCIAL ACTORS.
ProjectTitle: Construction and removal of civil structures and emergency services structures under inclusion of civil-social actors.
LongDescription: In Iraq under the management of both responsible state institutions 'Joint Coordination and Monitoring Center' and 'Joint Crisis Coordination Centre' emergency services structures are set up which form the basis for a regional network between players of the civil defence and contribute in the long term a contribution to the social stabilisation of the whole country and the region.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: IRAQI COUNCIL OF REPRESENTATIVES AND CIVIL SOCIETY
ProjectTitle: Iraqi Council of Representatives and civil society
LongDescription: The contriution is for support to the Iraq Foundation's (IF) project to strengthen the Iraqi parliament's ability to respond effectively and respond to public needs. The project will be implemented by IF and and Global Partners Governance's (GPG) who will work with the Parliament( CoR) and their committees to improve policy, quality and working methods. The project will also work with civil society to increase their participation and influence on political processes. One of four results within the initiative is to increase women's opportunities to participate in political processes and gender equality will also be integrated into the other results and activities within the project. This is a project that is partly a continuation of the work Global Partners Governance has conducted in Iraq with CoR since 2008, however not with Swedish funding. This initiative is also based on experience gained from GPG's efforts to increase the resilience of the political system, which has been done by strengthening Parliament as a forum for conflict resolution and political negotiations as well as cross-sectoral agreements.

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: UNHCR HIGH COMM. REFUGEES EMERGENCY AID PROGRAMME
ProjectTitle: UNHCR High Comm. Refugees Emergency Aid Programme
LongDescription: In 2014, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) allocated CHF 3 million to support the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in responding to the humanitarian crisis in Iraq. This funding aimed to provide immediate protection and assistance to refugees and internally displaced persons (IDPs) affected by the ongoing conflict. The SDC's contribution was part of a broader international effort to address the needs of approximately 2 million displaced individuals in Iraq. The support focused on enhancing protection mechanisms, improving access to civil documentation, and providing essential services to vulnerable populations.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: INCREASE CIVILIAN SECURITY IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Increase Civilian Security in Iraq
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: In 2020, the Danish Refugee Council (DRC) implemented the "Increase Civilian Security in Iraq" project, focusing on enhancing the safety and resilience of conflict-affected populations. The initiative encompassed activities such as protection services, shelter rehabilitation, and community-based interventions aimed at mitigating security risks and supporting recovery efforts. DRC's operations spanned multiple governorates, including Diyala, Salah al-Din, and Anbar, targeting areas with significant needs for humanitarian assistance and infrastructure rehabilitation.

ShortDescription: THIRD TRANCHE - SYRIA REGIONAL REFUGEE AND RESILIENCE PLAN (3RP) - IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Third Tranche - Syria Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP) - Iraq
LongDescription: The "Third Tranche - Syria Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP) - Iraq" in 2015, implemented by UNICEF and funded by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, aimed to support Syrian refugees and vulnerable host communities in Iraq. The initiative focused on enhancing access to education, health services, water and sanitation (WASH), and child protection. Activities included the provision of formal and non-formal education, immunization campaigns, WASH infrastructure improvements, and psychosocial support services. The program targeted regions with high concentrations of Syrian refugees, particularly in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq, encompassing governorates such as Erbil, Duhok, and Sulaymaniyah.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - PROTECTION ASSISTANCE TO VULNERABLE POPULATIONS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Protection assistance to vulnerable populations in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2018, humanitarian organizations in Iraq implemented protection assistance programs aimed at supporting vulnerable populations, including internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities affected by conflict. These initiatives focused on providing essential services such as legal aid, psychosocial support, and community-based protection activities to enhance safety and resilience. Efforts were concentrated in areas with significant displacement and returnee populations, particularly in the Nineveh Governorate, where the city of Mosul had experienced extensive conflict-related damage.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE AND SUPPORT
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Humanitarian Assistance and Support
LongDescription: The project provided humanitarian assistance and support to conflict-affected populations in Iraq in 2015. It aimed to address urgent needs by delivering essential aid such as food, shelter, medical care, and protection services to displaced persons and vulnerable communities suffering from the impacts of ongoing conflict. The initiative helped alleviate immediate suffering and contributed to stabilizing living conditions amidst widespread displacement and insecurity.

ShortDescription: OXFAM: PROMOTING GENDER EQUALITY, RESILIENCE AND SOCIAL COHESION IRAQ 2020-2022
ProjectTitle: Oxfam: Promoting Gender Equality, Resilience and Social Cohesion Iraq 2020-2022
LongDescription: The Oxfam project Promoting Gender Equality, Resilience and Social Cohesion in Iraq is implemented in the Ninewa region in Iraq during 2020-2022. It contributes to the two goals of the Swedish strategy for development cooperation with Iraq 2017-2021, to contribute to peaceful and inclusive societies and gender equality. As a large part of the population was forced to flee due to the violent conflicts in Iraq, there is now a big need to create livelihood opportunities for people returning and for people living in poverty. Oxfam's proposal with the aim to strengthen women's economic empowerment and resilience among the population living in conflict affected areas through increased access to safe and sustainable livelihood within the agricultural sector, is well-aligned with the goals in the Iraq strategy. With a specific focus on women, the project aims to contribute to women's economic participation and empowerment within the frames of the strategy.  The project aims to also contribute to social cohesion and thus to contribute to the decrease of tensions in Ninewa, a region of Iraq that has been much affected by contracted conflicts, and which has a population of diverse ethnic and religious backgrounds, as well as different experiences from displacement and return. Therefore it is very important to contribute to increased opportunities for a safe and sustainable return. The contribution contributes to this through the creation of livelihood opportunities within the agricultural sector, with good potential to generate income for people living in poverty, especially for women and youth, but also for others assessed to be living in vulnerability.

ShortDescription: ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS OF ODA PROJECTS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Administrative costs of ODA projects in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2019, the UK government allocated Official Development Assistance (ODA) funds to Iraq to support various development initiatives. While the specific administrative costs for these projects are not detailed in the available sources, it's important to note that administrative expenses are a standard component of ODA funding. These costs typically cover activities such as project management, monitoring and evaluation, and compliance with international standards. The exact allocation for administrative expenses within the Iraq-specific ODA projects would be detailed in individual project reports or financial statements provided by the implementing agencies.
Name_of_Donor: United Kingdom, Conflict stability and security fund

ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING COMMUNITY POLICING IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Strengthening Community Policing in Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: Enhance the basic operating capacities and infrastructure of Community Policing in Iraq, strengthening the capacity of community and civil society to engage in security related dialogue

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE FOR REFUGEES
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Emergency assistance for refugees
LongDescription: The project delivered emergency humanitarian assistance to refugees affected by conflict in Iraq in 2016. It focused on providing life-saving aid such as food, shelter, medical support, and protection services to displaced populations fleeing violence. This initiative helped alleviate the immediate needs of refugees, improving their safety and living conditions during critical periods of displacement.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: IMPROVEMENT OF THE MOTHER'S CHILD'S HEALTH IN RETURN AREAS NORTHERN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Improvement of the mother's child's health in return areas Northern Iraq
LongDescription: The aim of the plan is the improvement of the mother's child's health in the return areas of Northern Iraq, reconstruction and equipment are planned by health centres to allow to pregnant women and women in the reproductive old access to health services. In addition, midwives and local NGOs are strengthened, while trainings are carried out
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: REHABILITATION MORE ESSENTIALLY OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE FACILITIES WASH IN DOHUK, ERBIL AND NINEWA
ProjectTitle: Rehabilitation more essentially of public and private facilities WASH in Dohuk, Erbil and Ninewa
LongDescription: The project makes a contribution to the Reintegration of repatriates by the improvement of the living conditions / health terms and base infrastructure. The DWHH works together with the local governments of Dohuk and Ninewa, in particular with the suitable offices. The project makes a contribution to the reduction of avoidable illnesses which stand in connection with public health, as well as for the improvement of the living conditions. The people have an improved access to water supply systems.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: 2018 SYRIA 3RP
ProjectTitle: 2018 Syria 3RP
LongDescription: The 2018 Syria Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP) in Iraq, implemented by UNICEF and funded by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, aimed to support Syrian refugees and vulnerable host communities. The initiative focused on enhancing access to education, health services, water and sanitation (WASH), and child protection. Activities included the provision of formal and non-formal education, immunization campaigns, WASH infrastructure improvements, and psychosocial support services. The program targeted regions with high concentrations of Syrian refugees, particularly in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq, encompassing governorates such as Erbil, Duhok, and Sulaymaniyah.

ShortDescription: SYRIA CRISIS ??PROTECTING REFUGEES AND DISPLACED PEOPLE - UNHCR EMERGENCY APPEAL 2013 / CRISE EN SYRIE-PROT횋GER LES REFUGI횋S ET LES PERSONNES D횋PLAC횋E
ProjectTitle: Syria Crisis Protecting Refugees and Displaced People - UNHCR Emergency Appeal 2013
LongDescription: September 2013 - The humanitarian situation in Syria has rapidly deteriorated over the past year as a result of the civil war in the country. The United Nations estimates that 100,000 people have been killed, and hundreds of thousands more wounded, due to the violence. Within Syria, some 6.8 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, 4.25 million of whom are internally displaced. In addition, more than 2 million Syrian refugees are living in host countries in the region. By the end of 2013, the United Nations estimates that 10 million people in Syria will need humanitarian assistance and a further 3.55 million refugees from Syria will have fled to host countries, whose resources are increasingly overstretched by the influx of people needing assistance. With the support of DFATD and other donors, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) is protecting and helping an estimated 3 million refugees in Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey, as well as internally displaced Syrians, who had to leave their homes because of the conflict. Project activities include: registering refugees to ensure access to protection and assistance, providing emergency shelter and essential non-food items, such as baby kits, mattresses and bedding: providing supplies such as blankets and fuel vouchers to get through the winter, and, increasing access to safe water and sanitation facilities. UNHCR is also: providing health assistance, including psychosocial support and medical services, for refugees with specific needs, including children, supporting basic education, child protection, educational and recreational activities, conducting mine risk awareness campaigns to protect children, and, establishing safe spaces for survivors of sexual and gender-based violence, especially women and girls, within the refugee and host communities.

ShortDescription: COVERAGE OF BASIC NEEDS IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Coverage of basic needs Iraq
LongDescription: The 2018 German-funded project aimed to meet the basic needs of returnees, refugees, internally displaced persons (IDPs), and host communities in Iraq through cash assistance. Implemented by the German Red Cross, the initiative provided unconditional cash transfers to vulnerable families, enabling them to cover essential expenses such as food, shelter, and healthcare. This support was crucial for individuals and families striving to rebuild their lives after displacement, offering them the flexibility to address their most pressing needs and contributing to their resilience and self-reliance.

ShortDescription: HEALTH SERVICES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Health services in Iraq
LongDescription: Increased access to integrated qualitative health services for vulnera-ble populations in conflict affected areas in the target governorates in Iraq

ShortDescription: UNICEF 2018 HUMANITARIAN ACTION FOR CHILDREN APPEAL FOR IRAQ
ProjectTitle: UNICEF 2018 Humanitarian Action for Children Appeal for Iraq
LongDescription: In 2018, UNICEF's Humanitarian Action for Children (HAC) Appeal for Iraq, supported by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, aimed to assist 2.24 million people, including 1.2 million children, affected by conflict and displacement. The program focused on providing access to safe water, sanitation, education, health services, and child protection. Key interventions included the Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) reaching over 2.3 million people with life-saving supplies, rehabilitation of WASH facilities in schools, and psychosocial support for displaced children. Efforts were concentrated in areas with high displacement, such as Ninewa Governorate, where camps like Hajj Ali and Qayyarah served as critical hubs for aid delivery.

ShortDescription: CONSERVATION CROPPING IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Conservation Cropping in Iraq
LongDescription: The Conservation Cropping In Iraq 2012 initiative aims to promote the adoption of conservation cropping practices by Iraqi farmers and thereby increase crop productivity, profitability and sustainability in the dry lands of northern Iraq. Key outcomes include: wide adoption of conservation cropping systems, active research and development program focussing on development, monitoring and continuous adaption of conservation cropping techniques, and improved technical capacity of Iraqi scientists to develop conservation techniques in agriculture, as well as improved ability of agricultural agencies to plan, implement and monitor research and development programs. The total value of this initiative is $10.0 million over 4 years, starting 2011-12.

ShortDescription: INTEGRATED PROTECTION AND EDUCATION ASSISTANCE TO CONFLICT-AFFECTED PERSONS IN HARD-TO-REACH AREAS OF IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Integrated Protection and Education Assistance to Conflict-Affected Persons in Hard-To-Reach Areas of Iraq
LongDescription: In 2020, Terre des Hommes, with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented the "Integrated Protection and Education Assistance to Conflict-Affected Persons in Hard-To-Reach Areas of Iraq" project. This initiative aimed to support children and families in regions severely impacted by conflict, focusing on areas with limited access to essential services. The program provided temporary learning spaces, psychosocial support, and child protection services to enhance the well-being and resilience of vulnerable populations. Key activities included the establishment of educational facilities and the delivery of comprehensive protection services in underserved communities.

ShortDescription: OFFICE OF WEAPONS REMOVAL AND ABATEMENT - 20.PMWRA.IRAQ.HMA.HALO
ProjectTitle: Office of Weapons Removal and Abatement - 20.PMWRA.Iraq.HMA.HALO
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: In 2020, the U.S. Department of State's Office of Weapons Removal and Abatement awarded $2,658,500 to The HALO Trust under the project code 20.PMWRA.Iraq.HMA.HALO. This initiative aimed to enhance civilian safety in Iraq by clearing landmines and unexploded ordnance (UXO) in areas heavily affected by past conflicts, particularly those impacted by ISIS occupation. The HALO Trust focused its operations in regions such as Baiji and Tikrit, conducting thorough surveys and clearance activities to facilitate the safe return of displaced populations and the restoration of essential services. Their efforts included not only the physical removal of explosive hazards but also community education programs to raise awareness about the dangers of UXO.

ShortDescription: DRC EDUCATION (VET) FOR FEMALE-HEADED HOUSEHOLDS
ProjectTitle: DRC Education (VET) for Female-Headed Households
LongDescription: Basic Services for the Vulnerable aims to support Iraq's transition to a stable, economically prosperous nation by ensuring poor and marginalised Iraqis have access to basic services such as shelter and education. Planned activities include working with the: Danish Refugee Council to improve access to livelihood opportunities for female headed households through the provision of vocational education and training, International Rescue Committee (IRC) to provide safe and healing learning for marginalized and conflict-affected children and youth through increasing access to quality education opportunities by supporting 31 basic and accelerated learning schools, and the United Nations High Commission for Refugees to provide protection and assistance to internally displaced persons by providing shelter to 409,000 people living in destitute conditions. The total value of this initiative is $13.5 million over four years, starting 2011-12.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - RAPID RESPONSE MECHANISM - MERCY CORPS 2015 / CRISE EN IRAQ - M횋CANISME DE R횋PONSE RAPIDE - MERCY CORPS 2015
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Rapid Response Mechanism - Mercy Corps 2015
LongDescription: March 2015 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 2.4 million people from their homes. An estimated 5.2 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. As fighting and human rights violations persist and international efforts remain to free territory controlled by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), the situation is expected to deteriorate and to cause additional displacement.   With DFATD's support, Mercy Corps is helping to protect and reduce the vulnerability of internally displaced people affected by the civil unrest in Iraq. In consortium with UN agencies and international non-governmental organizations, Mercy Corps will provide emergency cash assistance as required to newly displaced persons and newly liberated areas across all of Iraq. Project activities include: (1) providing an initial emergency cash grant to newly displaced families, and (2) providing up to three more emergency cash grants over a period of three months to only the most vulnerable newly displaced families.

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: ADDITIONAL ALLOCATION OF SDC FUNDING TO ICRC OPERATIONS IN 2015: RESPONSE TO SYRIA AND IRAQ CRISES
ProjectTitle: Additional Allocation of SDC Funding to ICRC Operations in 2015: Response to Syria and Iraq Crises
LongDescription: In line with the Good Humanitarian Donorship (GHD) principles, Switzerland recognizes the necessity of predictable and flexible funding to respond to changing needs in humanitarian crises. SDC funding to ICRC operations allows the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) to respond proactively and to provide immediate protection and assistance for people affected by armed conflict and other situations of violence.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS OF ODA PROJECTS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Administrative Costs of ODA Projects in Iraq
LongDescription: Managing and coordinating aid projects in Iraq requires dedicated resources beyond direct service delivery. In 2019, the UK allocated funds specifically for the administrative side of Official Development Assistance (ODA) programs. This included expenses related to organizing activities, overseeing implementation, and ensuring that projects met accountability and quality standards. These behind-the-scenes efforts are crucial for turning funding into effective, on-the-ground impact, even if they often remain less visible than the frontline work.
Name_of_Donor: United Kingdom, Conflict stability and security fund

ShortDescription: OFFICE OF WEAPONS REMOVAL AND ABATEMENT - ERW CLEARANCE IN IRAQI KURDISTAN
ProjectTitle: Office of Weapons Removal and Abatement - ERW Clearance in Iraqi Kurdistan
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: U.S. Department of State: Office of Weapons Removal and Abatement. New Award obligating $6,074,236 incrementally with $3,000,000 Iraq bilateral funds. PoP of 24 months. See SOO and terms and conditions below.

ShortDescription: CONTRIBUTION TO 2020 UNICEF SYRIA 3RP AND HUMANITARIAN ACTION FOR CHILDREN APPEAL FOR SYRIANS AND IRAQIS
ProjectTitle: Contribution to 2020 UNICEF Syria 3RP and Humanitarian Action for Children Appeal for Syrians and Iraqis
LongDescription: In 2020, UNICEF, with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented the Syria Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP) and Humanitarian Action for Children (HAC) Appeal in Iraq. The initiative aimed to support Syrian refugees and vulnerable Iraqi communities by providing essential services such as education, health care, water and sanitation (WASH), and child protection. Key activities included the provision of formal and non-formal education, immunization campaigns, WASH infrastructure improvements, and psychosocial support services. The program targeted regions with high concentrations of Syrian refugees, particularly in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq, encompassing governorates such as Erbil, Duhok, and Sulaymaniyah.

ShortDescription: ADDRESSING THE RETURN AND REINTEGRATION OF IRAQIS WITH PERCEIVED AFFILIATION TO ISLAMIC STATE OF IRAQ AND THE LEVANT (ISIL)
ProjectTitle: Addressing the Return and Reintegration of Iraqis with Perceived Affiliation to Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL)
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: Contribute to stability in Iraq and reduce the risk of renewed violence, by strengthening social cohesion, addressing the key drivers of violent extremism, and strengthening the capacity of target communities to address challenges related to the return and reintegration of Iraqis with perceived affiliation to ISIL.

ShortDescription: CASH PROGRAMMING FOR NFI SUPPORT, CHILD PROTECTION, AND SUPPORT FOR SURVIVORS OF GBV. - PROTECTION AND SOLUTIONS
ProjectTitle: Cash programming for NFI support, Child Protection, and Support for Survivors of GBV. - Protection and Solutions
LongDescription: In 2016, humanitarian organizations in Iraq implemented cash-based programming to provide non-food item (NFI) support, child protection services, and assistance for survivors of gender-based violence (GBV). These initiatives aimed to address the immediate needs of vulnerable populations affected by conflict and displacement. Cash assistance was utilized to empower individuals, particularly women and children, by enabling them to access essential goods and services, thereby reducing their exposure to protection risks. The programs were integrated with case management and psychosocial support to ensure a comprehensive response to the complex challenges faced by affected communities. While specific project sites varied, significant activities were conducted in areas with high concentrations of internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees, including the Ninewa Governorate.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: ENSURE SUSTAINABLE ACCESS TO QUALITY ESSENTIAL VACCINATION, NUTRITION, NEONATAL HEALTH CARE SERVICES TO VULNERABLE CHILDREN AND WOMEN
ProjectTitle: Ensure Sustainable Access to Quality Essential Vaccination, Nutrition, Neonatal Health Care Services to Vulnerable Children and Women
LongDescription: Japan's 2020 initiative, "Ensure Sustainable Access to Quality Essential Vaccination, Nutrition, Neonatal Health Care Services to Vulnerable Children and Women," provided a $3 million contribution to UNICEF. The project aimed to support over 1 million children under five years old, as well as refugees and pregnant women, by enhancing access to immunization, nutrition, and maternal and newborn health services in displacement camps and conflict-affected governorates including Dohuk, Erbil, Sulaymaniyah, Kirkuk, Ninewa, Salahaddin, and Anbar. The assistance included the provision of vaccines, nutritional support, and the establishment of cold chain storage at approximately 100 health centers to ensure proper vaccine storage and distribution.

ShortDescription: SUPPORTING THE SECURITY DEVELOPMNET NEXUS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Supporting the Security Developmnet Nexus in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2019, Japan and UNDP strengthened their partnership to advance the "Security-Development Nexus" in Iraq, aiming to integrate security and development efforts for sustainable peace and stability. This collaboration focused on enhancing governance, justice, and security sectors, with an emphasis on community resilience and the reintegration of former combatants. A notable initiative under this partnership was the Community Security Integration Pilot (CSIP) launched in Al-Qurna, Basra province. The CSIP provided vocational training, psychosocial support, and small business grants to former volunteer fighters, facilitating their transition into civilian life and promoting social cohesion . Additionally, the partnership supported the establishment of a Monitoring Committee to oversee and accelerate the implementation of socio-economic infrastructure projects, ensuring accountability and efficiency in delivering public services .

ShortDescription: IMPROVING THE POLITICAL PROCESS
ProjectTitle: Improving the Political Process
LongDescription: In 2023, the UK's development efforts in Iraq focused on enhancing the political process, aiming to strengthen democratic institutions and promote inclusive governance. Key initiatives included supporting civil society organizations to increase civic engagement, particularly among women and youth, and providing technical assistance to improve electoral processes and public sector accountability .
Name_of_Donor: United Kingdom, Conflict stability and security fund

ShortDescription: ERW AND IED CLEARANCE IN RAMADI / L'ENL횊VEMENT DES EEI ET DES REG ? RAMADI
ProjectTitle: ERW and IED Clearance in Ramadi
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: The expected outcomes for this project include: (1) improved implementation of stability tasks by stabilization actors in Ramadi and other newly liberated areas, (2) improved conduct of explosive ordnance disposal operations by Iraqi institutions in Ramadi and other newly liberated areas.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS- IMPROVING ACCESS TO HEALTH AND LIVELIHOODS FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PEOPLE- 2016 / LA CRISE EN IRAK - ACC횊S AM횋LIORER AUX SERVICES DE SAN
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis- Improving Access to Health and Livelihoods for Internally Displaced People- 2016
LongDescription: March 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 3.2 million people from their homes. An estimated 10 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. The capacity of the Government to respond to the basic needs of its citizens has been overwhelmed. In 2016, more people will be displaced by the conflict, while many will remain displaced in camps and host communities. However, there will also be growing numbers of people returning to areas no longer under the control of ISIL who will also need assistance to help restart their lives.   With GAC's support, the project is building the resilience of IDPs, remainees and returnees, to enable them to cope with the impact of the crisis through social awareness and improved access to income. The project will: (1) provide primary, reproductive, maternal and child health care to up to 60,720 displaced people in camps, and (2) provide temporary employment activities and emergency livelihood assets to conflict-affected people returning to areas of origin.

ShortDescription: ENHANCING THE PROTECTIVE ENVIRONMENT FOR DISPLACEMENT-AFFECTED COMMUNITIES IN IRAQ THROUGH RESPONDING TO EMERGENCY NEEDS AND ENABLING DURABLE SOLUTION
ProjectTitle: Enhancing the Protective Environment for Displacement-Affected Communities in Iraq Through Responding to Emergency Needs and Enabling Durable Solutions
LongDescription: The Danish Refugee Council (DRC), with funding from the United States Population Migration and Refugee Assistance under Appropriation 1143, implemented a project titled "Enhancing the Protective Environment for Displacement-Affected Communities in Iraq Through Responding to Emergency Needs and Enabling Durable Solutions." This initiative aimed to support internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities across seven governorates in Iraq by providing critical basic needs and developing sustainable long-term solutions. The project focused on economic recovery, protection, shelter, settlements, water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH), camp coordination and management, and humanitarian disarmament and peacebuilding. DRC's efforts were aligned with the strategic priorities of the Iraq Humanitarian Response Plan, emphasizing the importance of a protective environment to enable people to live a life of dignity where their rights are respected

ShortDescription: DELIVERY OF COMMUNITY-BASED SERVICES AND REFERRALS TO PROMOTE WELL-BEING AND ENHANCE PROTECTION AMONG INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS AND OTHER POPULATIO
ProjectTitle: Delivery of Community-Based Services and Referrals to Promote Well-Being and Enhance Protection Among Internally Displaced Persons and Other Populations of Concern in Iraq
LongDescription: International Medical Corps (IMC), supported by the United States Population Migration and Refugee Assistance under Appropriation 1143, implemented a project in 2019 titled "Delivery of Community-Based Services and Referrals to Promote Well-Being and Enhance Protection Among Internally Displaced Persons and Other Populations of Concern in Iraq." This initiative aimed to provide integrated mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS) services, including mental health case management, community outreach, and specialized consultations at both community and clinical levels. IMC also focused on building the capacity of frontline service providers and strengthening coordination among different protection sectors to enhance child protection and gender-based violence (GBV) response services. The project prioritized the reactivation of psychosocial units within primary healthcare centers and the establishment of mental health service user associations, contributing to the development and implementation of Iraq's national MHPSS strategy

ShortDescription: 2021 DRC Y1  ENHANCING THE PROTECTI[AWARDS-  COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS]
ProjectTitle: 2021 DRC Y1  Enhancing the Protecti[Awards-  Cooperative Agreements]
LongDescription: The Danish Refugee Council (DRC) implemented the 2021 "Enhancing the Protective Environment for Internally Displaced Persons and Returnees" project in Iraq to strengthen protection services and facilitate durable solutions for displacement-affected populations. This initiative focused on providing protection services and advancing durable solutions for internally displaced persons and returnees. The project was carried out in various locations across Iraq, including Ninewa, Anbar, Diyala, Kirkuk, and Salah al-Din governorates. However, the exact coordinates of the project sites are not publicly disclosed due to security and privacy concern

ShortDescription: EXPANDING LEARNING AND ENHANCING VOICES FOR ACCESS TO EDUCATION (ELEVATE) FOR RETURNEES AND INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS IN NEWLY RETAKEN AND CRISIS A
ProjectTitle: Expanding Learning and Enhancing Voices for Access to Education (Elevate) for Returnees and Internally Displaced Persons in Newly Retaken and Crisis Affected Areas in Iraq
LongDescription: Mercy Corps' 2019 "Expanding Learning and Enhancing Voices for Access to Education (ELEVATE)" project aimed to improve educational access for returnees and internally displaced persons (IDPs) in newly retaken and crisis-affected areas of Iraq. Funded by the U.S. Population Migration and Refugee Assistance under Appropriation 1143, the initiative focused on rebuilding educational infrastructure, providing learning materials, and supporting community-based education programs to address the educational needs of vulnerable populations.

ShortDescription: PROVISION OF INFORMATION, COUNSELLING AND LEGAL ASSISTANCE (ICLA) AND GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE (GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE) SUPPORT PROGRAMMING TO INTERNALLY
ProjectTitle: Provision of Information, Counselling and Legal Assistance (Icla) and Gender-Based Violence (Gender-Based Violence) Support Programming to Internally Displaced Persons in Iraq
LongDescription: The Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) implemented a 2017 project in Iraq providing Information, Counselling and Legal Assistance (ICLA) and Gender-Based Violence (GBV) support to internally displaced persons. The initiative focused on legal assistance for housing, land, and property rights, and civil documentation, while also offering GBV prevention and response services, including psychosocial support and awareness campaigns. Activities were conducted across multiple governorates, including Erbil, Kirkuk, and Ninewa.

ShortDescription: NRC PROPOSES TO CONTINUE ASSISTANCE IN SHELTER AND GBV SUPPORT FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES IN ERBIL GOVERNORATE.
ProjectTitle: Nrc Proposes to Continue Assistance in Shelter and Gbv Support for Syrian Refugees in Erbil Governorate.
LongDescription: In 2016, the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) continued its support for Syrian refugees in Erbil Governorate, Iraq, focusing on shelter assistance and gender-based violence (GBV) prevention and response. The project provided safe and dignified shelter solutions while establishing safe spaces offering psychosocial support, legal aid, and awareness-raising activities to address GBV. These services were implemented in both camp and urban settings to reach vulnerable populations.

ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING THE PROTECTIVE ENVIRONMENT FOR AFFECTED CHILDREN, FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES THROUGH INCREASED ACCESS TO QUALITY EDUCATION AND CHILD PROT
ProjectTitle: Strengthening the Protective Environment for Affected Children, Families and Communities Through Increased Access to Quality Education and Child Protection Services
LongDescription: Save the Children implemented a project titled "Strengthening the Protective Environment for Affected Children, Families and Communities Through Increased Access to Quality Education and Child Protection Services" in Iraq from September 2018 to August 2019. Funded by the U.S. Population Migration and Refugee Assistance under Appropriation 1143, the initiative focused on early childhood care and development (ECCD) and child protection services for conflict-affected children. The project aimed to increase access to quality ECCD services for 210 children in Sinuni district (Ninewa), Domiz 2 and Gawilan refugee camps (Dohuk), and Khanaqin district (Diyala)

ShortDescription: 2020 DRC IRAQ LIVELIHOODS   Y2 OF 2[AWARDS-  COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS]
ProjectTitle: 2020 DRC Iraq Livelihoods   Y2 of 2[Awards-  Cooperative Agreements]
LongDescription: Promoting self-reliance and improving access to livelihoods opportunities for displacement-affected Iraqi and Syrian households in Salah al-Din, Diyala, Erbil, and Dohuk Governorates, Iraq

ShortDescription: NRC PROPOSES TO ASSIST IRAQI INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS IN SECURING REGISTRATION/CIVIL DOCUMENTATION, HOUSING/LAND/PROPERTY RIGHTS, AND ACCESS TO GB
ProjectTitle: Nrc Proposes to Assist Iraqi Internally Displaced Persons in Securing Registration/Civil Documentation, Housing/Land/Property Rights, and Access to Gb
LongDescription: In 2016, the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) implemented a project in Iraq aimed at assisting internally displaced persons (IDPs) in securing registration and civil documentation, housing, land, and property rights, as well as providing access to gender-based violence (GBV) support services. This initiative focused on legal assistance for housing, land, and property rights, and civil documentation, while also offering GBV prevention and response services, including psychosocial support and awareness campaigns. Activities were conducted across multiple governorates, including Erbil, Kirkuk, and Ninewa.

ShortDescription: INTEGRATED CLEARANCE OF CONVENTIONAL WEAPONS IN NORTHERN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Integrated Clearance of Conventional Weapons in Northern Iraq
LongDescription: In 2015, the Mines Advisory Group (MAG), with support from the U.S. Department of State, conducted extensive clearance operations in northern Iraq to mitigate the dangers posed by landmines and unexploded ordnance (UXO). These efforts focused on areas heavily affected by past conflicts, particularly in the Ninewa Governorate, facilitating the safe return of displaced populations and the restoration of essential services. MAG's operations included manual clearance, mechanical demining, and risk education to ensure comprehensive community safety

ShortDescription: ADVANCING THE FUTURE OF IRAQ'S DISPLACED YOUTH II (AFIDY II)
ProjectTitle: Advancing the Future of Iraq's Displaced Youth II (AFIDY II)
LongDescription: The Advancing the Future of Iraq's Displaced Youth II (AFIDY II) project, implemented by Mercy Corps with funding from the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, aimed to support displaced youth in Iraq. The project focused on providing educational and psychosocial support to internally displaced persons (IDPs), particularly in areas affected by conflict and displacement. One of the key locations for this initiative was the Debaga IDP camp in the Erbil Governorate, where Mercy Corps delivered water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services to approximately 7,500 residents.

ShortDescription: MASARAT  INTEGRATED LIVELIHOODS AND[AWARDS-  COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS]
ProjectTitle: MASARAT  Integrated Livelihoods and[Awards-  Cooperative Agreements]
LongDescription: Vulnerable Iraqi households (HHs) (IDPs, returnees and host community) achieve economic resilience and experience improved access to fundamental legal rights.

ShortDescription: CONTRIBUTION TO UNICEF NEEDS DEFINED IN THE SYRIA REGIONAL RESPONSE PLAN 5 ??IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Contribution To UNICEF Needs Defined in The Syria Regional Response Plan 5 Iraq
LongDescription: The 2013 U.S.-funded contribution to UNICEF under the Syria Regional Response Plan 5 in Iraq aimed to address the urgent needs of Syrian refugees, with a particular focus on children and vulnerable populations. UNICEF's interventions encompassed sectors such as education, water, sanitation, hygiene (WASH), health, and child protection. In Iraq, these efforts were concentrated in refugee camps located in the Kurdistan Region, including Domiz 1 and 2 in Dohuk, Darashakran, Kawergosk, Qushtapa, and Basirma in Erbil, and Arbat in Sulaymaniyah. These camps served as central hubs for delivering essential services to displaced Syrian families, facilitating access to education, healthcare, and safe living conditions.

ShortDescription: 2021 WHO IRAQ[FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE- VOLUNTARY CONTRIBUTIONS]
ProjectTitle: 2021 WHO Iraq[Financial Assistance- Voluntary Contributions]
LongDescription: The 2021 WHO Iraq project, funded through voluntary contributions, aimed to enhance the humanitarian health response for Syrian refugees residing in Iraq. This initiative focused on providing comprehensive primary healthcare services, including mental health support and disease surveillance, to refugees living in camps and host communities across the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. Key activities included strengthening health systems, improving access to essential medicines, and supporting local health authorities in Erbil, Dohuk, and Sulaymaniyah governorates. One of the central locations for these efforts was the Basirma refugee camp in Erbil Governorate, which served as a hub for delivering critical health services to the refugee population

ShortDescription: UNDP STABILIZATION PROJECT - LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND DECENTRALIZATION
ProjectTitle: UNDP Stabilization Project - Local Government and Decentralization
PurposeName: Decentralisation and support to subnational government
LongDescription: The 2015 UNDP Stabilization Project—Local Government and Decentralization, supported by USAID, aimed to facilitate the safe return of displaced Iraqis to areas liberated from ISIL by enhancing local governance and service delivery. Implemented through the Funding Facility for Stabilization (FFS), the project focused on rebuilding essential infrastructure, restoring public services, and strengthening the capacities of local authorities in nine governorates: Anbar, Basra, Duhok, Erbil, Missan, Nineveh, Salah al-Din, Sulaymaniyah, and Thi-Qar. Key initiatives included rehabilitating public facilities, promoting economic opportunities, and supporting decentralization reforms to empower local governments in managing resources and services effectively.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: PROMOTION OF A PROTECTION ENVIRONMENT THAT STRENGTHENS THE SELF-RELIANCE OF IRAQI IDPS, RETURNEES AND HOST COMMUNITY MEMBERS
ProjectTitle: Promotion of A Protection Environment That Strengthens the Self-Reliance of Iraqi Idps, Returnees and Host Community Members
LongDescription: The 2017 project titled "Promotion of a Protection Environment That Strengthens the Self-Reliance of Iraqi IDPs, Returnees, and Host Community Members," implemented by the Danish Refugee Council (DRC) with funding from the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, focused on enhancing the protection environment for vulnerable populations in Iraq. The initiative aimed to bolster self-reliance among internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities through protection services, legal assistance, and livelihood support.

ShortDescription: LOGISTICS SUPPORT AND RELIEF COMMODITIES - NFIS FOR DISPLACED CHILDREN, IRAQ.
ProjectTitle: Logistics Support and Relief Commodities - NFIs for displaced children, Iraq.
LongDescription: In 2016, the U.S. government, through USAID's Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA), provided substantial logistics support and relief commodities to assist displaced children in Iraq. This initiative involved the procurement and distribution of over 3 million non-food items (NFIs), including blankets, kerosene heaters, plastic sheeting, and towels, to vulnerable populations fleeing conflict zones. The Defense Logistics Agency (DLA) played a pivotal role in sourcing, packing, and transporting these critical supplies, collaborating with various federal agencies and non-governmental organizations to ensure timely delivery to affected areas. One notable distribution occurred at the Gazna informal IDP settlement in Erbil, where nearly 1,300 individuals received emergency relief commodities. These efforts were part of a broader humanitarian response aimed at mitigating the harsh conditions faced by displaced families, particularly children, during the ongoing crisis.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: VULNERABLE INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS IN IRAQ CAN SECURE REGISTRATION/CIVIL DOCUMENTATION (RCD), ENJOY THEIR HOUSING, LAND & PROPERTY (HLP) RIGHTS,
ProjectTitle: Vulnerable Internally Displaced Persons in Iraq Can Secure Registration/Civil Documentation (Rcd), Enjoy Their Housing, Land & Property (Hlp) Rights,
LongDescription: The 2015 project by the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), funded by the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, aimed to assist vulnerable internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq in securing civil documentation and asserting their housing, land, and property (HLP) rights.
