The initiative focused on providing legal assistance and counselling to displaced populations, particularly in areas heavily affected by conflict and displacement. One of the key locations for this project was the Domiz 1 Camp in Dohuk Governorate, which served as a central hub for delivering these critical services

ShortDescription: FUNDING TO UNITED NATIONS HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR REFUGEES (UNHCR) FOR PROCESSING OF CAMP HURRYIA RESIDENTS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Funding To United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) for Processing of Camp Hurryia Residents in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2013, the United States provided funding to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) to support the processing and resettlement of residents at Camp Hurriya (also known as Camp Liberty) in Iraq. This initiative aimed to facilitate the relocation of members of the People's Mujahedin of Iran (PMOI/MEK) from Iraq to third countries, ensuring their safety and compliance with international protection standards. UNHCR conducted individual assessments to determine the residents' protection needs and coordinated with various nations to secure resettlement opportunities. The program was part of a broader effort to resolve the longstanding situation of PMOI members in Iraq and to uphold humanitarian principles

ShortDescription: RETURNEES, INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS AND VULNERABLE IRAQIS ATTAIN LIVELIHOODS
ProjectTitle: Returnees, Internally Displaced Persons and Vulnerable Iraqis Attain Livelihoods
LongDescription: The 2013 initiative by ZOA International, funded by the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, aimed to enhance livelihoods for returnees, internally displaced persons (IDPs), and vulnerable Iraqis. The project focused on providing vocational training, agricultural support, and small business development to promote economic self-reliance among affected populations. While specific project sites are not detailed in the available sources, ZOA's operations in Iraq have encompassed various regions affected by conflict and displacement.

ShortDescription: SECOND CONTRIBUTION TOWARDS UNITED NATIONS HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR REFUGEES (UNHCR) S IRAQIS (OTHER) ANNUAL BUDGET ACTIVITIES
ProjectTitle: Second Contribution Towards United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) s Iraqis (Other) Annual Budget Activities
LongDescription: In 2013, the United States provided a second contribution to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) to support its annual budget activities in Iraq. This funding aimed to assist refugees, internally displaced persons (IDPs), and other vulnerable populations affected by ongoing conflicts and displacement within the country. UNHCR utilized these funds to deliver protection services, shelter, and essential humanitarian assistance across various regions in Iraq.

ShortDescription: THE PROJECT FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF HEALTH INFORMATION ON SYSTEM
ProjectTitle: The Project for the Development of Health Information on System
LongDescription: In 2013, KOICA partnered with the Iraqi Ministry of Health to implement the Project for the Development of a Health Information System aimed at modernizing Iraq’s healthcare data management. The initiative focused on establishing an e-government system to improve the collection, integration, and management of health information across the Ministry of Health. This project included building digital infrastructure, providing technical support, and enhancing the capacity of health officials through training programs. By improving health data accessibility and accuracy, the project aimed to support better decision-making, resource allocation, and overall healthcare service delivery throughout Iraq.

ShortDescription: PROVISION OF INTEGRATED HEALTH, MENTAL HEALTH, AND GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE SERVICES AND ACTIVITIES FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Provision of Integrated Health, Mental Health, and Gender-Based Violence Services and Activities for Syrian Refugees in Iraq
LongDescription: The 2019 initiative by International Medical Corps, funded through the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, aimed to provide comprehensive health, mental health, and gender-based violence (GBV) services to Syrian refugees in Iraq. The program focused on delivering integrated care through primary healthcare centers, mobile medical units, and community-based safe spaces. Services included mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), GBV prevention and response, and capacity-building for local health workers. One of the key locations for this project was the Domiz 1 Refugee Camp in Dohuk Governorate, which served as a central hub for these services.

ShortDescription: CATALYZE BLENDED CAPITAL INVESTMENT PLATFORM
ProjectTitle: Catalyze Blended Capital Investment Platform
LongDescription: This BAA is intended to address the challenge of how to most effectively increase private investment, in a developing country where private funds currently only flow to traditional asset classes (e.g. debt and equity in sovereign and investment grade borrowers) in order to address the gap between the amount of investment needed in the countries where USAID works, and the public sectors ability to finance these projects. Increasing private investment will require addressing problems with supply (those with funds to invest), demand (those seeking to receive finance), and intermediation (those who match supply with demand), as well as improving the overall enabling environment.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY GRANT AID FOR IRAQ TO IMPROVE HUMANITARIAN SITUATION AND ENHANCE STABILIZATION<THROUGH UNHCR>
ProjectTitle: Emergency Grant Aid for Iraq to improve humanitarian situation and enhance stabilization<through UNHCR>
LongDescription: In 2015, Japan provided emergency grant aid to Iraq to address the humanitarian crisis exacerbated by the conflict with ISIL. This assistance included support for food security, livelihood restoration, and the stabilization of newly liberated areas. The World Food Programme (WFP) played a key role in implementing food assistance programs for displaced families. Japan's contribution was part of a broader effort to enhance humanitarian conditions and facilitate the safe return of internally displaced persons (IDPs) to their homes.

ShortDescription: HEALTH, MENTAL HEALTH, AND GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE SUPPORT FOR CAMP AND NON-CAMP BASED SYRIAN REFUGEES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Health, Mental Health, and Gender-Based Violence Support for Camp and Non-Camp Based Syrian Refugees in Iraq
LongDescription: The 2018 initiative by International Medical Corps, funded through the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, aimed to provide integrated health, mental health, and gender-based violence (GBV) support to Syrian refugees residing both in camps and host communities across Iraq. The program delivered primary healthcare services, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), and GBV prevention and response activities through static clinics, mobile medical units, and community-based safe spaces. In 2018, International Medical Corps operated 25 women’s centers across six governorates, including Dohuk, Erbil, and Ninewa, offering a range of services and activities to support GBV survivors and vulnerable populations. One of the key locations for these services was the Domiz 1 Refugee Camp in Dohuk Governorate, which served as a central hub for delivering comprehensive care to the refugee population

ShortDescription: PROMOTION OF A PROTECTION ENVIRONMENT THAT STRENGTHENS IRAQI IDPS, RETURNEES AND HOST COMMUNITY MEMBERS' SELF-RELIANCE AND ACCESS TO BASIC SERVICES A
ProjectTitle: Promotion of A Protection Environment That Strengthens Iraqi Idps, Returnees and Host Community Members' Self-Reliance and Access to Basic Services and Targeted Assistance
LongDescription: The 2018 project by the Danish Refugee Council (DRC), funded through the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, aimed to strengthen the protection environment and enhance self-reliance among Iraqi internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host community members. The initiative focused on providing protection services, legal assistance, and support for access to basic services across various regions in Iraq.

ShortDescription: ELEVATE: EXPANDING LEARNING AND ENHANCING VOICES FOR ACCESS TO EDUCATION FOR RETURNEES AND INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS IN NEWLY RETAKEN AND CRISIS A
ProjectTitle: Elevate: Expanding Learning and Enhancing Voices for Access to Education for Returnees and Internally Displaced Persons in Newly Retaken and Crisis Affected Areas in Iraq
LongDescription: Mercy Corps' 2018 "Elevate" project, funded by the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, aimed to enhance educational access for returnees and internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq's newly retaken and crisis-affected areas. The initiative focused on providing quality education and psychosocial support to children and youth impacted by conflict, facilitating their reintegration into formal schooling systems

ShortDescription: 2018 INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR MIGRATION IRAQ HUMANITARIAN RESPNSE PLAN APPEAL FOR DISPLACEMENT TRACKING MATRIX (DTM) IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: 2018 International Organization for Migration Iraq Humanitarian Respnse Plan Appeal for Displacement Tracking Matrix (Dtm) in Iraq
LongDescription: The 2018 initiative by the International Organization for Migration (IOM), funded through the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, aimed to enhance the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) in Iraq. The DTM served as a critical tool for collecting and analyzing data on internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees, facilitating informed humanitarian responses and policy decisions.

ShortDescription: PROMOTING SELF-RELIANCE AND IMPROVING ACCESS TO LIVELIHOODS OPPORTUNITIES FOR DISPLACED IRAQI AND SYRIAN HOUSEHOLDS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Promoting Self-Reliance and Improving Access to Livelihoods Opportunities for Displaced Iraqi and Syrian Households in Iraq
LongDescription: The 2020 Danish Refugee Council (DRC) project, funded by the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, aimed to promote self-reliance and improve access to livelihood opportunities for displaced Iraqi and Syrian households in Iraq. The initiative focused on providing vocational training, small business support, and employment services to enhance economic resilience among internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities.

AgencyName: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade
ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE FOR IRAQ_FFIS(UNDP)
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian assistance for Iraq_FFIS(UNDP)
LongDescription: In 2016, the Republic of Korea's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) extended humanitarian assistance to Iraq through the United Nations Development Programme's (UNDP) Funding Facility for Immediate Stabilization (FFIS). This support was part of Korea's broader commitment to assist Iraq in its recovery from the impacts of conflict and instability. The FFIS aimed to provide rapid and flexible support to restore essential services and infrastructure in newly liberated areas, facilitating the safe return of displaced populations and contributing to the stabilization of the region. Korea's contribution underscored its dedication to international cooperation and the promotion of peace and stability in the Middle East.
Name_of_Donor: Korea, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

ShortDescription: ECONOMIC RECOVERY AND MARKET SYSTEMS, HUMANITARIAN COORDINATION AND INFORMATION MANAGEMENT
ProjectTitle: Economic Recovery and Market Systems, Humanitarian Coordination and Information Management
LongDescription: This program provides humanitarian aid to respond to acute needs in CAR through ERMS, HCIM, Shelter and Settlements assistance to CAR.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: VOLUNTARY CONTRIBUTION TO THE 2019 IRAQ CRIS FUNDING APPEAL - INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR MIGRATION DISPLACEMENT TRACKING MATRIX (DTM)
ProjectTitle: Voluntary Contribution to the 2019 Iraq Cris Funding Appeal - International Organization for Migration Displacement Tracking Matrix (Dtm)
LongDescription: The 2019 voluntary contribution from the United States to the International Organization for Migration (IOM) supported the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) in Iraq, a critical tool for monitoring displacement and return trends. This funding enabled IOM to collect and analyze data on internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees, informing humanitarian responses and policy decisions across the country.

ShortDescription: RETURNEES, INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS AND VULNERABLE IRAQIS ATTAIN LIVELIHOODS (RIVAL)
ProjectTitle: Returnees, Internally Displaced Persons and Vulnerable Iraqis Attain Livelihoods (Rival)
LongDescription: The 2019 "Returnees, Internally Displaced Persons and Vulnerable Iraqis Attain Livelihoods (RIVAL)" project, implemented by ZOA International and funded by the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, aimed to support economic recovery for conflict-affected populations in Iraq. The initiative focused on providing vocational training, agricultural support, and small business development to promote self-reliance among returnees, internally displaced persons (IDPs), and vulnerable Iraqis.

ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING THE PROTECTIVE ENVIRONMENT FOR AFFECTED CHILDREN, FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES THROUGH INCREASED ACCESS TO QUALITY EDUCATION AND CHILD PROTE
ProjectTitle: Strengthening the Protective Environment for Affected Children, Families and Communities Through Increased Access to Quality Education and Child Protection Services in Iraq
LongDescription: The 2019 initiative by Save the Children, funded through the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, aimed to strengthen the protective environment for conflict-affected children, families, and communities in Iraq by enhancing access to quality education and child protection services. The program focused on early childhood care and development (ECCD), targeting 210 children in Sinuni district (Ninewa), Domiz 2 and Gawilan refugee camps (Dohuk), and Khanaqin district (Diyala). Activities included the establishment of ECCD centers, provision of psychosocial support, and training for caregivers and educators to foster safe and inclusive learning environment

ShortDescription: HEALTH, MENTAL HEALTH, AND GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE SUPPORT FOR CAMP AND NON-CAMP-BASED SYRIAN REFUGEES
ProjectTitle: Health, Mental Health, and Gender-Based Violence Support for Camp and Non-Camp-Based Syrian Refugees
LongDescription: In 2016, International Medical Corps, supported by the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, implemented a program to provide health, mental health, and gender-based violence (GBV) support to Syrian refugees residing both in camps and host communities across Iraq. The initiative focused on delivering integrated services, including primary healthcare, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), and GBV prevention and response activities. These services were offered through static clinics, mobile medical units, and community-based safe spaces, aiming to address the comprehensive needs of the refugee population.

ShortDescription: IMPROVING ACCESS TO QUALITY HEALTH AND GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE SUPPORT SERVICES FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES IN CAMP AND NON-CAMP SETTINGS IN THE IRAQI KURDISTAN
ProjectTitle: Improving Access to Quality Health and Gender-Based Violence Support Services for Syrian Refugees in Camp and Non-Camp Settings in the Iraqi Kurdistan Region
LongDescription: The 2017 initiative by International Medical Corps, funded through the U.S. Population, Migration, and Refugee Assistance appropriation, aimed to enhance access to quality health and gender-based violence (GBV) support services for Syrian refugees residing in both camp and non-camp settings within the Iraqi Kurdistan Region. The program focused on delivering integrated primary healthcare, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), and GBV prevention and response services through static clinics, mobile medical units, and community-based safe spaces. These services were designed to address the comprehensive needs of the refugee population, ensuring culturally sensitive and survivor-centered care.

ShortDescription: MC PROPOSES TO INCREASE ACCESS TO EDUCATION FOR IDP AND HOST COMMUNITY YOUTH, ESPECIALLY GIRLS AND YOUNG WOMEN, IN DIYALA, KIRKUK, BAGHDAD, AL-RASHEED
ProjectTitle: Mc Proposes to Increase Access to Education for Idp and Host Community Youth, Especially Girls and Young Women, in Diyala, Kirkuk, Baghdad, Al-Rasheed
LongDescription: In 2016, Mercy Corps launched an initiative to increase access to education for internally displaced persons (IDPs) and host community youth, with a particular focus on girls and young women, in the governorates of Diyala, Kirkuk, and Baghdad, including the Al-Rasheed district. The program aimed to address the educational disruptions caused by conflict and displacement by providing safe learning environments, educational materials, and support services to facilitate the reintegration of affected youth into the formal education system.

ShortDescription: NZ IR3 EMERG. PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE
ProjectTitle: NZ IR3 EMERG. PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE
LongDescription: The UNICEF project titled "NZ IR3 EMERG. PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE" in Iraq, initiated in 2011, focused on enhancing the country's readiness and response capabilities to emergencies. This initiative aimed to strengthen institutional mechanisms, improve coordination among humanitarian actors, and ensure the timely delivery of essential services such as water, sanitation, health, education, and child protection during crises. The project also emphasized the importance of preparedness planning and capacity building to mitigate the impact of potential emergencies on vulnerable populations

ShortDescription: COMMUNITY INTEGRATION, GENDER BASED VIOLENCE AND MH PROJECT FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Community Integration, Gender Based Violence and Mh Project for Internally Displaced Persons in Iraq
LongDescription: The Community Integration, Gender-Based Violence (GBV), and Mental Health (MH) Project for Internally Displaced Persons in Iraq, funded by the United States Population Migration and Refugee Assistance in 2013, was implemented by International Medical Corps to address the critical needs of conflict-affected populations. The project provided survivor-centered GBV case management, risk mitigation, and prevention services, alongside integrated mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS) through community outreach and specialized consultations. In Erbil, International Medical Corps operated a primary health clinic in Baharka IDP Camp, offering both health and mental health services six days a week, and established mobile medical units to reach Syrian refugees and IDPs in urban areas and settlements. In Dohuk, the organization collaborated with local authorities to resume primary healthcare services in Garmawa Camp and expanded its capacity to meet increasing demands. The project also focused on community engagement, training local stakeholders in psychological first aid and mental health case management, and establishing women's and girls' safe spaces to support GBV survivors and vulnerable individuals

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - WASH AND SHELTER ASSISTANCE - OXFAM-QU횋BEC 2015 / CRISE EN IRAQ - EAU, ASSAINISSEMENT ET AIDE EN ABRI - OXFAM-QU횋BEC 2015
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - WASH and Shelter Assistance - OXFAM-Qubec 2015
LongDescription: December 2014 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate as armed clashes continue to drive displacement. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced an estimated 2 million people from their homes. With efforts to retake territory lost to ISIL in 2014 progress, additional displacement is expected in 2015. An estimated 5.2 million people across Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. The situation is expected to deteriorate as fighting and human rights violations persist.   With DFATD s support, the OXFAM-Qubec is helping to reduce the vulnerability of internally displaced people affected by the civil unrest in Iraq. Project activities include: (1) providing water and sanitation assistance, (2) raising awareness of hygiene and public health issues, and (3) providing cash and voucher assistance for shelter improvements, heating fuel, etc.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING RESILIENCE AND SUPPORT IN SECURING THE LIVELIHOOD AND PEACEFUL COEXISTENCE OF VULNERABLE GROUPS
ProjectTitle: Strengthening resilience and support in securing the livelihood and peaceful coexistence of vulnerable groups
LongDescription: Strengthening economic resilience, food security and peaceful coexistence for individuals and communities affected by conflict, displacement and COVID-19 in the IS-liberated areas of Ninewa and Anbar.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: USAID/OFDA GRANT FOR IRAQ/MOSUL DAM
ProjectTitle: USAID/OFDA Grant for Iraq/Mosul Dam
LongDescription: This award supports the UNDP phase II of early warning system for potential Mosul Dam breach focused on warning/alert systems, emergency response plans, and public awareness activities for communities along the flood path, as well as protection of essential infrastructure.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: SUPPORTING COMMUNITY POLICING AND TRANSITIONAL JUSTICE TO PROMOTE STABILISATION IN IRAQ (PHASE IV)
ProjectTitle: Supporting Community Policing and Transitional Justice to Promote Stabilisation in Iraq (Phase IV)
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: Contribute to enhancing peace, security and stability in Iraq and promoting an environment conducive to returns by strengthening the role of the State as the primary guarantor of safety and security through enhanced access to transitional justice and rights and improved trust between law enforcement officials and communities.

ShortDescription: ICRC APPEALS 2022-2025: OPERATIONS
ProjectTitle: ICRC Appeals 2022-2025: Operations
LongDescription: This is a Decision on Contribution (Rule for Managing Contributions 2.9 짠) between Sida and the International Committee of the Red Cross, ICRC, to allow for humanitarian response in relevant crises for 2022.  ICRC  s objectives are in line with the Strategy for Sweden  s Humanitarian Assistance through Sida (2021-2025). The contribution is relevant for all objectives in the strategy, with an emphasis on the strategy area on protection and assistance to crisis affected populations.  Out of the initial allocation, a segment is proposed to be un-allocated, which would enable the ICRC to swiftly allocate already pre-existing financial contributions to countries and regions which experience a crisis in a sudden onset, a deteriorated or a severely underfunded situation. Sida must, as per the suggested agreement, approve the ICRC suggestion on how the initially un-allocated funds are to be allocated.   During 2020, the Humanitarian Assistance Unit at Sida conducted an overview of ongoing strategic partnerships in order to ensure that partnership was established with the most relevant and effective humanitarian actors to carry out Sweden's strategy for humanitarian assistance through Sida (2021 ??2025). As a result of the overview, Sida has decided to appraise a new contribution and enter into a new strategic partnership agreement with ICRC, 2021-000057.  The main purpose of this contribution is, in line with the humanitarian strategy, to save life, alleviate suffering and maintain human dignity. Most of the policy markers, including environment and conflict prevention, have therefor been marked as partly applicable.

ShortDescription: SYRIA CRISIS - EMERGENCY FOOD ASSISTANCE - WORLD FOOD PROGRAMME 2013 / CRISE EN SYRIE - ASSISTANCE ALIMENTAIRE D'URGENCE - PROGRAMME ALIMENTAIRE MONDI
ProjectTitle: Syria Crisis - Emergency Food Assistance - World Food Programme 2013
LongDescription: August 2013 - The humanitarian situation in Syria has rapidly deteriorated over the past year as a result of the civil war in the country. The United Nations estimates that 100,000 people have been killed, and hundreds of thousands more wounded, due to the violence. Within Syria, some 6.8 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, 4.25 million of whom are internally displaced. In addition, close to 2 million Syrian refugees are living in host countries in the region. By the end of 2013, the United Nations estimates that 10 million people in Syria will need humanitarian assistance and a further 3.55 million refugees from Syria will have fled to host countries, whose resources are increasingly overstretched by the influx of people needing assistance. With the support of DFATD and other donors, the World Food Programme is providing food assistance to an estimated 6.7 million people, inside and outside Syria, affected by the conflict in Syria. This will help reduce acute malnutrition and food shortages, and protect livelihoods.

ShortDescription: PROMOTING SOCIAL COHESION IN IRAQ / PROMOUVOIR LA COH횋SION SOCIALE EN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Promoting Social Cohesion in Iraq
LongDescription: This project aims to help relieve social tensions between host-community members and internally displaced persons in several municipalities of the Diyala and Sulaymaniyah governorates of Iraq. It also complements Canada's existing humanitarian relief efforts for internally displaced persons in Iraq, thereby leveraging greater impact of Canada's response to the crisis.   Project activities include: (1) training of youth, women and men community leaders in basic negotiation, mediation, participatory project planning and management, (2) implementing 30 small to large scale community projects, (3) training internally displaced persons and host-community leaders in advanced negotiation and conflict management skills.   Over 20,000 women, girls, boys and men internally displaced persons and host-community members benefit from this project supported by Canada and implemented by Mercy Corps in the Chamchamal, Dokan, Khanaqin districts of the Diyala and Sulaymaniyah governorates.

ShortDescription: GOVERNANCE STRENGTHENING PROJECT - PUBLIC SECTOR EXECUTIVE FUNCTION
ProjectTitle: Governance Strengthening Project - Public Sector Executive Function
PurposeName: Public sector policy and administrative management
LongDescription: USAID's Governance Strengthening Project (GSP/Taqadum), initiated in 2011, aimed to enhance the capacity and accountability of Iraq's provincial and local governments. Implemented by Chemonics International, the project focused on institutional development, executive oversight, and improved service delivery across 15 provinces, including Erbil. Key initiatives involved training officials in budgeting, planning, and legislative processes, as well as establishing performance indicators and citizen engagement mechanisms. The project emphasized inclusivity, exceeding targets for female participation and fostering local ownership of governance reforms.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: 2021 SEED Y1 ADDRESSING GENDER BASED VIOLENCE AND INC[AWARDS-  COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS]
ProjectTitle: 2021 SEED Y1 Addressing Gender Based Violence and Inc[Awards-  Cooperative Agreements]
LongDescription: Prevent Gender Based Violence, and protect, empower and support survivors and vulnerable and conflict affected populations to address protection risks and support durable solutions.

ShortDescription: SUPPORT FOR VOLUNTARY FAMILY PLANNING SERVICES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Support for voluntary family planning services in Iraq
LongDescription: Supporting demographic transition has a multi-faceted impact that can help achieve FCDO NSC objectives  Maternal health & infant mortality Gender empowerment & girls education  Poverty and youth employment Fiscal space Political stability, inclusion, and participation Environmental impact Sustainability dividend  A more stable social contract
Name_of_Donor: United Kingdom, Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: PROSPECTS FOR PEACE THROUGH EDUCATION IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Prospects for Peace through Education in Iraq
LongDescription: The 2021 German-funded project, "Prospects for Peace through Education in Iraq," aimed to enhance university access for disadvantaged groups, including internally displaced persons (IDPs), refugees, and marginalized communities. Implemented by the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD) in collaboration with local universities, the initiative provided scholarships and support services to enable these groups to pursue higher education. This effort contributed to rebuilding Iraq's human capital and fostering long-term peace and stability by empowering youth through education.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: STUDIES AND EXPERTS FUND
ProjectTitle: Studies and Experts Fund
LongDescription: The goal of the project is identification of project approaches and planning, implementation and analysis of impacts of technical cooperation (TC)-activities.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING RESILIENCE THROUGH SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PEOPLE, REFUGEES, RETURNEES AND VULNERABLE HOST COMMUNITY FAMILIES
ProjectTitle: Strengthening resilience through sustainable livelihoods for internally displaced people, refugees, returnees and vulnerable host community families
LongDescription: Strengthening resilience through sustainable livelihoods for internally displaced people, refugees, returnees and vulnerable host community families
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: ADDRESSING THE RETURN AND REINTEGRATION OF IRAQIS WITH PERCEIVED AFFILIATION TO ISLAMIC STATE OF IRAQ AND THE LEVANT (ISIL) - PHASE II
ProjectTitle: Addressing the Return and Reintegration of Iraqis with Perceived Affiliation to Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) - Phase II
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: Contribute to stability in Iraq and reduce the risk of renewed violence, by strengthening social cohesion, addressing the key drivers of violent extremism, and strengthening the capacity of target communities to address challenges related to the return and reintegration of Iraqis with perceived affiliation to ISIL.

ShortDescription: NPA IRAQ 2023-2025
ProjectTitle: NPA Iraq 2023-2025
LongDescription: The contribution aims to support a set of civil society organisations (CSOs) that are play an active role in working for democracy, inclusion, environmental protection and sustainable development in Iraq. The programme period covers October 2023-december 2025 and will focus on:- supporting marginalised communities (women and youth groups-WYGs), to have increased representation, participation and influence in the decision-making processes and - strengthening Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) so they can effectively influence decisions and promote environment protection in IraqThe geographic scope of the programme covers: Locations within the provinces of Kurdistan Region, Kirkuk, Diyala, Baghdad, Basra, Dhi Qar, Muthanna, Maysan, Ninewa, Al횂짯Anbar, Babil, and Salah al횂짯Din.The contribution is coded as OECD DAC code 15150 - Democratic participation and civil society, since the aim of the project is to strengthen civil society organisations ability to play an active role in for democracy, inclusion andnvironmental protection.

ShortDescription: PROTECTION AND ASSISTANCE TO SYRIAN REFUGEES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Protection and Assistance to Syrian Refugees in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2014, Japan extended Emergency Grant Aid totaling $22.7 million to support Syrian refugees in Iraq and internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Lebanon, who were severely affected by the ISIL offensive. This assistance was channeled through international organizations such as UNHCR, UNICEF, WFP, ICRC, and IOM. The aid aimed to alleviate the humanitarian crisis by providing emergency shelters, non-food items, and essential services to the displaced populations. The initiative was part of Japan's broader commitment to support the international community's efforts in addressing the challenges posed by ISIL and assisting those affected by the conflict.

ShortDescription: UNMAS DEMINING PHASE 2 - UNMAS DEMINING PHASE 2, NEW STRATEGY
ProjectTitle: UNMAS Demining phase 2 - UNMAS Demining phase 2, new strategy
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: The UNMAS Demining Phase 2 program (2021), supported by Sida, aims to assist the Iraqi government in protecting civilians from the dangers of landmines and explosive remnants of war. This initiative enables safer humanitarian operations, socio-economic development, and community welfare by clearing contaminated areas. The program emphasizes building national capacity for mine risk management and clearance, contributing to the safe return of displaced populations and reconstruction efforts.

ShortDescription: PEACE WINDS SHELTER UPGRADE FOR SSRIAN REFUGEES IN THE KURDISTAN REGION OF IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Peace Winds Shelter Upgrade for Ssrian Refugees in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq
LongDescription: Peace Winds America, with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, initiated a shelter upgrade project in 2018 to enhance living conditions for Syrian refugees in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. The project focused on improving shelter durability and accessibility, particularly for individuals with disabilities and the elderly, by implementing features such as wheelchair ramps, handrails, and accessible sanitation facilities. Utilizing a cash-for-work model, refugees participated in the construction process, gaining skills and income. By August 2023, the project had upgraded shelters for approximately 4,500 families and improved access to 111 public facilities across camps in Erbil and Duhok governorates .

ShortDescription: PROVIDING SAFE AND NURTURING LEARNING ENVIRONMENTS FOR CONFLICT-AFFECTED GIRLS AND BOYS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Providing Safe and Nurturing Learning Environments for Conflict-Affected Girls and Boys in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2020, Catholic Relief Services (CRS), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a project to provide safe and nurturing learning environments for conflict-affected girls and boys in Iraq. The initiative focused on delivering quality education and emotional support to displaced children, particularly in areas heavily impacted by conflict. CRS operated in regions including Baghdad, Kirkuk, Mosul, Dohuk, and Erbil, offering educational programs and psychosocial services to support children's well-being and learning continuity

ShortDescription: WORLD FOOD PROGRAMME (WFP) MACRO GRANT - 2015 AWARD - ASSISTANCE AND RECOVERY
ProjectTitle: World Food Programme (WFP) Macro Grant - 2015 Award - Assistance and Recovery
LongDescription: In 2015, the World Food Programme (WFP), supported by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a macro grant in Iraq to provide emergency food assistance to conflict-affected populations. The initiative focused on delivering monthly food vouchers to approximately 60,000 Syrian refugees residing in camps, as well as providing food assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) across various governorates. The program aimed to address immediate food security needs and support recovery efforts amidst the ongoing humanitarian crisis.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: TO IMPROVE THE LIVING CONDITIONS AND PROTECTION MECHANISMS OF THE MOST VULNERABLE SYRIAN REFUGEES AND HOST-COMMUNITY MEMBERS RESIDING IN CAMPS AND NON
ProjectTitle: To Improve the Living Conditions and Protection Mechanisms of the Most Vulnerable Syrian Refugees and Host-Community Members Residing in Camps and Non
LongDescription: In 2015, the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a project in Iraq aimed at improving living conditions and protection mechanisms for vulnerable Syrian refugees and host-community members residing in both camps and non-camp settings. The initiative focused on providing shelter support, enhancing water and sanitation facilities, and offering legal assistance to secure housing, land, and property rights. NRC also established community outreach centres to facilitate access to essential services and information. The project was implemented across various locations in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq, including Erbil and Duhok governorates

ShortDescription: PEACE WINDS SHELTER UPGRADE FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES IN THE KURDISTAN REGION OF IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Peace Winds Shelter Upgrade for Syrian Refugees in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq
LongDescription: Peace Winds America, with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, continued its shelter upgrade initiative in 2019 to enhance living conditions for Syrian refugees in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. The project focused on improving shelter durability and accessibility, particularly for individuals with disabilities and the elderly, by implementing features such as wheelchair ramps, handrails, and accessible sanitation facilities. Utilizing a cash-for-work model, refugees participated in the construction process, gaining skills and income. The initiative also included the operation of tool service centers in partnership with the Barzani Charity Foundation, providing training and resources to support livelihood opportunities for refugees.

ShortDescription: INDEPENDENT MEDIA DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMME IN IRAQ 2023-2026 - IMS MEDIA SUPPORT TO IRAQ 2023-2026
ProjectTitle: Independent Media Development Programme in Iraq 2023-2026 - IMS media support to Iraq 2023-2026
PurposeName: Media and free flow of information
LongDescription: The overall objective of the programme is to strengthen public interest media to produce ethical, diverse, accountable, and inclusive public interest content. The contribution will also enable public debate on human rights, accountability and the advancement of positive social, political and cultural change. The contribution will allow forwarding of funds to 12 partners, seven media actors and five civil society organisations. Media partners will be offered training public interest content and media and disinformation while the civil society organisation will be doing advocacy on increasing an enabling environment for journalists in Iraq, byadvancing human rights and accountability for the media workers and journalists. The contribution is linked to the OECD DAC's code 15153 since it aims to support journalists connected to independent media to develop media content that is fact-based and free from disinformation.

ShortDescription: TECHNICAL SUPPORT UNBOUND FINANCIAL CREDIT II
ProjectTitle: Technical support Unbound Financial Credit II
LongDescription: The 2017 German-funded project, "Technical Support for Unbound Financial Credit II," aimed to assist the Iraqi Reconstruction Fund for Areas Affected by Terroristic Operations (REFAATO) in implementing its investment program through consulting services. The initiative focused on enhancing REFAATO's capacity to plan, execute, and assess the impacts of reconstruction projects in areas liberated from ISIS. By providing technical expertise, the project sought to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of REFAATO's operations, ensuring that investments contributed to sustainable recovery and development in affected regions.

ShortDescription: CONSULTING SERVICES FOR RECONSTRUCTION FUND FOR AREAS AFFECTED BY TERRORISTIC OPERATIONS (REFAATO)
ProjectTitle: Consulting services for Reconstruction Fund for Areas Affected by Terroristic Operations (REFAATO)
LongDescription: The 2017 German-funded project aimed to provide technical support to the Iraqi Reconstruction Fund for Areas Affected by Terroristic Operations (REFAATO) through consulting services. Managed by GOPA Infra GmbH, the initiative focused on enhancing REFAATO's capacity to plan, execute, and assess the impacts of reconstruction projects in areas liberated from ISIS. Key activities included strengthening institutional structures, improving project management processes, and ensuring effective coordination with relevant stakeholders. This support was crucial in facilitating the efficient and sustainable reconstruction of affected regions, contributing to the stabilization and recovery of Iraq

ShortDescription: DEPOSIT INTO THE IRAQ HUMANITARIAN FUND (IHF)
ProjectTitle: Deposit into the Iraq Humanitarian Fund (IHF)
LongDescription: In 2020, the German government made significant contributions to the Iraq Humanitarian Fund (IHF) to support humanitarian efforts in Iraq. These funds were allocated to address the needs of vulnerable populations affected by conflict and displacement. The IHF facilitated rapid and flexible funding for humanitarian projects, enabling partners to respond effectively to emergencies and provide essential services such as food assistance, health care, and protection services. Germany's support underscored its commitment to alleviating the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and promoting stability in the region.

ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING REGIONAL DISASTER CONTROL AND ESTABILISHING HUMANITARIAN INFRASTRUCTURE IN ERBIL
ProjectTitle: Strengthening regional disaster control and estabilishing humanitarian infrastructure in Erbil
LongDescription: The German-funded project aimed to enhance regional disaster control and establish humanitarian infrastructure in Erbil, Kurdistan Region of Iraq. Implemented by the German Red Cross, the initiative focused on improving disaster preparedness and response capabilities through capacity-building activities and infrastructure development. Key components included training for local emergency responders, establishment of emergency response units, and development of facilities to support humanitarian operations. This project contributed to strengthening the resilience of Erbil's communities in the face of potential disasters and emergencies.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Emergency Assistance in Iraq
LongDescription: The 2017 German-funded project, "Emergency Assistance for Internally Displaced People and Returnees in Ninewa (East Mosul)," aimed to provide critical shelter and WASH (Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene) support to populations affected by the conflict in Iraq. Implemented by Mission East, the initiative focused on delivering essential non-food items (NFIs), emergency shelter solutions, and improving access to clean water and sanitation facilities for displaced individuals and returning families in the Ninewa governorate. This assistance was crucial in alleviating the immediate humanitarian needs of the affected populations and supporting their recovery and reintegration efforts.

ShortDescription: OPPORTUNITIES FOR EDUCATION FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED AND LOCAL BOYS AND GIRLS IN ERBIL GOUVERNEMENT
ProjectTitle: Opportunities for education for internally displaced and local boys and girls in Erbil gouvernement
LongDescription: The German-funded project aimed to enhance educational opportunities for internally displaced persons (IDPs) and local children in Erbil Governorate, Kurdistan Region of Iraq. Implemented by the German Corporation for International Cooperation (GIZ), the initiative focused on providing consulting services to the Kurdistan Regional Government's Ministry of Education. Key activities included monitoring educational facilities, developing education plans, and supporting the construction and rebuilding of schools to accommodate the influx of displaced students. This project contributed to improving access to quality education for vulnerable children in the region.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: LIVING IN DIGNITY, A SAFE ENVIRONMENT AND CONNECTION FOR WOMEN AND THEIR CHILDREN AFFECTED BY (S)GBV IN THE KURDISH AUTONOMOUS REGION OF IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Living in Dignity, A safe environment and connection for women and their children affected by (S)GBV in the Kurdish Autonomous Region of Iraq
PurposeName: Ending violence against women and girls
LongDescription: The 2020 German-funded project, "Living in Dignity," aimed to provide a safe environment and support for women and their children affected by sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) in the Kurdish Autonomous Region of Iraq. Implemented by the Women Rehabilitation Organization (WRO), the initiative focused on enhancing access to essential services such as psychosocial support, legal assistance, and protection services for survivors of SGBV. The project also worked towards reducing the risks of SGBV through community-based interventions and awareness-raising activities. By addressing the immediate needs of survivors and promoting long-term prevention strategies, the project contributed to fostering a safer and more supportive environment for women and children in the region.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: FINANCIAL SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM. - FINANCIAL SECTOR CAPACITY
ProjectTitle: Financial Sector Development Program. - Financial Sector Capacity
LongDescription: The Iraq Financial Sector Development Program is a c ontract from the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) to provide economic-consulting services to Iraq. The work is intended to improve the soundness of the Iraqi private financial sector through institution building and targeted economic reforms, and improving the quality and availability of finance and business education. The contract builds on AECOM s long-standing partnership with USAID in its efforts to rebuild Iraq s economy.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: FY21 INL AME UNDP IRAQ FINANCIAL INTELLIGENCE
ProjectTitle: FY21 INL AME UNDP Iraq Financial Intelligence
LongDescription: Unified approach to Countering Illicit Finance Assistance awards made through Bilateral Agreements, Letters of Agreement, including those established under C-175 authority, and Fulbright Commission agreements. The obligation of funds does not constitute a bulk obligation where funds will later be sub-obligated through other instruments.

ShortDescription: FOOD EMERGENCY RELIEF IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Food emergency relief in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2019, Germany provided significant humanitarian assistance to address the food security needs of Syrian refugees and internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq, particularly in the Kurdistan Region. The German Federal Foreign Office (GFFO) contributed €17.5 million to the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP), enabling the provision of monthly food assistance to approximately 28,600 Syrian refugees. This support was crucial in alleviating food insecurity among vulnerable populations affected by the Syrian conflict.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: PROTECTION AND EMPOWERMENT OF SYRIAN REFUGEES, INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS, RETURNEES AND VULNERABLE HOSTR COMMUNITIES
ProjectTitle: Protection and Empowerment of Syrian refugees, internally displaced persons, returnees and vulnerable hostr communities
LongDescription: The project aims at strengthening the psychosocial well beiing and positive coping strategies and contributes to a successful integration respectively reintegration of Syrian refugees, internally displaced persons, returnees and contributes to the stabilisation of host communities in Sulaymaniyah, Ninive.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - SHELTER, WATER AND EDUCATION FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PEOPLE - 2016 / LA CRISE EN IRAK - ABRIS, EAU ET 횋DUCATION POUR LES PERSONNES D횋PL
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Shelter, Water and Education for Internally Displaced People - 2016
LongDescription: March 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 3.2 million people from their homes. An estimated 10 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. The capacity of the Government to respond to the basic needs of its citizens has been overwhelmed. In 2016, more people will be displaced by the conflict, while many will remain displaced in camps and host communities. However, there will also be growing numbers of people returning to areas no longer under the control of ISIL who will also need assistance to help restart their lives.   With GAC's support, this project is helping up to 9,348 people affected by violence live with dignity in areas of displacement or return. This project will: (1) provide shelter solutions for up to 1,100 vulnerable displaced families, (2) provide up to 1,100 conflict-affected families with safe and adequate water and sanitation facilities, (3) provide up to 2,500 displaced children with access to quality education and psychosocial support by establishing child support centres, and (4) provide schools with teaching and learning materials.

ShortDescription: SUPPORT TO POPULATIONS AFFECT. BY EXPLOSIVE ORDNANCE THROUGH COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH, INCREASED ACCESS TO & QUALITY OF SPECIALIZED HEALTH SERVICES, IRQ
ProjectTitle: Support to populations affect. by explosive ordnance through comprehensive approach, increased access to & quality of specialized health Services, IRQ
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: Support to populations affected by explosive ordnance through a comprehensive approach including Clearance, Explosive Ordnance Risk education (EORE) and increased access to and quality of specialized health Services, IRQ. Safe access to mine free land is possible and access to specialised health care granted.

ShortDescription: USAID/OFDA GRANT FOR IRAQ/MOSUL DAM - ASSISTANCE AND RECOVERY
ProjectTitle: USAID/OFDA Grant for Iraq/Mosul Dam - Assistance and Recovery
LongDescription: This award supports the UNDP phase II of early warning system for potential Mosul Dam breach focused on warning/alert systems, emergency response plans, and public awareness activities for communities along the flood path, as well as protection of essential infrastructure.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: FUNDING FOR IOM'S DISPLACEMENT TRACKING MATRIX TO HELP ADVANCE THE POLICY OBJECTIVE OF IMPROVING HUMANITARIAN CONDITIONS IN IRAQ BY CONTRIBUTING TO A
ProjectTitle: Funding for Iom's Displacement Tracking Matrix to Help Advance the Policy Objective of Improving Humanitarian Conditions in Iraq By Contributing to A
LongDescription: In 2016, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) in Iraq to monitor and analyze internal displacement trends. The DTM collected data on internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees across the country, providing critical information to humanitarian partners and government agencies to inform response strategies and resource allocation. This initiative aimed to improve humanitarian conditions by offering timely and accurate data on displacement dynamics

ShortDescription: 2017 IRAQ HUMANITARIAN RESPONSE PLAN APPEAL: INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR MIGRATION WILL PRIORITIZE THIS FUNDING FOR SUPPORT OF THE DISPLACEMENT TRA
ProjectTitle: 2017 Iraq Humanitarian Response Plan Appeal: International Organization for Migration Will Prioritize This Funding for Support of the Displacement Tracking Matrix (Dtm) in Iraq
LongDescription: The International Organization for Migration (IOM), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, prioritized support for the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) in Iraq under the 2017 Humanitarian Response Plan. The DTM collected and analyzed data on internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees, providing critical information to humanitarian partners and government agencies to inform response strategies and resource allocation. This initiative aimed to improve humanitarian conditions by offering timely and accurate data on displacement dynamics.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - RESPONSE TO SEXUAL AND GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE - 2015 / CRISE EN IRAQ - R횋PONSE ? LA VIOLENCE SEXUELLE ET FOND횋E SUR LE SEXE - 2015
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Response to Sexual and Gender-Based Violence - 2015
LongDescription: March 2015 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 2.4 million people from their homes. An estimated 5.2 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. As fighting and human rights violations persist and international efforts remain to free territory controlled by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), the situation is expected to deteriorate and to cause additional displacement.   With DFATD's support, and that of other donors, the partner is providing protection for up to 35,000 women and girls survivors of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) across Iraq. Project activities include: (1) establishing women and girls centres in camps and host communities to provide services to SGBV survivors, such as case management, community outreach to identify victims of SGBV that don't come forward, and organize advocacy campaigns to raise awareness of SGBV, (2) addressing child forced marriage by providing direct support and safe spaces for child brides and engaging the community on the issue of early and forced marriage, and (3) coordinating the overall humanitarian response to SGBV in Iraq.

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE - COUNTRY-LEVEL FUNDING FOR THE MIDDLE EAST - UNHCR 2019-2021/AIDE D'URGENCE - FINANCEMENT AU NIVEAU DES PAYS POUR LE MOYEN-ORIEN
ProjectTitle: Emergency Assistance - Country-Level Funding for the Middle East - UNHCR 2019-2021
LongDescription: July 2019 Humanitarian needs stemming from the crises in Syria and Iraq remain significant throughout the Middle East. Continued violence in Syria raises little prospects for the voluntary, safe, sustainable and dignified return of over 5.6 million refugees in the region. Internally displaced persons range in the millions in Syria and Iraq, and refugees facing protracted displacement in host countries continue to face acute humanitarian needs in Jordan and Lebanon.With the support of GAC and other donors, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) provides assistance and protection to refugees, internally-displaced persons and other persons of concern in Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon and Syria.Project activities include: (1) providing shelter, clothing and other essential non-food items, (2) providing adequate water, sanitation, and health services, including in reproductive health, (3) providing opportunities for education and livelihoods support, (4) providing protection, including against sexual and gender-based violence, child protection and working with governments to register asylum seekers and refugees, and help issue identity documents, (5) working with governments to support refugee self-reliance and forge peaceful relations between refugees and local citizens, and (6) expanding opportunities for durable solutions for people of concern.

ShortDescription: SYRIA CRISIS - FOOD ASSISTANCE FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES IN EGYPT AND IRAQ - WFP 2014 / CRISE EN SYRIE - ASSISTANCE ALIMENTAIRE POUR LES R횋FUGI횋S SYRIENS EN
ProjectTitle: Syria Crisis - Food Assistance for Syrian Refugees in Egypt and Iraq - WFP 2014
LongDescription: February 2014 - The humanitarian situation in Syria continues to deteriorate as a result of the civil war in the country. The United Nations estimates that more than 130,000 people have been killed, with hundreds of thousands more wounded, due to the violence. Within Syria, some 9.3 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, 6.5 million of whom are internally displaced. In addition, over 2.4 million Syrian refugees are registered and living in host countries in the region. Women and children are particularly vulnerable to the impact of the conflict and host countries are increasingly overstretched by the influx of affected people needing assistance.   With the support of DFATD and other donors, the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) is providing food assistance to 146,000 Syrian and Palestinian refugees in Egypt and 300,000 Syrian refugees in Iraq. The project activity includes providing food or cash or vouchers to purchase food when appropriate.

ShortDescription: 2022 WHO IRAQ
ProjectTitle: 2022 WHO Iraq
LongDescription: In 2022, the World Health Organization (WHO), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, enhanced the humanitarian health response for Syrian refugees in Iraq. The initiative provided free access to primary healthcare services through camp-based primary health care centres (PHCCs) for refugees residing in camps, and through specified public health facilities for those living within host communities. These services were delivered in collaboration with the directorates of health in Erbil, Dohuk, and Sulaymaniyah, aiming to improve health security and resilience among refugees and host communities.

ShortDescription: MINES ADVISORY GROUP, MAG, MINES IRAQ, 2013-2014
ProjectTitle: Mines Advisory Group, MAG, Mines Iraq, 2013-2014
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: MAG implements its demining operations during 2013-2014 in order to address the humanitarian and socio-economic barriers that mines pose, in one of the world's most contaminated countries, Iraq. In northern Iraq, where the project is implemented, it will also focus on capacity development of the regional authority responsible for demining, IKMAA.

ShortDescription: TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH AND WELLBEING OF SYRIAN REFUGEES IN IRAQ.
ProjectTitle: To Improve the Health and Wellbeing of Syrian Refugees in Iraq.
LongDescription: In 2015, International Medical Corps (IMC), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a comprehensive health initiative to improve the well-being of Syrian refugees in Iraq. The program provided primary healthcare services, maternal and child health support, mental health and psychosocial assistance, and community health education. IMC operated in several refugee camps, including Domiz 1 in Duhok Governorate and Kawergosk in Erbil Governorate, delivering essential medical care and promoting health awareness among displaced populations.

ShortDescription: COMMUNITY POLICING IN RETURN AREAS
ProjectTitle: Community Policing in return areas
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: The 2017 German-funded project aimed to strengthen peace and security in return areas in Iraq through the establishment of Community Policing Forums (CPFs). Implemented by the International Organization for Migration (IOM) in collaboration with Iraq’s Ministry of Interior, the initiative focused on enhancing cooperation between law enforcement agencies and community members to address security concerns and promote stability. Key activities included the establishment of CPFs in liberated areas, training for police officers and community representatives, and fostering dialogue to rebuild trust between communities and security forces. The project contributed to creating safer environments for internally displaced persons and returnees, facilitating their reintegration into their home communities.

ShortDescription: NRC S HUMANITARIAN PROGRAMME 2021-2025 - NRC HUMANITARIAN COUNTRY PROGRAMMES AND METHOD / CAP.-BUILD. PROJECTS 2021-2025
ProjectTitle: NRC s Humanitarian Programme 2021-2025 - NRC Humanitarian Country programmes and Method / Cap.-build. projects 2021-2025
LongDescription: The Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) has applied for a renewed strategic partnership with Sida during 2021-2025.NRC has applied as well to Sida for funding of 364.5 million SEK to carry out the Humanitarian Programme for 2021 in 26 humanitarian crisis settings: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania/Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen. The application includes provision of 40 million SEK to replenish the Rapid Response Mechanism funding instrument and 7 individual projects for method, capacity-building and coordination.The intervention's tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sida's funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR, etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach ??PBA).짭NRC s catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRC s advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRC s analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRC s portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Sweden s development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.In 2022 support NRC with 455,5 MSEK in total of Sida's humanitarian funding, according to the following breakdown:- The grant will support NRC humanitarian programmes in 23 crises settings that Sida has prioritized through its needs-based allocation model, with 288.5 MSEK during 2022.- As multi-annual funding for emergency response in DR Congo, Mali and Nigeria is initiated in 2022, the grant will provide as well NRC with outstanding financial commitments from Sida, estimated 104 MSEK for 2023-2024.- NRC emergency response in sudden onset crises will be supported through Sida's Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) window with 50 MSEK for 2022.- NRC's method and capacity development projects for Protection, Environment and the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) will receive 13 MSEK, including 3 MSEK from Sida/Globen for IDMC.Sida's contribution to NRC for 2022 will cover around 6.5% of NRC's total financial requirements of the supported programmes and projects. It wi

ProjectTitle: Support to Integrated Reconciliation
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: In 2017, Germany provided significant support to Iraq's national reconciliation efforts through the "Support for Integrated Reconciliation in Iraq" (SIRI) project, implemented by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in partnership with Iraq's National Reconciliation Committee. This initiative aimed to foster social cohesion and peaceful coexistence in post-ISIS Iraq

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE/COOPERATION ACTIVITIES
ProjectTitle: humanitarian assistance/cooperation activities
LongDescription: In 2014, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) intensified its humanitarian efforts in Iraq amidst escalating conflict and widespread displacement. The ICRC provided emergency assistance to over 1.5 million people, including food, water, and essential relief items, across 14 provinces. They also supported health facilities and physical rehabilitation centers, visited detainees, and facilitated family reunifications. Additionally, the ICRC promoted adherence to International Humanitarian Law among all parties to the conflict.

ShortDescription: EXPLOSIVE HAZARD CLEARANCE IN MOSUL DISTRICT/D횋MINAGE DES ENGINS EXPLOSIFS DANS LE DISTRICT DE MOSUL
ProjectTitle: Explosive Hazard Clearance in Mosul District
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: The project aims to increase stabilization and early recovery conditions of in areas of Mosul District by clearing explosive hazards and build local capacity to address residual contamination in the future. The project provides mentorship and oversight to all operations through locally trained teams. Project activities include: (1) training and mentoring local teams to deliver mine risk education for local communities, (2) conducting non-technical surveys, and (3) conducting clearance operations.

ShortDescription: AMERICAN STYLE HIGHER EDUCATION IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: American Style Higher Education in Iraq
LongDescription: The "Reconciliation and Prosperity in Iraq through American-Style Higher Education" project, initiated in 2021, aimed to strengthen American-style higher education institutions across Iraq. Funded by the U.S. Department of State, the initiative supported universities such as the American University of Iraq—Baghdad (AUIB), the American University of Iraq—Sulaimani (AUIS), the American University of Kurdistan (AUK), and the Catholic University in Erbil (CUE). The program focused on enhancing academic quality, fostering international partnerships, and aligning curricula with global standards to promote reconciliation and economic development in Iraq

ShortDescription: CAREER PLANNING FOR IRAQ S RE ENGAGING STUDENTS
ProjectTitle: Career Planning for Iraq s Re Engaging Students
LongDescription: The "Career Planning for Iraq’s Re-Engaging Students" project, initiated in 2022, aimed to strengthen American-style higher education institutions in Iraq by enhancing career development services for students returning to campus-based learning. Funded by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs, the initiative focused on improving career counseling, expanding internship opportunities, and fostering partnerships with the private sector to better align academic programs with labor market needs. Participating institutions included the American University of Iraq–Sulaimani (AUIS), the American University of Kurdistan (AUK), the American University of Iraq–Baghdad (AUIB), and the Catholic University in Erbil (CUE)

ShortDescription: BUILDING RESILIENT LIVELIHOODS AMONG VULNERABLE IRAQI IDPS, RETURNEES, AND HOST COMMUNITIES IN SALAH AL-DIN AND DIYALA GOVERNATES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Building Resilient Livelihoods Among Vulnerable Iraqi Idps, Returnees, and Host Communities in Salah Al-Din and Diyala Governates in Iraq
LongDescription: The Near East Foundation (NEF), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented the "Building Resilient Livelihoods" project to support vulnerable Iraqi internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities in Salah al-Din and Diyala governorates. The initiative focused on enhancing economic resilience through vocational training, access to capital, and the establishment of community-based livelihood support hubs known as Siraj Centers. These centers served as platforms for delivering business development services, facilitating market linkages, and promoting inclusive economic growth. By strengthening local capacities and fostering entrepreneurship, the project aimed to improve income-generating opportunities and support sustainable livelihoods in conflict-affected areas

ShortDescription: IMPROVE STABILISATION
ProjectTitle: Improve Stabilisation
LongDescription: Activities covering Stabilisation in Iraq
Name_of_Donor: United Kingdom, Conflict stability and security fund

ProjectTitle: Strengthening American Style Higher
LongDescription: Strengthening American-Style Higher Education in Iraq project.
