ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING PROTECTION, EMPOWERMENT, AND ADVOCACY FOR THE RIGHTS OF SURVIVORS OF GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE AND CONFLICT-AFFECTED PEOPLE IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Strengthening Protection, Empowerment, and Advocacy for the Rights of Survivors of Gender-Based Violence and Conflict-Affected People in Iraq
LongDescription: The SEED Foundation, with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a program to strengthen protection, empowerment, and advocacy for survivors of gender-based violence (GBV) and conflict-affected individuals in Iraq. The initiative focused on providing comprehensive services, including mental health support, legal assistance, and community-based programs, to address the needs of survivors and promote their recovery and reintegration into society. By collaborating with local authorities and organizations, the program aimed to enhance the capacity of service providers and advocate for policies that protect the rights of vulnerable populations.

ShortDescription: ICRC APPEALS 2018-2020: OPERATIONS
ProjectTitle: ICRC Appeals 2018-2020: Operations
LongDescription: Each year Sida undertakes a humanitarian allocation process in which all on-goinghumanitarian crises are analyzed, and where the partners most relevant to respond toidentified needs in each specific crisis are selected. The initial funding to the ICRC in2018, which is being encompassed in this decision, is thus based on the Sidahumanitarian allocation process that took place in late 2017. A three-year agreement ishowever suggested to be signed with the ICRC, where additional contributions will beadded to the agreement, subject to funds availability, governmental appropriations andSida needs assessments.For 2018, it is proposed that 450 MSEK is allocated to the ICRC for the implementationof activities in 36 contexts (of which 8 are regional and covers several countries). Out ofthe initial allocation 115 MSEK is proposed to be unallocated, which would enable theICRC to flexibly add additional financial contributions to countries and regions withincreased needs or that are severely underfunded. Sida must, as per the agreement,approve the ICRC suggestion on how the unallocated funds are to be allocated.An additional 10 MSEK (5 MSEK per year) is allocated to the ICRC as unallocatedfunding for 2019 and 2020, respectively.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: NEW PARTNERSHIPS FOR COMPREHENSIVE RECONSTRUCTION
ProjectTitle: New partnerships for comprehensive reconstruction
LongDescription: The aim of the plan is to support the return process in the provinces of Diyala and Kirkuk by the reconstruction of local structures and strengthening of municipalities and to improve the Resilienz of the population. This happens by access to many-sided food, sure drinking water care and sewage disposal. The life bases and income possibilities, in particular for women, are improved (cash for work), local state and civil-social structures are strengthened and improved.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: IMPROVING HEALTH AND EDUCATION OUTCOMES OF CONFLICT-AFFECTED IRAQI INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS AND RETURNEES
ProjectTitle: Improving Health and Education Outcomes of Conflict-Affected Iraqi Internally Displaced Persons and Returnees
LongDescription: Handicap International (now known as Humanity & Inclusion), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a program to improve health and education outcomes for conflict-affected internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees in Iraq. The initiative focused on providing rehabilitation care, psychosocial support, and inclusive education services, particularly for individuals with disabilities. Activities included training local health professionals, distributing assistive devices, and promoting inclusive education practices to ensure that children with disabilities had access to quality education. The program was implemented in various regions, including Ninewa, Diyala, Kirkuk, and Anbar governorates.

ShortDescription: PROVISION OF EDUCATION, INFORMATION, COUNSELLING AND LEGAL ASSISTANCE (ICLA) AND LIVELIHOODS SUPPORTS TO VULNERABLE SYRIAN REFUGEES IN ERBIL AND DOHUK
ProjectTitle: Provision of Education, Information, Counselling and Legal Assistance (Icla) and Livelihoods Supports to Vulnerable Syrian Refugees in Erbil and Dohuk Governorates of Iraq
LongDescription: The Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), supported by U.S. Department of State funding, implemented a program to support vulnerable Syrian refugees in Erbil and Dohuk governorates of Iraq. The initiative provided education, livelihoods support, and Information, Counselling, and Legal Assistance (ICLA) services. These services aimed to enhance access to civil documentation, housing, land, and property rights, and improve employment opportunities for refugees. The program was implemented in refugee camps such as Domiz 1 and Bardarash in Dohuk, and Qushtapa and Kawergosk in Erbil. These efforts contributed to the protection and empowerment of Syrian refugees residing in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq

ShortDescription: FISCAL DECENTRALISATION AND RESILIENCY-BUILDING FOR IRAQ / LA D횋CENTRALISATION FISCALE ET ACCROITRE LA R횋SILIENCE D'IRAK
ProjectTitle: Fiscal Decentralisation and Resiliency-Building for Iraq
LongDescription: This project aims to address short- and long-term constraints affecting the Iraqi Government's ability to meet the needs of the population in an effective and equitable manner. It will support building the capacity of various levels of government to manage the current fiscal and humanitarian crises and to become more resilient in the face of any new crisis.   The project will strengthen the capacity of representatives of the Government of Iraq to allow them to be better placed to implement necessary reforms related to fiscal and program decentralisation. It will support the establishment of a common understanding on fiscal and program decentralisation among the various levels of government, will develop a knowledge base on program decentralization and support capacity building activities, including through the engagement of stakeholders and holding of workshops and seminars related to fiscal and program decentralisation.   The humanitarian crisis caused by the influx of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and refugees within its borders is hindering the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) abilities to focus on other priorities that are essential for the long-term development. This influx is overstretching health, education and social protection services in the KRI and is placing severe strains on the local economy. The project will help strengthen the capacity of the KRG to play a more central leadership and coordination role on the crisis response, allowing it to incorporate immediate response measures into its longer-term development planning.

ShortDescription: USAID/OFDA GRANT FOR IRAQ/COMPLEX EMERGENCY - PROTECTION AND SOLUTIONS
ProjectTitle: USAID/OFDA Grant for Iraq/Complex Emergency - Protection and Solutions
LongDescription: USAID's Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) provided substantial humanitarian aid in 2015 to address Iraq's complex emergency. The assistance encompassed protection services, health and WASH interventions, and emergency relief supplies, benefiting conflict-affected populations across multiple governorates.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE IN SHELTER, WATER, HYGIENE AND SANITATION - 2015 / CRISE EN IRAQ - AIDE D'URGENCE, ABRIS, EAU, ASSAINISSEMENT ET HY
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Emergency Assistance in Shelter, Water, Hygiene and Sanitation - 2015
LongDescription: March 2015 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 2.4 million people from their homes. An estimated 5.2 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. As fighting and human rights violations persist and international efforts remain to free territory controlled by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), the situation is expected to deteriorate and to cause additional displacement.   With DFATD's support, the partner is helping to reduce the vulnerability of internally displaced people affected by the civil unrest in Iraq. Project activities include: (1) providing emergency financial support towards housing for 3,000 conflict-affected people, (2) providing 10,800 vulnerable people with essential cooking sets, (3) distributing hygiene kits containing items such as soap, sanitary napkins, diapers and toothpaste, (4) providing household level water treatment and storage solutions, and (5) providing educational messages on hygiene.

ShortDescription: 2019 IOM CRP PHASE IX IRAQ[FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE- VOLUNTARY CONTRIBUTIONS]
ProjectTitle: 2019 IOM CRP Phase IX Iraq[Financial Assistance- Voluntary Contributions]
LongDescription: Initial Contribution for the Community Revitalization Program (CRP) IX to continue contributing to stabilization efforts by the government of Iraq

ShortDescription: IMPROVE THE HUMANITARIAN HEALTH RESPONSE TO THE SYRIAN REFUGEES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Improve the Humanitarian Health Response to the Syrian Refugees in Iraq
LongDescription: The World Health Organization (WHO), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, enhanced the humanitarian health response for Syrian refugees in Iraq. The initiative provided free access to primary healthcare services through camp-based primary health care centres (PHCCs) for refugees residing in camps, and through specified public health facilities for those living within host communities. These services were delivered in collaboration with the directorates of health in Erbil, Dohuk, and Sulaymaniyah, aiming to improve health security and resilience among refugees and host communities.

ShortDescription: NPA HUMANITARIAN DISARMAMENT PROGRAMME IN SOUTH IRAQ, CLEARANCE AND CAPACITY SUPPORT
ProjectTitle: NPA Humanitarian Disarmament Programme in South Iraq, Clearance and Capacity Support
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: Norwegian People's Aid (NPA) implemented a humanitarian disarmament program in southern Iraq, focusing on the clearance of landmines and unexploded ordnance (UXO) and building local capacity for mine action. Operating primarily in Basra and Muthanna governorates, NPA conducted technical and non-technical surveys, manual and mechanical clearance operations, and provided training to national authorities and local personnel. These efforts aimed to reduce threats to civilian security and facilitate safe access to land for communities affected by past conflicts.

ShortDescription: INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR MIGRATION FAST TRACK AND SRP CONTRIBUTION
ProjectTitle: International Organization for Migration Fast Track and SRP Contribution
LongDescription: The International Organization for Migration (IOM), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented the "Fast Track and SRP Contribution" program in 2015 to address the urgent humanitarian needs arising from Iraq's complex emergency. This initiative focused on providing critical assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) and conflict-affected populations through the delivery of shelter and non-food items (NFIs), livelihood support, and logistics services. The program was part of the broader Strategic Response Plan (SRP) and Fast Track Priorities, which aimed to rapidly mobilize resources to meet the most pressing needs in areas experiencing significant displacement and insecurity. Key operational areas included Anbar, Ninewa, Salah al-Din, and Kirkuk governorates, where IOM's interventions contributed to stabilizing communities and supporting the return and reintegration of displaced individuals

ShortDescription: 2018 SYRIA REGIONAL REFUGEE AND RESILIENCE PLAN
ProjectTitle: 2018 Syria Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan
LongDescription: The World Health Organization (WHO), supported by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, participated in the 2018–2019 Syria Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP) to enhance healthcare services for Syrian refugees in Iraq. This initiative aimed to strengthen health systems, improve access to primary healthcare, and bolster disease surveillance and outbreak response capacities, particularly in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KR-I), where the majority of Syrian refugees reside. By collaborating with local health authorities, WHO worked to ensure that refugees and host communities received essential health services, contributing to the overall resilience and stability of the region.

ShortDescription: USAID/OFDA GRANT FOR COMPLEX EMERGENCY - PROTECTION AND SOLUTIONS
ProjectTitle: USAID/OFDA Grant for Complex Emergency - Protection and Solutions
LongDescription: USAID's Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) provided humanitarian aid in 2016 to address Iraq's complex emergency. The assistance encompassed protection services, health and WASH interventions, and emergency relief supplies, benefiting conflict-affected populations across multiple governorates.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH AND HUMAN SECURITY: SAVING WOMENS' LIVES IN CONFLICT, SAVING COMMUNITIES
ProjectTitle: Reproductive Health and Human Security: Saving womens' lives in conflict, saving communities
LongDescription: In 2016, Japan partnered with UNFPA to enhance reproductive health and human security in conflict-affected regions of Iraq. The initiative focused on providing emergency obstetric and reproductive healthcare to survivors of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV), pregnant women, and internally displaced persons (IDPs) through mobile and static clinics. Key outcomes included improved case management for SGBV survivors, establishment of safe women-only spaces, and capacity building for national SGBV service providers. The project targeted areas such as Anbar, Salahaddin, Baghdad, Kirkuk, and Ninewa governorates, aiming to strengthen the resilience of vulnerable communities and promote gender equality.

ShortDescription: UNDP STABILIZATION PROJECT - PUBLIC SECTOR EXECUTIVE FUNCTION
ProjectTitle: UNDP Stabilization Project - Public Sector Executive Function
PurposeName: Public sector policy and administrative management
LongDescription: USAID is supporting two major United Nations (UN) efforts to help Iraqis return to their homes in areas freed from occupation by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, also known as Daesh
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: ACCESSING QUALITY BASIC EDUCATION IN IRAQ II
ProjectTitle: Accessing Quality Basic Education in Iraq II
LongDescription: Catholic Relief Services (CRS), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented the "Accessing Quality Basic Education in Iraq II" project to enhance educational access and quality for conflict-affected children. Building upon previous initiatives, CRS operated in multiple governorates, including Dohuk, Kirkuk, Ninewa, and Baghdad, focusing on rehabilitating schools, providing psychosocial support, and training educators to address the needs of displaced and vulnerable populations. These efforts aimed to create safe and inclusive learning environments, facilitating the reintegration of children into formal education systems and promoting community resilience in post-conflict settings

ShortDescription: DEVELOPING A NEW COLLEGE OF EDUCATION AT AUIB
ProjectTitle: Developing a New College of Education at AUIB
LongDescription: This award supports the Developing a New College of Education at AUIB project. Includes readjustment and other benefits for veterans, other than indemnities for death or disability.]

ShortDescription: ACCESSING QUALITY BASIC EDUCATION IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Accessing Quality Basic Education in Iraq
LongDescription: Catholic Relief Services (CRS), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented the "Accessing Quality Basic Education in Iraq" project to enhance educational access and quality for conflict-affected children. Building upon previous initiatives, CRS operated in multiple governorates, including Dohuk, Kirkuk, Ninewa, and Baghdad, focusing on rehabilitating schools, providing psychosocial support, and training educators to address the needs of displaced and vulnerable populations. These efforts aimed to create safe and inclusive learning environments, facilitating the reintegration of children into formal education systems and promoting community resilience in post-conflict settings .

ShortDescription: PROVISION OF EDUCATION, LIVELIHOODS AND INFORMATION, COUNSELLING AND LEGAL ASSISTANCE (ICLA) SUPPORT TO VULNERABLE SYRIAN REFUGEES IN ERBIL AND DOHUK
ProjectTitle: Provision of Education, Livelihoods and Information, Counselling and Legal Assistance (Icla) Support to Vulnerable Syrian Refugees in Erbil and Dohuk Governorates
LongDescription: The Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a comprehensive program in 2018 to support vulnerable Syrian refugees in Erbil and Dohuk governorates. This initiative provided education services, livelihoods support, and Information, Counselling, and Legal Assistance (ICLA) to address critical needs such as legal identity documentation, housing, land, and property rights. In Erbil, the ICLA team exceeded project targets by conducting over 1,200 general information sessions and providing legal counselling to nearly 850 individuals in the first half of the year. In Dohuk, NRC offered school catch-up classes and psychosocial support in six refugee and IDP camps, alongside adolescent girl club activities and summer school enrolments

ShortDescription: GPGF IRAQ 2023-2025 - GPGF  IRAQ 2022-2025
ProjectTitle: GPGF Iraq 2023-2025 - GPGF  Iraq 2022-2025
PurposeName: Decentralisation and support to subnational government
LongDescription: The main aim of the contribution is to support an improved policy, legislation and accountability in Parliament, tackle corruption and improve basic service delivery. This will be done by working with the Parliament, the Committees, Members of Parliament, and the Office of the Speaker to better improve capacity, knowledge, transparency and accountability

ShortDescription: U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE: BUREAU OF NEAR EASTERN AFFAIRS (NEA) - MULTI-SECTOR - UNSPECIFIED: SECURING THE PEACE IN IRAQ THROUGH SUPPORT TO AMERICAN-ST
ProjectTitle: U.S. Department of State: Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs (NEA) - Multi-sector - Unspecified: Securing the Peace in Iraq through Support to American-style Higher Education project
LongDescription: U.S. Department of State: Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs (NEA) - Multi-sector - Unspecified. Economic Support Fund. This award supports the Securing the Peace in Iraq through Support to American-Style Higher Education project.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: WINDOW OF OPPORTUNITY, STRENGTHENING GENDER EQUALITY, CHALLENGING ROLE PERCEPTIONS AND NORMS. FUTURE PERSPECTIVES OF RECONSTRUCTION IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Window of Opportunity, Strengthening Gender Equality, Challenging Role Perceptions and Norms. Future Perspectives of Reconstruction in Iraq
LongDescription: The 2021 German-funded project "Window of Opportunity: Strengthening Gender Equality, Challenging Role Perceptions and Norms" aimed to empower German NGOs and their local partners to implement development projects in Iraq. The initiative focused on promoting women's participation, combating gender-based violence, and enhancing civil society cooperation. It included leadership training for women's organizations, skills development courses for women and girls, and awareness campaigns to prevent gender-based violence. The project also aimed to improve services for survivors of sexual and gender-based violence and at-risk groups by developing and applying a survivor-centered approach
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: PROMOTION OF A PROTECTION ENVIRONMENT THAT STRENGTHENS SYRIAN REFUGEE AND IRAQI RETURNEES, INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS AND HOST COMMUNITY MEMBERS' SE
ProjectTitle: Promotion of A Protection Environment That Strengthens Syrian Refugee and Iraqi Returnees, Internally Displaced Persons and Host Community Members' Se
LongDescription: The Danish Refugee Council (DRC), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a program in 2016 aimed at enhancing the protection environment for Syrian refugees, Iraqi returnees, internally displaced persons (IDPs), and host community members in Iraq. This initiative focused on strengthening self-reliance and access to basic services for these vulnerable populations. DRC's activities included legal assistance, psychosocial support, and community-based protection mechanisms to address the diverse needs arising from displacement and conflict

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN DEMINING - MINE ACTION SUPPORT
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Demining - Mine Action Support
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: In 2016, Germany significantly contributed to humanitarian demining efforts in Iraq, focusing on areas affected by conflict. The German Federal Foreign Office allocated €5 million to the United Nations Mine Action Service (UNMAS) through the Voluntary Trust Fund for Assistance in Mine Action. This funding supported survey and clearance activities to ensure that prioritized locations within retaken areas were free from explosive hazards, facilitating the safe return of displaced populations and the restoration of essential infrastructure .

ShortDescription: UN INTERNATIONAL RESCUE COMMITTEE PROPOSES TO IMPROVE ACCESS TO EDUCATION AND SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL SKILLS-TRAINING IN SAFE ENVIRONMENTS FOR SYRIAN REFUGEE
ProjectTitle: UN International Rescue Committee Proposes to Improve Access to Education and Social/Emotional Skills-Training in Safe Environments for Syrian Refugee
LongDescription: In 2016, the International Rescue Committee (IRC), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented the "Learning in a Healing Classroom" program to support Syrian refugee children in Iraq. This initiative aimed to improve access to education and provide social-emotional skills training in safe environments. The program focused on creating nurturing learning spaces, training educators in trauma-informed teaching practices, and integrating social-emotional learning into the curriculum to help children cope with the effects of displacement and conflict. By fostering resilience and academic development, the IRC sought to enhance the well-being and future prospects of Syrian refugee children in the region.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN MINE AND ORDNANCE DISPOSAL
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian mine and ordnance disposal
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: Comprehensive humanitarian demining measures to support the conflict-affected population through land clearance, hazard awareness, victim welfare and advocacy in Iraq

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE SUPPORT THROUGH ERMS, WASH, AND PROTECTION.
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian assistance support through ERMs, WASH, and protection.
LongDescription: In 2019, the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) supported a comprehensive humanitarian assistance initiative in Iraq, focusing on Emergency Response Mechanisms (ERMs), Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH), and protection services to enhance the economic recovery and resilience of crisis-affected populations. The program aimed to address the immediate needs of internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities by providing access to clean water, improving sanitation facilities, and offering protection services, including psychosocial support and legal assistance. Additionally, the initiative supported livelihood opportunities through cash-for-work programs and vocational training, fostering economic self-reliance and social cohesion among affected communities. These efforts were part of a broader strategy to stabilize post-conflict regions and facilitate sustainable development across multiple governorates in Iraq
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: INTERVENTION FOR MORE DURABLE ASSISTANCE AND DEVELOPMENT (IMDAD)
ProjectTitle: Intervention for More Durable Assistance and Development (IMDAD)
LongDescription: More Sustainable Assistance and Development (IMDAD) by promoting economic recovery, social cohesion and access to quality health care and rehabilitation services, with a focus on the most vulnerable populations in Sinjar, Talafar, Telkief and Hamdaniya.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Emergency Assistance Iraq
LongDescription: In 2016, Germany provided €3.5 million in humanitarian assistance to Iraq, focusing on Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) and healthcare services for displaced populations in Diyala Governorate. This support aimed to alleviate the immediate needs of internally displaced persons (IDPs) and host communities by improving access to clean water, sanitation facilities, and essential health services. The intervention was part of Germany's broader commitment to addressing the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and supporting the resilience of affected communities.

ShortDescription: 2020 CVT IRAQ[AWARDS-  COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS]
ProjectTitle: 2020 CVT Iraq[Awards-  Cooperative Agreements]
LongDescription: Protecting Promoting Community Resilience in Iraq: A Trauma-Informed Approach[Covers awards where the principle purpose of the relationship is the transfer of money, property, services, or anything of value to the state, local government, or other recipient to accomplish a public purpose of support or stimulation authorized by the Federal statute.]

ShortDescription: SUPPORT SOCIAL STABILITY IN IRAQ THROUGH PREVENTING VIOLENT EXTREMISM
ProjectTitle: Support Social Stability in Iraq through Preventing Violent Extremism
LongDescription: This project aims to build institutional capacity at national and sub-national levels to prevent and address violent extremism, enhance community resilience and promote viable pathways to reduce tensions, and improve stability through socio- economic support.

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY GRANT AID IN RESPONSE TO IDPS IN IRAQ AND SYRIAN REFUGEES IN LEBANON AFFECTED BY ISIL<THROUGH ICRC(IRAQ)>
ProjectTitle: Emergency Grant Aid in response to IDPs in Iraq and Syrian Refugees in Lebanon affected by ISIL<through ICRC(Iraq)>
LongDescription: Japan's Emergency Grant Aid in 2014 allocated $2.27 million to support internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq and Syrian refugees in Lebanon, addressing the humanitarian crisis exacerbated by the ISIL offensive. Implemented through the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), the aid focused on providing medical assistance, including the provision of ambulances and support for health facilities, to meet the urgent needs of affected populations. This initiative was part of Japan's broader commitment to support the international community's efforts in addressing the challenges posed by ISIL and assisting those affected by the conflict.

ShortDescription: SERVICE DELIVERY PROJECT (TAQADUM)
ProjectTitle: Service Delivery Project (Taqadum)
PurposeName: Decentralisation and support to subnational government
LongDescription: Taqadum will establish new partnerships with four ministries (Agriculture, Sport and Youth, Housing and Construction, and Labor and Social Affairs) in addition to the three ministries it currently partners with (Health, Education, and Municipalities and Public Works). These partnerships will focus on decentralization of authorities and service delivery improvements in 15 provinces (excluding the Iraq Kurdistan Region). Taqadum will assist in establishment of task forces, conducting assessments, and developing and implementing Intergovernmental Coordination Improvement Plans (ICIP) and Service Delivery Improvement Plans. This work will be accomplished through the facilitation of meetings between provinces and decentralizing ministries, and by building the capacity of local governments. Taqadum will also focus on the three Da'esh-occupied provinces to build their capacity for restoring service delivery following liberation.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS  - HUMANITARIAN COORDINATION - OCHA MULTI YEAR / CRISE EN IRAK - COORDINATION DE L'ASSISTANCE HUMANITAIRE - OCHA PLURIANNUEL
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis  - Humanitarian Coordination - OCHA Multi Year
LongDescription: September 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate as armed clashes between Daesh and government forces drive displacement. Since January 2014, over 3.3 million people have been displaced and an additional 887,000 previously displaced people have returned to their homes that have often been destroyed, making it one of the largest cases of internal displacement in the world. The impending battle to retake Mosul - Iraq's second biggest city - from Daesh could result in over a million more IDPs. Persecution of minority groups is an ongoing concern as well as the protection of women and children who are at an increased risk of (and in some cases targeted for) sexual violence such as rape, as well as child, early and forced marriage. Canada is helping reduce the vulnerability of hundreds of thousands of crisis-affected people, especially women and children, through a broad spectrum of humanitarian assistance activities across Iraq.   GAC's multi-year humanitarian support to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in Iraq is contributing to improved coordination and communication among humanitarian agencies. Project activities include: (1) coordinating activities for humanitarian agencies to ensure a needs-based humanitarian response, (2) developing communication tools and increasing surge capacity for clusters in areas of high humanitarian need, (3) providing effective support to clusters in developing documentation and analysis of data for planning and monitoring, (4) building the capacity of emergency response preparedness, and (5) managing joint funding mechanisms to respond to evolving humanitarian priorities.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - DISABILITY SERVICES FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PEOPLE - 2016 / LA CRISE EN IRAK - SERVICES D'AIDE AUX HANDICAP횋S AUX PERSONNES D횋PLAC횋ES -
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Disability Services for Internally Displaced People - 2016
LongDescription: March 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 3.2 million people from their homes. An estimated 10 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. The capacity of the Government to respond to the basic needs of its citizens has been overwhelmed. In 2016, more people will be displaced by the conflict, while many will remain displaced in camps and host communities. However, there will also be growing numbers of people returning to areas no longer under the control of ISIL who will also need assistance to help restart their lives.   With GAC's support, this project is providing emergency services to Kirkuk, Diyala and Baghdad governorates, which together host more than a million IDPs and present a combined monthly rate of almost 1,000 wounded civilians. This project will: (1) provide emergency physical and functional rehabilitation services to people with functional limitations and caregivers, (2) deliver awareness campaigns regarding the dangers of explosive remnants of war to vulnerable civilians, and (3) ensure the needs of people with disabilities are integrated in humanitarian assistance projects.

ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING CUSTOMARY JUSTICE AND PEACEBUILDING EFFORTS IN AREAS OF RETURN,AND ADVANCING THE CIVIL / RENFORCER LA JUSTICE COUTUMI횊RE, LA CONSOLIDATI
ProjectTitle: Strengthening Customary Justice and Peacebuilding Efforts in Areas of Return,and Advancing the Civil
LongDescription: The expected outcomes include: (1) increased understanding of customary justice systems and housing, land and property dispute resolution among government, humanitarian and peacebuilding actors, (2) improved understanding of housing, land and property, displaced women's housing, land and property rights, collaborative dispute resolution, and advocacy methods among ethno-religious and tribal leaders, and government, humanitarian and peace building actors, and (3) improved understanding of and access to civil documentation and/or housing, land and property rights for returnees in Anbar and Ninewah.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - EMERGENCY HEALTHCARE FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PEOPLE - 2016 / LA CRISE EN IRAK - SOINS DE SANT횋 D'URGENCE POUR LES PERSONNES D횋PLAC횋ES -
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Emergency Healthcare for Internally Displaced People - 2016
LongDescription: March 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 3.2 million people from their homes. An estimated 10 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. The capacity of the Government to respond to the basic needs of its citizens has been overwhelmed. In 2016, more people will be displaced by the conflict, while many will remain displaced in camps and host communities. However, there will also be growing numbers of people returning to areas no longer under the control of ISIL who will also need assistance to help restart their lives.   With GAC's support, this project is providing 90,000 displaced people with comprehensive primary healthcare, including sexual and reproductive health care, mental health care, health promotion, essential medication, and emergency referral systems through static and mobile clinics.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS -  WATER AND LIVELIHOODS FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PEOPLE - 2016 / LA CRISE EN IRAK - EAU ET MOYENS DE SUBSISTANCE POUR LES PERSONNES D횋PLA
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis -  Water and Livelihoods for Internally Displaced People - 2016
LongDescription: March 2016 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 3.2 million people from their homes. An estimated 10 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. The capacity of the Government to respond to the basic needs of its citizens has been overwhelmed. In 2016, more people will be displaced by the conflict, while many will remain displaced in camps and host communities. However, there will also be growing numbers of people returning to areas no longer under the control of ISIL who will also need assistance to help restart their lives.   With GAC's support, this project is providing up to 56,370 vulnerable people with WASH and livelihoods support. This project will: (1) provide water and sanitation assistance to up to 48,060 conflict-affected persons through the rehabilitation of small-scale water infrastructure and the provision of household sanitation facilities, especially for female-headed households, (2) provide basic income generation opportunities and help restore household and business assets for conflict-affected people in areas no longer under the control of ISIL to help restart livelihoods, (3) provide cash distributions to IDPs facing serious protection threats, (4) provide essential items through rapid response one-off cash transfers for newly displaced households, and, (5) provide reliable and accurate information on services and organise IDPs and host communities into community groups.

ShortDescription: INTEGRATED CLEARANCE OF EXPLOSIVE REMNANTS OF WAR IN NINEWAH REGION/횋LIMINATION INT횋GR횋E DES RESTES EXPLOSIFS DE GUERRE DANS LA R횋GION DE NINIVE
ProjectTitle: Integrated Clearance of Explosive Remnants of War in Ninewah Region
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: This project aims to remove dangerous explosive items from communities in Ninewah, Iraq to enhance the security of civilians affected by Daesh.  The goal is to support the protection of internally displaced persons, returning populations and stabilization actors. This is accomplished through the deployment of clearance teams as well as dog teams to detect explosive remnants of war in affected areas.

ShortDescription: SUPPORT FOR THE FUNDING FACILITY FOR STABILIZATION IN IRAQ/DISPOSITIF POUR LE FINANCEMENT DE LA STABILISATION EN IRAK
ProjectTitle: Support for the Funding Facility for Stabilization in Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: The Funding Facility for Stabilization provides the Government of Iraq with a mechanism to address the local population's immediate needs in newly liberated areas from Daesh. The project is designed to address three windows of engagement: (1) light infrastructure rehabilitation, (2) livelihoods support, and (3) capacity support for local governments. Its geographic focus is on cities that have been liberated from Daesh, in particular in the governorates of Ninewah and Anbar.

ShortDescription: SUPPORTING AN INCLUSIVE AND MULTI-SECTORAL RESPONSE TO COVID-19 AND ADDRESSING ITS SOCIO-ECONOMIC IMPACT IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Supporting an Inclusive and Multi-Sectoral Response to COVID-19 and Addressing its Socio-Economic Impact in Iraq
LongDescription: Japan's 2020 initiative, "Supporting an Inclusive and Multi-Sectoral Response to COVID-19 and Addressing its Socio-Economic Impact in Iraq," allocated $2.26 million to UNDP. The project aimed to enhance Iraq's response to the pandemic by providing critical medical equipment, including ventilators, and supporting socio-economic recovery efforts. Key activities included strengthening healthcare infrastructure, promoting social cohesion, and implementing impact assessments to inform post-COVID-19 recovery strategies. The initiative was part of a broader UNDP program supported by Japan, which extended assistance to 29 countries, focusing on human security and sustainable development goals

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: REHABILITATION OF WATER TREATMENT PLANTS AND WATER NETWORKS
ProjectTitle: Rehabilitation of water treatment plants and water networks
LongDescription: The planned project aims to improve the water supply in the areas of Anbar that have been severely damaged by the fight against the Islamic State, in order to restore the livelihoods of the returning families.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - IMPROVEMENT OF WATER SUPPLY
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Improvement of water supply
LongDescription: In 2016, Germany provided humanitarian assistance to improve the freshwater supply for internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq. This support aimed to address the urgent water needs of displaced communities, ensuring access to clean and safe drinking water to prevent waterborne diseases and enhance living conditions. The assistance was part of Germany's broader commitment to humanitarian aid in conflict-affected regions of Iraq.

ShortDescription: REBUILDING COMMUNITIES AND IMPROVING THE WELL-BEING OF WOMEN AND GIRLS IN IRAQ/REB횂TIR DES COMMUNAUT횋S ET AM횋LIORER LE BIEN-횎TRE DES FEMMES ET DES FI
ProjectTitle: Rebuilding Communities and Improving the Well-Being of Women and Girls in Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: The project works at improving the well-being for the most vulnerable women and girls in Iraq. It aims to do so by: creating safe spaces for women and girls to support them in their collective efforts for positive change, supporting meaningful community participation by women, working with men and boys to promote gender equality and positive role models, supporting local women's rights defenders, contributing to an inclusive, women-led accountable Women, Peace and Security agenda. Project activities include: (1) building the capacity of parliamentarians (women and men) towards policy development that strives to improve gender equality (GE) and promote the participation of women in the rebuilding of their communities, (2) providing technical and financial assistance for women's rights organisations (WROs) and groups of women's rights defenders, including, training and coaching in GE, human rights (HR), policy development, network development and livelihoods programming, (3) with the assistance of the WROs, establishing child-friendly women's spaces where women can meet to seek assistance, education, exchange ideas and discuss matters of importance to the rebuilding of their communities, (4) training for community leaders (who are mostly men), as well as men and boys in GE and issues pertaining to women and girls (and in some cases men and boys) in their communities such as HR, sexual and gender-based violence, and sexual and reproductive health and rights, in order to garner support for improved lives of their mothers, sisters and daughters, (5) establishing networks between women, WROs and community leaders to ensure women's voices are heard and that they participate in the rebuilding of their communities, develop and conduct a social media campaign with GE messaging based on the work with community leaders, men, boys, women and girls to champion GE.

ShortDescription: STANDING STRONG: REBUILDING LIVELIHOODS OF DISPLACED POPULATIONS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Standing Strong: Rebuilding Livelihoods of Displaced Populations in Iraq
LongDescription: The "Standing Strong: Rebuilding Livelihoods of Displaced Populations in Iraq" project, implemented by World Relief Corporation with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, aimed to support emergency livelihoods for internally displaced persons (IDPs) and promote economic self-sufficiency for host community members and returnees. Operating in Ninewa and Kirkuk Governorates, the project provided cash-for-work opportunities, agricultural training, and grants for small business rehabilitation. Notably, in Sinjar District, 100 new beekeepers were trained and equipped, while 50 damaged businesses received grants for shop rehabilitation. These efforts contributed to restoring livelihoods and fostering resilience among communities affected by conflict

ShortDescription: WR PROPOSES TO SUPPORT EMERGENCY LIVELIHOODS AND PSYCHOLOGICAL/SOCIAL RECOVERY AND RESILIENCE FOR IRAQI INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS IN NINEWA AND KIR
ProjectTitle: Wr Proposes to Support Emergency Livelihoods and Psychological/Social Recovery and Resilience for Iraqi Internally Displaced Persons in Ninewa and Kir
LongDescription: World Relief Corporation, with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a project in 2016 to support emergency livelihoods and promote psychological and social recovery for internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Ninewa and Kirkuk governorates. The initiative aimed to enhance economic self-sufficiency and resilience among conflict-affected populations by providing vocational training, cash-for-work opportunities, and psychosocial support services. These efforts were designed to address the immediate needs of IDPs while fostering long-term recovery and integration into host communities.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN MINE ACTION AND CLUSTER MUNITION CLEARANCE IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian mine action and cluster munition clearance in Iraq
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: In 2019, Germany continued its significant support for humanitarian mine action in Iraq, focusing on the clearance of explosive remnants of war (ERW) and the provision of risk education to affected communities. The Federal Foreign Office allocated €4 million to enhance the capacity of national mine action organizations, including the Free Field Foundation (3F), through training and technical support. These efforts aimed to facilitate the safe return of displaced populations and enable the use of land for agriculture and development. Additionally, Germany's contributions supported the United Nations Mine Action Service (UNMAS) in conducting surveys, clearance operations, and risk education sessions, thereby improving safety and livelihoods for communities in Ninewa, Anbar, and other affected areas.

ShortDescription: EXPLOSIVE THREAT MITIGATION
ProjectTitle: Explosive Threat Mitigation
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: Access to restore essential services is enabled through the conduction of explosive hazard assessments and surveys. UNMAS (United Nations Mine Action Service) Iraq will enable and coordinate explosive hazard management operations in priority locations depending on assessments and survey. Explosive hazard clearance is conducted by UNMAS. UNMAS will coordinate the deployment of relevant follow-up assets in priority locations depending on initial survey results. Explosive hazards that are safe to move are moved to a designated storage and controlled detonation site, so that the cleared buildings can soon be used by the public again.

ShortDescription: IMPROVEMENT OF WATER SUPPLY AND CASH ASSISTANCE IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Improvement of water supply and cash assistance in Iraq
LongDescription: Germany provided funding in 2019 to enhance water supply and offer cash assistance aimed at facilitating housing solutions for returnees in Iraq. This initiative was part of broader efforts to support displaced populations and host communities, focusing on improving access to clean water, sanitation services, and economic stability through cash-based interventions. The project targeted areas with significant returnee populations, aiming to create sustainable living conditions and promote social cohesion.

ShortDescription: PHYSICAL REHABILITATION MEASURES FOR MINE VICTIMS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Physical Rehabilitation Measures for Mine Victims in Iraq
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: Germany funded the "Physical Rehabilitation Measures for Mine Victims in Iraq" project in 2019, aiming to provide comprehensive support to individuals affected by landmines and explosive remnants of war. The initiative focused on delivering medical care, physical rehabilitation services, and psychosocial support to survivors, facilitating their reintegration into society. Implemented by the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) in collaboration with local partners, the project sought to enhance the quality of life for victims and promote their inclusion in community activities

ShortDescription: 2021 WRO IRAQ  GENDER BASED VIOLENCE  Y1[AWARDS-  COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS]
ProjectTitle: 2021 WRO Iraq  Gender Based Violence  Y1[Awards-  Cooperative Agreements]
LongDescription: Reduce the risk of Gender Based Violence and CP violations through comprehensive MHPSS, economic empowerment, legal assistance and community-based activities that bolster self-resilience and strengthening peaceful coexistence among IDPs, returnees, and host  communities

ShortDescription: SYRIA CRISIS - SUPPORT TO THE 횂??묿O LOST GENERATION횂???INITIATIVE - UNICEF 2014 / CRISE EN SYRIE - APPUI ? L INITIATIVE 횂짬 NON ? UNE G횋N횋RATION PERDUE
ProjectTitle: Syria Crisis - Support to the Lost Generation Initiative - UNICEF 2014
LongDescription: February 2014 - The humanitarian situation in Syria continues to deteriorate as a result of the civil war in the country. The United Nations estimates that more than 130,000 people have been killed, with hundreds of thousands more wounded, due to the violence. Within Syria, some 9.3 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, 6.5 million of whom are internally displaced. In addition, over 2.4 million Syrian refugees are registered and living in host countries in the region. Women and children are particularly vulnerable to the impact of the conflict and host countries are increasingly overstretched by the influx of affected people needing assistance.   UNICEF is one of the partners leading the 창??밡o Lost Generation창???initiative to educate and normalize the lives of conflict-affected children and their families. With DFATD s support, this UNICEF project will benefit more than 613,000 conflict-affected children in Syria, Jordan, Lebanon, Iraq, Turkey and Egypt. Project activities include: (1) providing formal, non-formal and alternative education to 402,274 children, (2) constructing and/or rehabilitating schools, and providing school supplies benefitting 18,000 children, (3) providing support and training to 500 teachers, (4) providing psychological support to 495,810 children and caregivers, (5) providing vocational training and life skills to 13,100 youth, and (6) providing cash assistance to 400 highly vulnerable families.

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY GRANT AID FOR IDPS AND RETURNEES TO LIBERATED AREAS IN IRAQ (THROUGH UNDP)
ProjectTitle: Emergency Grant Aid for IDPs and returnees to liberated areas in Iraq (through UNDP)
LongDescription: Japan's Emergency Grant Aid in 2016 allocated $2 million to support internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees in newly liberated areas of Iraq. Implemented through UNDP, this assistance aimed to provide essential services such as protection, education, livelihood support, shelter improvement, and health services. The initiative focused on facilitating the safe and sustainable return of displaced communities and contributing to the stabilization of the affected regions

ShortDescription: PROVISION OF SAFE AND NURTURING LEARNING ENVIRONMENTS FOR CONFLICT-AFFECTED GIRLS AND BOYS IN IRAQ TO COMPLETE THEIR EDUCATION
ProjectTitle: Provision of Safe and Nurturing Learning Environments for Conflict-Affected Girls and Boys in Iraq to Complete Their Education
LongDescription: Catholic Relief Services (CRS), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a project to provide safe and nurturing learning environments for conflict-affected girls and boys in Iraq. Operating in the Kurdistan Region, Ninewa, and Kirkuk governorates, CRS supported 9,000 children across 26 schools by offering teacher training, student counseling, and upgrading school facilities. These efforts aimed to facilitate access to formal education for displaced Iraqi children and promote their emotional well-being in post-conflict settings

ShortDescription: 2020 JRS IRAQ[AWARDS-  COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS]
ProjectTitle: 2020 JRS Iraq[Awards-  Cooperative Agreements]
LongDescription: Internally Displaced Persons and returnees in Dohuk and Ninewa Governorates have enhanced wellbeing through improved access to quality services

ShortDescription: EXPLOSIVE ORDINANCE RISK EDUCATION IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Explosive Ordinance Risk Education in Iraq
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: To reduce the threats posed to civilian security by at-risk, illicitly proliferated, and indiscriminately used conventional weapons.

ShortDescription: TO STRENGTHEN REFUGEES, INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS, RETURNEES AND HOSTING COMMUNITY, HEREAFTER JOINTLY REFERRED TO AS DISPLACEMENT AFFECTED COMMUNI
ProjectTitle: To Strengthen Refugees, Internally Displaced Persons, Returnees and Hosting Community, Hereafter Jointly Referred to As displacement Affected Communi
LongDescription: The Danish Refugee Council (DRC), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a project to strengthen the resilience of displacement-affected communities in Iraq. Focusing on internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, refugees, and host communities, the initiative aimed to enhance protection, improve access to basic services, and promote sustainable livelihoods. DRC's efforts included legal assistance, psychosocial support, vocational training, and community-based protection mechanisms, addressing the diverse needs arising from displacement and conflict. The project operated across multiple governorates, adapting to the evolving humanitarian context in Iraq .

ShortDescription: INCREASING ACCESS TO PROTECTION, MENTAL HEALTH, PSYCHOSOCIAL SUPPORT AND EDUCATION FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS AND RETURNEE MINORITIES IN DOHUK A
ProjectTitle: Increasing Access to Protection, Mental Health, Psychosocial Support and Education for Internally Displaced Persons and Returnee Minorities in Dohuk and Ninewa Governates in Iraq
LongDescription: Jesuit Refugee Service (JRS) Iraq, supported by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a comprehensive program to enhance the well-being of internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnee minorities in Duhok and Ninewa governorates. Through community centers in Sharya (Duhok), Qaraqosh (Ninewa), and Erbil, JRS provided mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), education services, skills training, and livelihoods support. The program specifically focused on genocide survivors and individuals with acute mental health issues, offering home visits, legal consultations, and community-based activities to foster resilience and social cohesion among affected populations .

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY COUNTRY-SPECIFIC FUNDING - ICRC APPEALS 2013 / FINANCEMENT URGENT VISANT DES PAYS EN PARTICULIER - APPELS DU CICR 2013
ProjectTitle: Emergency Country-Specific Funding - ICRC Appeals 2013
LongDescription: March 2013 - The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) is an impartial, neutral and independent organization that draws its mandate from the 1949 Geneva Conventions and their Additional Protocols of 1977. The ICRC's primary mission is to help protect the lives and dignity of people affected by war and internal violence. The ICRC seeks to provide these affected people with assistance and prevent further suffering by promoting and strengthening international humanitarian law and universal humanitarian principles. With Canada's support, ICRC's emergency operations aims to provide protection and assistance to populations affected by armed conflict and other situations of violence in the following countries: Burma, Central African Republic, Colombia, Democratic Republic of Congo, Iraq, Pakistan, Philippines, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, West Bank & Gaza and Yemen.

ShortDescription: SYRIAN REFUGEES AND IRAQI HOST COMMUNITY CHILDREN AFFECTED BY CONFLICT ACCESS QUALITY EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES IN LEARNING ENVIRONMENTS THAT ARE SAFE
ProjectTitle: Syrian Refugees and Iraqi Host Community Children Affected By Conflict Access Quality Educational Opportunities in Learning Environments That Are Safe
LongDescription: The International Rescue Committee (IRC), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a project to provide quality educational opportunities in safe and nurturing environments for Syrian refugee and Iraqi host community children affected by conflict. Operating in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq, the initiative focused on enhancing access to education, improving learning outcomes, and addressing the psychosocial needs of children through tailored programs and support services. These efforts aimed to mitigate the impact of displacement and conflict on children's education and well-being.

ShortDescription: SUPPORT TO RECONSTRUCTION AND PEACEBUILDING OF LIBERATED CITIES IN IRAQ -PHASE ?
ProjectTitle: Support to Reconstruction and Peacebuilding of Liberated Cities in Iraq -Phase
LongDescription: Japan's 2019 initiative, "Support to Reconstruction and Peacebuilding of Liberated Cities in Iraq – Phase III," allocated $5.4 million to UN-Habitat. This project aimed to enhance the living conditions of returnees and host communities in liberated areas by providing shelter and livelihoods assistance. Key activities included the rehabilitation of severely damaged houses and the construction of low-cost core housing units, which can be incrementally expanded, offering affordable and durable shelter solutions. Additionally, the project focused on vocational training and increased employment opportunities to promote self-reliance among returnees. The initiative was part of Japan's broader commitment to supporting Iraq's reconstruction and development efforts

ShortDescription: COUNTRY BASED POOLED FUNDS - CBPF OCHA (NEW STRATEGY)
ProjectTitle: Country Based Pooled Funds - CBPF OCHA (new strategy)
LongDescription: The CBPFs are an important tool for effective humanitarian response as they prioritize a) quick release of funds, b) NGOs i.e. nimbleness and speed and c)local actors that can access hard to reach areas.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - IMPROVEMENT OF THE SITUATION OF INTERNALLY DISPLACED PEOPLE (IDPS)
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Improvement of the situation of internally displaced people (IDPs)
LongDescription: Germany's 2016 humanitarian assistance project aimed to improve the water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) conditions for internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq. This initiative focused on providing access to clean drinking water, constructing and rehabilitating sanitation facilities, and promoting hygiene practices to reduce the risk of waterborne diseases among vulnerable populations. The project was implemented in various regions hosting IDPs, ensuring that displaced families received essential services to enhance their living conditions and well-being.

ShortDescription: WASH AND PROTECTION ASSISTANCE FOR THE MOST VULNERABLE AND CRITICALLY AFFECTED IDPS, RETURNEES, AND HOST COMMUNITY FAMILIES. - PROTECTION AND SOLUTION
ProjectTitle: WASH and Protection assistance for the most vulnerable and critically affected IDPs, returnees, and host community families. - Protection and Solution
LongDescription: In 2016, the Danish Refugee Council (DRC), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a comprehensive program to provide Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) and protection assistance to the most vulnerable and critically affected internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host community families in Iraq. The initiative focused on improving access to clean water, sanitation facilities, and hygiene promotion, alongside offering legal assistance, psychosocial support, and community-based protection mechanisms. Operating across multiple governorates, including Anbar, Baghdad, Kirkuk, Salah al-Din, Ninewa, and Diyala, the program aimed to address the immediate needs arising from displacement and conflict, while promoting resilience and social cohesion among affected populations
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: IMPROVING HEALTH CARE BY STRENGTHENING HEALTH STRUCTURES IN UNDERSERVED REGIONS OF KIRKUK PROVINCE, IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Improving health care by strengthening health structures in underserved regions of Kirkuk Province, Iraq
LongDescription: Sustainable improvement of basic health care, in particular the continuity of care in sexual and reproductive health (SRH) and mother-child-newborn health (MCNH) by supporting the state health structures of the DoH in Kirkuk, in accordance with the national health plan 2018-2022.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - ASSISTANCE FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS (IDPS)
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Assistance for internally displaced persons (IDPs)
LongDescription: Germany's 2016 humanitarian assistance project aimed to provide comprehensive support to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in the districts of Ninewa, Dohuk, and Kirkuk. This initiative focused on delivering essential services such as food aid, shelter, and medical care, alongside psychological support to help individuals cope with the trauma and stress resulting from displacement. Implemented by organizations like Mission East, the project sought to alleviate the immediate needs of IDPs and facilitate their recovery and integration into host communities .

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: ADDITIONAL CONTRIBUTION (CASH) OF SDC FUNDING TO WFP OPERATIONS IN RESPONSE TO THE SYRIA AND IRAQ CRISES 2015
ProjectTitle: Additional Contribution (Cash) of SDC Funding to WFP Operations in Response to the Syria and Iraq Crises 2015
LongDescription: In 2015, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) allocated CHF 8 million to the World Food Programme (WFP) to address the escalating humanitarian crises in Syria and Iraq. This funding enabled WFP to provide immediate food assistance to vulnerable populations affected by conflict and displacement. The support was part of Switzerland's commitment to the Good Humanitarian Donorship (GHD) principles, ensuring predictable and flexible funding to meet the changing needs in humanitarian emergencies.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: SAFEGUARDING MASS GRAVES AND IDENTIFYING MISSING PERSONS IN LIBERATED AREAS / SAUVEGARDE DES FOSSES COMMUNES ET L'IDENTIFICATION DES PERSONNES DISPARU
ProjectTitle: Safeguarding mass graves and identifying missing persons in liberated areas
LongDescription: This project aims to increase the effectiveness of Iraqi authorities in recovering and safeguarding vulnerable human remains from mass graves in areas of Iraq that have been liberated from Da'esh. It also aims to increase participation among family members, especially women and girls, in the process of locating and identifying their missing relatives.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: CONSTRUCTION OF BASES OF A SURGICAL APPLICATION STRUCTURE FOR THE POPULATION PROTECTION IN THE AUTONOMOUS REGION KURDISTAN
ProjectTitle: Construction of bases of a surgical application structure for the population protection in the autonomous region Kurdistan
LongDescription: The aim of the project is the lasting strengthening of state and civil-social structures in the autonomous region Kurdistan by the support of the population protection authority JCC founded anew with the construction of an urgently required population protection application component. In the first project phase the capacities of the JCC are created for a basic population protection. This encloses on the one hand the equipment with the most necessary, own capacities, here on the other hand also specific training measures are to the mediation of basics.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: SUPPORTING STABILISATION IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Supporting stabilisation in Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: This project covers UK contributions to the UN Development Programme's Funding Facility for Immediate Stabilisation (FFIS) in Iraq. The FFIS strengthens Iraq's ability to deliver basic services to people in areas liberated from Daesh.

ShortDescription: PRIOR-YEAR COMMITMENTS
ProjectTitle: PRIOR-YEAR COMMITMENTS
LongDescription: The UNICEF project titled "Prior-Year Commitments" in Iraq, initiated in 2011, focused on addressing the challenges faced by out-of-school children and enhancing educational access across the country. The project aimed to identify the reasons behind non-attendance, analyze the bottlenecks in education, and provide recommendations to reduce and eliminate the phenomenon of out-of-school children. Collaborating with the Ministries of Education in both central Iraq and the Kurdistan Region, as well as other stakeholders, the project conducted surveys and analyses to gather data and insights. The ultimate objective was to ensure that all children were enrolled in school by 2015, contributing to the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals related to education.

ShortDescription: IMPROVEMENT OF WASH (WATER, SANITATION AND HYGIENE) NEEDS
ProjectTitle: Improvement of WASH (water, sanitation and hygiene) needs
LongDescription: Germany's 2017 humanitarian assistance project aimed to address the water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) needs of internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities in Iraq. Implemented by organizations such as Oxfam GB, the project focused on improving access to clean water, constructing and rehabilitating sanitation facilities, and promoting hygiene practices to reduce the risk of waterborne diseases. The initiative targeted areas with significant displacement, including newly accessible regions, to enhance the living conditions of vulnerable populations

ShortDescription: SHELTER, WATER, SANITATION AND HYGIENE (WASH) AND GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE (GENDER BASED VIOLENCE) SUPPORT FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES AND HOST COMMUNITIES IN TH
ProjectTitle: Shelter, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) and Gender-Based Violence (Gender Based Violence) Support for Syrian Refugees and Host Communities in Th
LongDescription: The Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a project to provide shelter, Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH), and gender-based violence (GBV) support for Syrian refugees and host communities in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. The initiative focused on constructing and rehabilitating shelters, improving access to clean water and sanitation facilities, and establishing GBV prevention and response mechanisms. NRC also conducted awareness campaigns and provided psychosocial support to survivors, aiming to enhance the protection and well-being of vulnerable populations affected by the Syrian conflict.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian emergency assistance
LongDescription: Germany's 2017 humanitarian emergency assistance project aimed to address the urgent water, sanitation, hygiene (WASH), and health needs of internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities in Iraq. Implemented by organizations such as Welthungerhilfe, the project focused on providing access to clean drinking water, constructing and rehabilitating sanitation facilities, distributing hygiene items, and offering health services to reduce the risk of waterborne diseases and improve overall well-being. The initiative targeted areas with significant displacement, including newly accessible regions, to enhance the living conditions of vulnerable populations .

ShortDescription: A VIRTUOUS PRODUCTION CYCLE TO RELAUNCH A CITY AND ITS ECONOMIC FABRIC FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS AND RETURNEES TO THE NINEVEH PLAINS, IRAQ
ProjectTitle: A Virtuous Production Cycle to Relaunch A City and Its Economic Fabric for Internally Displaced Persons and Returnees to the Nineveh Plains, Iraq
LongDescription: AVSI Foundation, with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented the "A Virtuous Production Cycle to Relaunch a City and Its Economic Fabric" project to support the return and reintegration of internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees in the Nineveh Plains, Iraq. Focusing on Qaraqosh (Al-Hamdaniya), the initiative aimed to restore agricultural livelihoods by refurbishing 71 small and medium-sized farms, providing seeds, livestock, and equipment, and establishing a cooperative profit-sharing system managed by the Association of Farmers in Baghdeda. The project also promoted social cohesion through community gardens and life-skills training, directly benefiting over 6,100 individuals and indirectly impacting an additional 10,000 community members

ShortDescription: RECONCILIATION AND CONFLICT PREVENTION IN NINEWAH/R횋CONCILIATION ET LA PR횋VENTION DES CONFLITS ? NINIVE
ProjectTitle: Reconciliation and Conflict Prevention in Ninewah
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: The project aims to reduce and prevent violent conflict in Ninewah by promoting reconciliation. Ninewah is among eastern Mosul cities that were recently liberated from Daesh and are in need of assistance rebuild their communities and stabilize tensions. The project seeks to strengthen the role of leaders and their communities in local conflict management efforts. Activities focus on: (1) enhancing the skills of government, religious, tribal and community leaders, as well as women and youth, to de-escalate and resolve violent disputes, and peacefully manage conflicts affecting their communities, and (2) increasing mutual trust between displaced people and host communities.

ShortDescription: SYRIA CRISIS - PROTECTION AND EMERGENCY RELIEF IN EGYPT AND IRAQ - UNHCR 2014 / CRISE EN SYRIE - SERVICES DE PROTECTION ET ASSISTANCE D URGENCE EN 횋GY
ProjectTitle: Syria Crisis - Protection and Emergency Relief in Egypt and Iraq - UNHCR 2014
LongDescription: February 2014 - The humanitarian situation in Syria continues to deteriorate as a result of the civil war in the country. The United Nations estimates that more than 130,000 people have been killed, with hundreds of thousands more wounded, due to the violence. Within Syria, some 9.3 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, 6.5 million of whom are internally displaced. In addition, over 2.4 million Syrian refugees are registered and living in host countries in the region. Women and children are particularly vulnerable to the impact of the conflict and host countries are increasingly overstretched by the influx of affected people needing assistance.   With the support of DFATD and other donors, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) is assisting 250,000 Syrian refugees in Egypt and 400,000 Syrian refugees in Iraq. Activities include: (1) providing access to asylum, (2) registering refugees to ensure their safety and protection, (3) providing refugees with core relief items, (4) providing refugee households with the items they need to survive changing seasons (cold in winter, drought in summer), (5) providing temporary emergency shelters to all newly-arrived refugees and ensuring Syrians already in camps have appropriate shelters.

ShortDescription: GOVERNANCE STRENGTHENING PROJECT - LEGISLATIVE FUNCTION AND PROCESSES
ProjectTitle: Governance Strengthening Project - Legislative Function and Processes
LongDescription: The USAID Governance Strengthening Project (GSP) in Iraq aimed to enhance the legislative function and processes of the Iraqi Parliament (Council of Representatives) by providing technical assistance, capacity building, and institutional support. Implemented by AECOM International Development, the project focused on developing a parliamentary institute, improving staff recruitment and training, streamlining legislative procedures, and strengthening oversight and public outreach capabilities. Despite initial progress, the project faced significant challenges, including performance issues, inadequate monitoring, and political obstacles, ultimately leading to its termination in November 2011 after $42 million had been spent
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE FOR IDP
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Emergency assistance for IDP
LongDescription: Germany's 2017 humanitarian emergency assistance project aimed to provide urgent support to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in central Iraq. This initiative focused on delivering essential services such as food aid, shelter, medical care, and protection to individuals and families affected by conflict and displacement. Implemented by organizations like Caritas Germany, the project sought to alleviate the immediate needs of IDPs and facilitate their recovery and integration into host communities. The assistance was part of Germany's broader commitment to humanitarian efforts in Iraq during a period of significant displacement and crisis.

ShortDescription: PROTECTING AND PROMOTING COMMUNITY RESILIENCE IN IRAQ: A TRAUMA-INFORMED APPROACH
ProjectTitle: Protecting and Promoting Community Resilience in Iraq: A Trauma-Informed Approach
LongDescription: The Center for Victims of Torture (CVT), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented the "Protecting and Promoting Community Resilience in Iraq: A Trauma-Informed Approach" project to enhance mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS) services for individuals affected by conflict and human rights violations. Operating in the Kurdistan Region and Federal Iraq, CVT collaborated with local partners, including the Jiyan Foundation for Human Rights, to train professionals in interdisciplinary trauma-focused care. The initiative emphasized capacity building, staff wellbeing, and community outreach to address the psychological impacts of torture and violence, aiming to foster resilience and support healing processes within affected communities .

ShortDescription: ASSISTANCE FOR IDPS (INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS)
ProjectTitle: Assistance for IDPs (internally displaced persons)
LongDescription: Germany's 2017 humanitarian assistance project aimed to address the urgent needs of internally displaced persons (IDPs) in central Iraq, focusing on providing essential services such as food aid, shelter, medical care, and protection. Implemented by organizations like Oxfam GB, the initiative sought to alleviate the immediate hardships faced by IDPs and facilitate their recovery and integration into host communities. The project was part of Germany's broader commitment to humanitarian efforts in Iraq during a period of significant displacement and crisis.

ShortDescription: SUPPORT TOWARDS SHELTER AND WATER, SANITATION AND HYGIENE (WASH) NEEDS OF ACUTELY VULNERABLE SYRIAN REFUGEES IN THE KURDISTAN REGION OF IRAQ (KR-I)
ProjectTitle: Support Towards Shelter and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Needs of Acutely Vulnerable Syrian Refugees in The Kurdistan Region of Iraq (Kr-I)
LongDescription: The Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, implemented a project to address the shelter and Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) needs of acutely vulnerable Syrian refugees in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. The initiative focused on improving living conditions in Domiz Refugee Camp by installing water tanks, emergency latrines, and shading structures to protect residents from extreme heat. Additionally, NRC launched an urban shelter pilot project in Dohuk, aiming to provide shelter solutions by upgrading and rehabilitating existing homes and buildings, and implementing targeted cash assistance programs. These efforts sought to alleviate overcrowding in camps and support refugees residing in urban areas

ShortDescription: OPPORTUNITIES  FORAS  PROJECT - TRADE AND INVESTMENT ENABLING ENVIRONMENT
ProjectTitle: Opportunities  Foras  Project - Trade and Investment Enabling Environment
LongDescription: The USAID-funded Iraq Opportunities Project (Foras), launched in 2013 and implemented by ACDI/VOCA in partnership with FHI 360, aimed to improve economic opportunities and create employment for Iraqis, particularly targeting youth, women, internally displaced persons (IDPs), and other vulnerable populations. The project focused on strengthening vocational and skills training service providers, enhancing job-seekers' skills, and ensuring employer engagement at both industrial and local levels. Foras supported entrepreneurs through training, information-sharing, and access to grants for promising start-up ideas. Operating in five key economic hubs—Baghdad, Basra, Karbala, Najaf, and Erbil—the program also utilized internet and mobile technologies, including a web-based portal and mobile registration system, to reach a broader audience and facilitate job matching between employers and job-seekers
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: PRESERVATION OF CULTURAL HERITAGE SITES OF MINORITY COMMUNITIES IN NORTHERN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Preservation of Cultural Heritage Sites of Minority Communities in Northern Iraq
LongDescription: Cultural heritage sites hold historic, artistic, or cultural significance to minority communities in Iraq and were targeted for destruction by ISIS and other terrorist groups. This project involves conservation needs assessments of sites in and around Mosul and the emergency stabilization and conservation of a subset of assessed sites.

ShortDescription: BUREAU OF DEMOCRACY, HUMAN RIGHTS, AND LABOR - RESTORING LIFE
ProjectTitle: Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor - Restoring Life
LongDescription: The "Restoring Life" project, funded by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor (DRL), aimed to promote the social reintegration of marginalized individuals in Iraq by providing access to free and fair legal representation and opportunities to participate in social rehabilitation programs. While specific details about the project's implementation are limited, DRL's initiatives in Iraq have historically focused on supporting civil society organizations, enhancing access to justice, and promoting human rights and labor reforms

ShortDescription: FY 2015 ADDITIONAL FUNDING IN RESPONSE TO IRAQ BEA
ProjectTitle: FY 2015 Additional Funding in Response to Iraq Bea
LongDescription: In 2015, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, expanded its humanitarian operations in Iraq to address the escalating needs of conflict-affected populations.
