The goal was to inform child-centered social protection sector planning, budgeting, and financing, including in humanitarian situations. The project also aimed to increase the percentage of key child-related Sustainable Development Goal indicators monitored through national surveys or administrative data.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - NO LOST GENERATION -  2015 / CRISE EN IRAQ - NON ? UNE G횋N횋RATION PERDUE - 2015
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - No Lost Generation -  2015
LongDescription: March 2015 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced an estimated 2.4 million people from their homes. An estimated 5.2 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. As fighting and human rights violations persist and international efforts remain to free territory controlled by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), the situation is expected to deteriorate and to cause additional displacement.   With DFATD's support, the partner is helping to reduce the vulnerability of internally displaced people affected by the civil unrest in Iraq. Project activities include: (1) providing youth friendly spaces, (2) training an estimated 2,500 youth through life skills and resilience courses, training 100 coaches and 100 youth leaders to serve as mentors and instructors in safe spaces, and (3) reaching 8,000 youth through recreational activities and community events and 16,000 community members through awareness campaign and community impact projects.

ShortDescription: ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS OF ODA PROJECTS혻IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Administrative Costs of ODA Projects in Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: he "Administrative Costs of ODA Projects in Iraq" initiative, implemented in 2016, aimed to cover the facilitation expenses associated with planning, implementing, and resourcing Official Development Assistance (ODA) projects in Iraq. These administrative costs were essential for the effective management and oversight of development programs, ensuring that resources were utilized efficiently and that projects met their objectives. The funding for these administrative expenses was provided by the UK Government, reflecting its commitment to supporting development efforts in Iraq.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - HEALTH CARE ASSISTANCE IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Health care assistance in Iraq
LongDescription: Germany provided health care assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq in 2016, focusing on delivering essential medical services to those affected by the ongoing conflict. This initiative aimed to address the acute health needs of displaced populations, including access to primary health care, medications, and medical supplies. The assistance was part of Germany's broader humanitarian efforts to support vulnerable communities in the region during a period of significant displacement and instability.

ShortDescription: COMPREHENSIVE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT OF CRISIS MANAGEMENT STRUCTURES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Comprehensive Capacity Development of Crisis Management Structures in Iraq
LongDescription: The project contributes to the security sector reform of Iraq. To this end, the project will apply a holistic approach to existing structures and will strengthen the responsible actors in the field of disaster risk management. The establishment of rapid response units will provide the essential operational basis for Iraqi civil protection authorities. The integration of volunteers strengthens civic engagement and increases the overall resilience. The expansion of a logistics supply network through a logistics centre will improve the supply of the population.

ShortDescription: NATIONAL DATABASE FOR CULTURAL HERITAGE PROTECTION IN IRAQ / PHASE II
ProjectTitle: National Database for Cultural Heritage Protection in Iraq / Phase II
LongDescription: Germany funded the "National Database for Cultural Heritage Protection in Iraq – Phase II" project in 2022, aiming to strengthen Iraq's capacity to combat illicit trafficking of cultural artifacts. Implemented by the European Union Advisory Mission in Iraq (EUAM Iraq), the project focused on developing a digital database to identify, trace, and recover stolen or missing Iraqi cultural heritage items. A technical workshop held in December 2022 in Baghdad brought together 30 participants from institutions such as the State Board of Antiquities and Heritage and the Federal Intelligence and Investigations Agency. The database, designed to meet international standards, is planned to be piloted in 2023 and will serve as a law enforcement tool to analyze and interpret large amounts of cultural heritage protection data, aiding in the mapping of criminal networks and focusing investigative efforts on suspects or locations involved in cultural-heritage-related crimes

ShortDescription: PREVENTING REPRISALS AND MITIGATING VIOLENCE IN IRAQ/PR횋VENTION DES REPR횋SAILLES ET  R횋DUCTION DE LA VIOLENCE EN IRAK
ProjectTitle: Preventing Reprisals and Mitigating Violence in Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: This project supports a grassroots movement in the Anbar and Ninewah Governorates in Iraq to prevent retributive violence and protect vulnerable populations. This initiative also establishes community-driven civil-military committees to allow civil society, local authorities and the security sector to address grievances linked with retributive violence. Project activities include: (1) conducting working-sessions for civil society organizations to co-ordinate activities in support to the anti-retribution movement, (2) developing a media campaign in support to the anti-retribution movement, and, (3) establishing civil-military committees to address grievances that could lead to retributive violence.

ShortDescription: SHELTER
ProjectTitle: Shelter
LongDescription: Support for displaced persons and returnees in the Iraqi Governments of Ninewa and Kirkuk in the form of accommodation measures, protection activities and remittances

ShortDescription: MSB IRAQ IDPS UNHCR
ProjectTitle: MSB Iraq IDPs UNHCR
LongDescription: Tents, blankets, expert secondments and materials for emergency shelter/camp intervention in support of Iraqi IDPs

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - EMERGENCY WATER, HYGIENE, AND SANITATION ASSISTANCE  - OXFAM QUEBEC 2015 / CRISE EN IRAK - ASSISTANCE D'URGENCE EN EAU, ASSAINISSEMENT E
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Emergency Water, Hygiene, and Sanitation Assistance  - Oxfam Quebec 2015
LongDescription: February 2015 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced an estimated 2.25 million people from their homes. An estimated 5.2 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. As fighting and human rights violations persist and international efforts remain to free territory controlled by the so-called Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), the situation is expected to deteriorate and to cause additional displacement.   With DFATD's support, Oxfam Quebec is helping to reduce the vulnerability of internally displaced people affected by the civil unrest in Iraq. Project activities include: (1) rehabilitating water sources, (2) conducting community mobilization for better hygiene practices, and (3) distributing emergency relief items.

ShortDescription: WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION CONSOLIDATED GRANT
ProjectTitle: World Health Organization Consolidated Grant
LongDescription: This grant provides support for collaborative activities with USAID and the World Health Organization (WHO) in infectious diseases, maternal and child health, family planning, safe motherhood, reproductive health, environmental health and HIV/AIDS. Specifically, support is provided to WHOs relevant technical and program divisions for technical input and assistance in the development, implementation and/or evaluation of health programs and studies including: 1) Global strategy development, 2) Technical analyses, 3) Demonstration activities and feasibility studies, 4) Capacity building, 5) Policy reform, 6) Project evaluation and assessments, 7) Monitoring and evaluation, 8) Education/information strategies, 9) Maternal and neonatal health, 10) Family Planning and Reproductive Health, 11) Implementing Best Practices in Family Planning, and 11) Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC).
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN SUPPORT TO UNHCR IN UN CONSOLIDATED AND EMERGENCY APPEALS - SUPPORT TO UNHCR UN CONSOLIDATED AND EMERGENCY
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian support to UNHCR in UN Consolidated and Emergency Appeals - Support to UNHCR UN Consolidated and Emergency
LongDescription: Humanitarian support to UNHCRs activities in UN Consolidated and Emergency Appeals 2013. Initial allocation: Mali situation 33 MSEK,Yemen 19 MSEK,Chad 15 MSEK,Somalia 13 MSEK,Kenya 12 MSEK,Syria situation 10 MSEK, Afghanistan 10 MSEK,Colombia 9 MSEK,Iraq 9 MSEK, CAR, 5 MSEK, DRC 5 MSEK, Ethiopia 5 MSEK, Myanmar situation 9 MSEK, SGBV Prevention and protection 5 MSEK/year during 2013-2015.

ShortDescription: ICRC 2014-2015 - HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE IRAQ
ProjectTitle: ICRC 2014-2015 - Humanitarian Assistance Iraq
LongDescription: In 2014, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) significantly expanded its humanitarian efforts in Iraq to address the escalating crisis caused by the armed conflict and the rise of the Islamic State (ISIL). The ICRC's response focused on providing essential aid to internally displaced persons (IDPs) and residents in conflict-affected areas, including Anbar, Baghdad, Kirkuk, and Nineveh governorates. Key interventions included the distribution of food, essential household items, and cash assistance to over 1.5 million people, ensuring access to clean water through repairs to water infrastructure and water trucking, and supporting health services by providing medical supplies and equipment to hospitals and clinics. Additionally, the ICRC engaged in protection activities, such as visiting detainees, clarifying the fate of missing persons, and promoting respect for international humanitarian law among all parties to the conflict. These efforts were carried out in coordination with the Iraqi Red Crescent Society and other humanitarian organizations to maximize the impact of the assistance provided

ShortDescription: UNDP PARLIAMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY - PARTICIPATORY AND ACCOUNTABLE GOVERNANCE IRAQ
ProjectTitle: UNDP Parliament and Civil society - Participatory and Accountable Governance Iraq
LongDescription: UNDP i collaboration with UNOPS carries out a program with the        objectives to strengthen the parliament, in particular female         members, and the secretariat of the parliament as well as the NGO     directorate at the government to establish mechanisms and capacity to work in relation to civil society organisations.

ShortDescription: SUPPORT TO RECONSTRUCTION AND PEACEBUILDING OF LIBERATED CITIES IN IRAQ - PHASE III
ProjectTitle: Support to Reconstruction and Peacebuilding of Liberated Cities in Iraq - Phase III
LongDescription: Japan's contribution to the "Support to Reconstruction and Peacebuilding of Liberated Cities in Iraq - Phase III" project, implemented in 2020, focused on rehabilitating essential infrastructure and enhancing livelihoods in areas affected by conflict. This initiative aimed to facilitate the safe return of displaced populations and promote community resilience through the restoration of housing, provision of vocational training, and support for local economic activities. The project was part of Japan's broader commitment to supporting Iraq's recovery and stabilization efforts.

ShortDescription: EMPOWERING WOMEN TO PARTICIPATE IN IRAQ'S NATIONAL RECONCILIATION PROCESS/AUTONOMISER LES FEMMES POUR PARTICIPER DANS LE PROCESSUS NATIONAL DE R횋CONCI
ProjectTitle: Empowering Women to Participate in Iraq's National Reconciliation Process
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: This project aims to increase access for Iraqi women to decision making processes relating to national reconciliation in liberated areas of Iraq. It seeks to build the capacity of women from Anbar, Ninewah, Kirkuk, and Salahaddin governorates to identify and transform conflict dynamics, solicit women's priorities on how best to achieve reconciliation, and build cross-community alliances aimed at convincing key decision makers of the importance of strengthening the role of women in reconciliation processes. Project activities include: (1) providing financial management training for civil society organizations, (2) delivering conflict identification and transformation, public policy development, and platform development workshops for women activists, (3) conducting outreach activities and community meetings to seek input on local priorities, (4) facilitating meetings for women activists with national-level decision makers, and (5) developing a reconciliation toolkit for use in future advocacy campaigns.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - SUPPORTING CAMP CONSTRUCTION FOR DISPLACED PERSONS IN DOHUK - UNHCR 2014 / CRISE EN IRAK - APPUI ? LA CONSTRUCTION DE CAMPS DE D횋PLAC횋S
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Supporting Camp Construction for Displaced Persons in Dohuk - UNHCR 2014
LongDescription: September 2014 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The recent surge in violence between armed groups and government forces has already displaced an estimated 1.7 million people from their homes and continues to drive displacement. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. Iraqi Kurdistan is also hosting 215,000 Syrian refugees, which is placing a great strain on local infrastructure. The situation is expected to deteriorate as fighting and human rights violations persist.   With DFATD s support, the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) will build camps in Dohuk Governorate in Iraqi Kurdistan for families displaced by the violence in Northern Iraq. Project activities include: (1) preparing the camp sites for construction, (2) building water and sanitation facilities to ensure that people have access to safe drinking water and proper facilities to safely dispose of waste, and (3) building temporary shelters.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - IMPROVEMENT OF THE SITUATION OF IDPS
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Improvement of the situation of IDPs
LongDescription: In 2016, Germany provided €1.9 million in humanitarian assistance to improve the water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) conditions for internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq. This support aimed to address the critical needs of IDPs affected by ongoing conflicts, particularly in the Kurdistan Region. The assistance included repairing and maintaining water networks and sanitation facilities in camps, schools, and host communities, benefiting up to 22,900 individuals. The project was implemented by various partners, including CARE Germany, and was part of Germany's broader efforts to support IDPs and host communities in Iraq during the humanitarian crisis.

ShortDescription: VULNERABILITY OF CONFLICT-AFFECTED ADOLESCENTS (SYRIAN REFUGEES, INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS, AND HOST COMMUNITY) IN SULAYMANIYAH IS REDUCED THROUGH
ProjectTitle: Vulnerability of Conflict-Affected Adolescents (Syrian Refugees, Internally Displaced Persons, and Host Community) in Sulaymaniyah Is Reduced Through
LongDescription: In 2015, Mercy Corps implemented a project in Sulaymaniyah, Iraq, aimed at reducing the vulnerability of conflict-affected adolescents, including Syrian refugees, internally displaced persons (IDPs), and host community members. Funded by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM), the initiative focused on providing psychosocial support, education, and livelihood opportunities to empower youth and enhance their resilience in the face of ongoing displacement and conflict.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - DEPLOYMENT OF EMERGENCY RELIEF ITEMS - CANADIAN RED CROSS 2014 / CRISE EN IRAK - ENVOI DE MAT횋RIEL DE SECOURS D URGENCE - CROIX-ROUGE CA
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Deployment of Emergency Relief Items - Canadian Red Cross 2014
LongDescription: September 2014 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The recent surge in violence between armed groups and government forces has already displaced an estimated 1.7 million people from their homes and continues to drive displacement. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. Iraqi Kurdistan is also hosting 215,000 Syrian refugees, which is placing a great strain on local infrastructure. The situation is expected to deteriorate as fighting and human rights violations persist.   In response to the crisis, DFATD is deploying emergency relief items from its stockpile, managed by the Canadian Red Cross, to meet the immediate needs of approximately 40,000 conflict-affected people. The relief items are being provided to Save the Children Canada and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, who will distribute the items to those who are most in need, in coordination with the Government of Iraq and the wider humanitarian community. The relief items include: (1) tents and tarpaulins to help provide temporary shelter, and (2) basic household items such as blankets, kitchen sets, and hygiene kits (which include items such as soap and toothbrushes), as well as jerry cans and buckets to safely transport water.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS (IDPS)
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Emergency assistance for internally displaced persons (IDPs)
LongDescription: In 2016, Germany provided humanitarian assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq, focusing on emergency relief efforts in response to the escalating displacement crisis. The German government allocated €1 million for multi-year basic relief, including non-food items (NFIs) and fuel vouchers, to support vulnerable IDPs who had fled acute violence in Iraq. Additionally, Germany contributed €1.174 million to the Iraq-Syria Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP), which aimed to address the needs of both refugees and host communities in Iraq.

ShortDescription: FRONTLINE AID RELATED DIPLOMACY TO IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Frontline aid related diplomacy to Iraq
LongDescription: The UK’s "Frontline Aid-Related Diplomacy to Iraq" initiative in 2013 was designed to support the planning, implementation, and oversight of Official Development Assistance (ODA) projects in Iraq. This programme aimed to enhance the effectiveness of aid delivery by covering administrative costs associated with diplomatic and logistical activities. It was part of a broader strategy to assist Iraq in its post-conflict reconstruction and development efforts, ensuring that aid was effectively coordinated and aligned with the country's needs.

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: IRQ OXFAM INTEG WASH PROTECTION DIYALA
ProjectTitle: IRQ Oxfam Integ WASH Protection Diyala
LongDescription: In 2017, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) allocated CHF 2 million to support Oxfam's integrated Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) and protection response in Diyala Governorate, Iraq. This project aimed to reduce water and sanitation-related health risks and enhance access to clean water for internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities in the districts of Kifri and Khanaqin. The initiative also provided vulnerable families with access to protection services, including information on entitlements and available services in return areas, to support informed decision-making regarding displacement. The project reached approximately 60,000 individuals, including an equal number of women, men, and children. Key activities included the rehabilitation and extension of water supply systems, improvement of sanitation facilities, hygiene promotion, and the provision of cash assistance for protection services. Additionally, capacity-building efforts were made with local authorities and community committees to ensure the sustainability of services.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: SPECIAL PROGRAMME FOR THE MIDDLE EAST, PAKISTAN, AFGHANISTAN AND IRAQ, DAAD
ProjectTitle: Special programme for the Middle East, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iraq, DAAD
LongDescription: The measures (e.g. assistance with new study courses, scholarships, training of university staff, conferences, networking activities) shall support academic cooperation with the region Middle East, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iraq. The goal is to use the potential of university cooperation for conflict resolution and prevention by improving university structures as well as individual capacities of partner countries by training and counselling, German Academic Exchange Service

ShortDescription: BASIC MEDICAL CARE
ProjectTitle: Basic medical care
LongDescription: In 2017, Germany, through its development cooperation agency GIZ, supported Médecins du Monde in providing basic medical care to populations affected by conflict in Iraq. The assistance aimed to improve access to essential health services for internally displaced persons (IDPs) and other vulnerable groups, addressing urgent medical needs in areas impacted by ongoing violence and displacement

ShortDescription: NACHHALTIGE VERBESSERUNG DES SCHUTZES VON ZIVILISTEN IM IRAK
ProjectTitle: Sustainable Improvement of Civilian Protection in Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: In 2021, Germany, through its development cooperation agency GIZ, implemented the project "Nachhaltige Verbesserung des Schutzes von Zivilisten im Irak" (Sustainable Improvement of Civilian Protection in Iraq). The initiative aimed to advance and maintain protective measures for civilians at local, national, and international levels. This was achieved by strengthening the capacity of Iraqi institutions to protect civilians, promoting human rights, and enhancing the rule of law. The project also focused on fostering dialogue and cooperation among government bodies, civil society, and international partners to create a comprehensive approach to civilian protection.

ShortDescription: IDENTIFYING OPPORTUNITIES TO BUILD THE RULE OF LAW WITHIN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Identifying Opportunities to build the Rule of Law within Iraq
LongDescription: Understanding current capability gaps in the Iraqi justice and rule of law system, specifically aimed at developing evidence base investigation techniques.

ShortDescription: 2021 IMC IRAQ   PROVISION OF INTEGR[AWARDS-  COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS]
ProjectTitle: 2021 IMC Iraq   Provision of Integr[Awards-  Cooperative Agreements]
LongDescription: In 2021, the International Medical Corps (IMC), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM), provided health and protection services to conflict-affected Syrian refugees in Iraq. This initiative focused on delivering essential healthcare, mental health and psychosocial support, and protection services to vulnerable populations, including women and children, in refugee camps and surrounding communities.

ShortDescription: CONTROL OF COMMUNICABLE DISEASES IN EMEGENCY, IRAQ - SUSTAINING THE ESSENTIALS AND INNOVATING FOR THE FUTURE
ProjectTitle: Control of Communicable Diseases in Emegency, Iraq - Sustaining the Essentials and Innovating for the Future
LongDescription: Japan's Emergency Grant Aid in 2016 supported WHO Iraq with a $1.4 million contribution aimed at enhancing the country's capacity to prevent and control communicable diseases. This funding focused on strengthening health services in conflict-affected areas, particularly in Duhok and Ninewa governorates, where over 600,000 people reside. The assistance facilitated the delivery of primary and secondary healthcare services, including the prevention, early detection, and containment of disease outbreaks in 11 governorates. This initiative was part of Japan's broader commitment to mitigating the impact of ongoing conflict on Iraq's public health system.

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY SUPPORT TO RETURNEES IN IRAQ AFTER THE OUTBREAK OF COVID-19
ProjectTitle: Emergency Support to Returnees in Iraq after the Outbreak of COVID-19
LongDescription: Japan's Emergency Support to Returnees in Iraq after the Outbreak of COVID-19, implemented in 2021, aimed to assist displaced Iraqis returning to their communities amid the pandemic. The project focused on providing essential services such as shelter, health care, and livelihood support to ensure safe and sustainable reintegration. Collaborating with UN-Habitat, the initiative also addressed infrastructure needs, including the rehabilitation of public spaces and facilities to support returning populations.

ShortDescription: UNHCR - HUMANITARIAN APPEALS - UNHCR HUMANITARIAN SUPPORT
ProjectTitle: UNHCR - Humanitarian Appeals - UNHCR Humanitarian Support
LongDescription: The contribution concerns an agreement with UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) for activities in line with UNHCR's Global Appeal, based on a new full appraisal of UNHCR.The implementation period is only one year, since the Global Appeal only covers activities for 2021. Funding beyond 2021 would need project plans and budgets covering a longer period.With its mandate to protect refugees, internally displaced persons, stateless and returnees, including possible resettlement solutions, UNHCR is a key partner within protection. UNHCR has an operational duty to protect people of concern (legal assistance, civil documentation, asylum etc.) and a normative duty as the guardian of the 1951 Refugee Convention. UNHCR is the main actor in all refugee crises, with an overarching coordination responsibility for the humanitarian interventions carried out by the UN and civil society organisations, not the least within the Global Protection Cluster. The organisation also cooperates with national and local authorities.Through the financial support to UNHCR 2021, Sida will contribute to the humanitarian response directed to refugees and internally displaced persons to contribute to protection and basic needs (food, water, sanitation, health care etc.), education, shelter etc. Sida also contributes to strategic coordination within the humanitarian system through UNHCR.Sida s financial support to UNHCR 2021 amounts to a total of 270 MSEK. Sida s decision complements the Swedish Government s core support to the organisation. Sida s support is directed to selected operations and situations included in UNHCR s Global Appeal, including regional refugee response plans. Within the earmarking at country or crisis level, Sida s support is unearmarked.During 2021, the financial support will be directed to the following countries/crises: Bangladesh, Cameroon, Chad, Kenya, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ethiopia, Iraq, Mali, Mozambique, Somalia, Sudan, South Sudan,  the Syria crisis, Uganda, Ukraine and the Venezuela crisis.The decision also includes an unallocated support, which UNHCR can use for new or deteriorating crises during 2021 after approval by Sida.The grant will be disbursed in the beginning of the year to allow UNHCR to plan and implement humanitarian activities (assistance and protection) without delay and with good planning.

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY GRANT AID FOR IRAQ IN RESPONSE TO THE ARMED CONFLICT
ProjectTitle: Emergency Grant Aid for Iraq in response to the armed conflict
LongDescription: Japan's Emergency Grant Aid in 2014 provided critical humanitarian assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq, who were severely affected by the armed conflict between extremist groups and Iraqi security forces. The aid, totaling $6 million, was channeled through international organizations such as the World Food Programme (WFP), the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), and the International Organization for Migration (IOM). This support focused on delivering essential non-food items (NFIs), including shelter materials, hygiene kits, and cooking utensils, to displaced populations in regions like Mosul and Anbar. The assistance aimed to alleviate immediate suffering and provide a foundation for longer-term recovery efforts.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE THROUGH HCIM
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian assistance through HCIM
LongDescription: The Humanitarian Coordination and Information Management (HCIM) project in Iraq, funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), aimed to enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of humanitarian assistance during the complex emergency resulting from the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIS) conflict. Implemented by various partners including the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) and the UN Office for Project Services (UNOPS), the HCIM initiative focused on improving coordination among humanitarian actors, streamlining information sharing, and supporting data-driven decision-making to address the needs of displaced and conflict-affected populations. The project operated across multiple governorates in Iraq, including Anbar, Baghdad, Basrah, Dohuk, Erbil, Kirkuk, Ninewa, Salah al-Din, and others, reflecting its nationwide scope
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: NZ-5. ACCESS TO IMPROVED SANITATION
ProjectTitle: NZ-5. ACCESS TO IMPROVED SANITATION
LongDescription: The UNICEF project titled "NZ-5: Access to Improved Sanitation" in Iraq, initiated in 2011, aimed to enhance sanitation infrastructure and hygiene practices, particularly in underserved rural communities. Collaborating with the Iraqi government, UNICEF focused on rehabilitating and extending water and sewage services to rural areas, benefiting several hundred thousand Iraqis. This initiative was part of a broader effort to improve public health by reducing waterborne diseases and promoting better hygiene standards

ShortDescription: COUNCIL OF REPRESENTATIVES
ProjectTitle: Council of Representatives
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: In 2013, the UK Government supported Iraq's Council of Representatives through various initiatives aimed at strengthening parliamentary functions and promoting democratic governance. These efforts included providing technical assistance, facilitating training programs for parliamentarians and staff, and supporting institutional reforms to enhance legislative effectiveness and accountability. The UK's engagement was part of a broader strategy to assist Iraq in building democratic institutions and promoting good governance following years of conflict and instability.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - EMERGENCY WATER, HYGIENE AND SANITATION ASSISTANCE (2) - 2015 / CRISE EN IRAQ - AIDE D'URGENCE EN EAU, ASSAINISSEMENT ET HYGI횊NE (2) - 2
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Emergency Water, Hygiene and Sanitation Assistance (2) - 2015
LongDescription: March 2015 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 2.4 million people from their homes. An estimated 5.2 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. As fighting and human rights violations persist and international efforts remain to free territory controlled by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), the situation is expected to deteriorate and to cause additional displacement.   With DFATD's support, the partner is helping to reduce the vulnerability of internally displaced people affected by the civil unrest in Iraq. Project activities include: (1) providing emergency cash assistance to 705 of the most vulnerable internally displaced households, (2) providing water storage containers to 60 families, (3) providing materials and technical support to 600 households for the creation of temporary household latrines, (4) delivering hygiene and sanitation educational messages and training to 600 families, (5) providing hand washing facilities to 600 families, and (6) distributing vouchers for essential hygiene items.

ShortDescription: PRM-INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR MIGRATION BAGHDAD INTERNATIONAL COOPERATIVE ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT SERVICES
ProjectTitle: Prm-International Organization for Migration Baghdad International Cooperative Administrative Support Services
LongDescription: The U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM) provided funding to the International Organization for Migration (IOM) in 2017 to support the protection and assistance needs of refugees, migrants, and conflict victims in Iraq. IOM's efforts included humanitarian aid, camp coordination, and information management, focusing on the needs of internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees across various governorates. The main office of IOM in Iraq is located in the UNAMI Compound (Diwan 2), International Zone, Baghdad, Iraq.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - EMERGENCY RESPONSE TO SEXUAL AND GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE - PLAN CANADA 2015 / CRISE EN IRAQ - R횋PONSE D URGENCE ? LA VIOLENCE SEXUELLE ET
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Emergency Response to Sexual and Gender-Based Violence - Plan Canada 2015
LongDescription: December 2014 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced an estimated 2 million people from their homes. An estimated 5.2 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. As fighting and human rights violations persist and international efforts remain to free territory controlled by the so-called Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), the situation is expected to deteriorate and to cause additional displacement.   With DFATD s support, Plan Canada is helping to reduce the vulnerability of internally displaced women and girls affected by the civil unrest in Iraq. Project activities include: (1) establishing women community centres, (2) conducting educational and social activities for women and girl survivors of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV), (3) running SGBV awareness campaigns in displaced communities, and (4) conducting SGBV community outreach activities to reach women and girls in need.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS -- EMERGENCY RELIEF SUPPLIES AND WINTER SHELTERS -- WORLD VISION CANADA 2014 / CRISE EN IRAK - FOURNITURES DE SECOURS ET ABRIS D HIVER D U
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis -- Emergency Relief Supplies and Winter Shelters -- World Vision Canada 2014
LongDescription: September 2014 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate as armed clashes continue to drive displacement. The recent surge in violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced an estimated 1.7 million people from their homes. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. Iraqi Kurdistan is hosting an additional 215,000 Syrian refugees, which is also placing a great strain on local infrastructure. The situation is expected to deteriorate as fighting and human rights violations persist.   With DFATD s support, World Vision is helping to reduce the vulnerability of 410,500 displaced people in Dohuk Governorate in Iraqi Kurdistan. Project activities include: (1) distributing essential non-food relief items, such as blankets, and mattresses and heaters, (2) providing materials, such as tarps, to help people winterize their shelters, and (3) providing unconditional cash grants to help people meet their emergency survival needs, including medicines, clothing and rent.

ShortDescription: INSTITUTIONAL SUPPORT, DAAD
ProjectTitle: institutional support, DAAD
LongDescription: In 2014, the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD) provided institutional support to higher education institutions in Iraq, aiming to enhance academic cooperation and capacity building. This initiative focused on strengthening university structures and individual capacities through various measures such as introducing new study programs, providing scholarships, training university staff, organizing conferences, and facilitating networking activities. The goal was to leverage the potential of university cooperation for conflict resolution and prevention in the region.

ShortDescription: ISLAMIC RELIEF HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE 2017-2019
ProjectTitle: Islamic Relief Humanitarian Assistance 2017-2019
LongDescription: Between 2017 and 2019, Islamic Relief Sweden, in collaboration with Islamic Relief Worldwide, received Swedish funding to implement humanitarian assistance programs in Iraq. These programs aimed to address the urgent needs of internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities affected by ongoing conflicts. Key interventions included the provision of food assistance, non-food items, shelter support, and access to clean water and sanitation facilities. Additionally, the programs focused on enhancing livelihoods through cash-for-work initiatives and providing psychosocial support to vulnerable populations. The funding allowed for a flexible and adaptive response to the evolving humanitarian situation, ensuring timely and effective assistance to those in need

ShortDescription: ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS OF ODA PROJECTS
ProjectTitle: Administrative Costs of ODA Projects
LongDescription: The "Administrative Costs of ODA Projects in Iraq" initiative in 2016 encompassed the facilitation expenses associated with planning, implementing, and resourcing Official Development Assistance (ODA) projects in Iraq. These administrative costs were essential for the effective management and oversight of development programs, ensuring that resources were utilized efficiently and that projects met their objectives. The funding for these administrative expenses was provided by the UK Government, reflecting its commitment to supporting development efforts in Iraq.
Name_of_Donor: United Kingdom, Conflict stability and security fund

ShortDescription: ANTI-CORRUPTION AND INTEGRITY IN ARAB COUNTRIES (ACIAC)
ProjectTitle: Anti-Corruption and Integrity in Arab Countries (ACIAC)
LongDescription: Enhancement of region-wide compliance with the UN Convention against Corruption. Reinforcement of the effectiveness of the public administration. Development of region-wide collective action capacity to achieve Sustainable Development Goal 16.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - FOOD AID FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PEOPLE (IDPS)
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Food aid for internally displaced people (IDPs)
LongDescription: In 2016, Germany provided humanitarian assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq, focusing on food aid to support those affected by ongoing conflicts. This assistance was part of Germany's broader commitment to addressing the needs of displaced populations in the region.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: OPEN ADVISORY FUND FOR SUSTAINABLE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Open Advisory Fund for Sustainable Economic Development, Iraq
LongDescription: Reform measures of the Iraqi government on inclusion and qualification of disadvantaged groups into the labor market and the planning of sustainable public investment are developed and ready for implementation.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE EMERGENCY FOOD AID
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance Emergency food aid
LongDescription: In 2014, Germany provided humanitarian assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq, focusing on food aid to support those affected by ongoing conflicts. This assistance was part of Germany's broader commitment to addressing the needs of displaced populations in the region.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN AID FOR NORTH IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Aid for North Iraq
LongDescription: In 2014, Germany provided humanitarian assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in northern Iraq, focusing on essential supplies such as food, first aid equipment, and blankets. This aid was delivered through various channels, including direct shipments and coordination with international organizations. For instance, on August 8, 2014, four Bundeswehr (German army) Transall transport planes flew relief supplies of medicines, food, and blankets to Erbil, the capital of the autonomous Kurdish region in northern Iraq. The aid was delivered by United Nations (UN) agencies for distribution to civilians who had fled from the radical Islamic units of ISIS in the Sinjar mountains .

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: IMPROVED PROTECTION AND EDUCATION FOR CHILDREN AND YOUTH WITH HEARING DISABILITIES
ProjectTitle: Improved protection and education for children and youth with hearing disabilities
LongDescription: The project seeks to improve the educational situation of children with disabilities. At the same time it aims at increasing the awareness of duty bearers for their specific protection needs in Amman, Iraq.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
ProjectTitle: Technical Assistance
LongDescription: The Support Which Implements Fast Transition 5 (SWIFT 5) project, initiated in 2019 with initial funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM), aimed to enhance the capacity of Iraq's Central Statistical Organization (CSO) to conduct poverty monitoring through the Survey of Well-Being via Instant and Frequent Tracking (SWIFT). This initiative was part of a broader effort to improve data collection and analysis capabilities in Iraq. The CSO's main office is located in the Al-Jadriya district of Baghdad
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - ASSISTANCE FOR IDPS
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Assistance for IDPs
LongDescription: In 2016, Germany, through its development cooperation agency GIZ, supported Mission East in providing assistance and psychological support to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in the districts of Ninive, Dohuk, and Kirkuk. This initiative aimed to address the immediate needs of displaced populations affected by conflict, focusing on delivering essential services and mental health support to enhance their well-being and facilitate their recovery.

ShortDescription: WORK EMPOWERMENT FOR WOMEN IN IRAQ/RENFORCER LE POUVOIR DES FEMMES IRAKIENNES SUR LE MARCH횋 DU TRAVAIL
ProjectTitle: Work Empowerment for Women in Iraq
LongDescription: The project aims to increase protection and access to equitable employment for women in Iraq. Through collaboration with the Iraqi Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs, the Ministry of Justice's Higher Judicial Council, Iraqi law firms, the Iraqi Bar Association, Iraqi trade unions, and local women's community organizations, the project informs women of their rights in the workplace, gives them resources to ensure they are respected, and thereby encourages them to join the workforce.Project activities include: (1) the training of up to 275 women, following which at least 85% will beable to demonstrate knowledge of their rights in the workplace and how to assert them, (2) the establishment of a monitoring and liaison body on gender discrimination and harassment in the workplace. Up to 75 labour court judges and lawyers and up to 120 labour inspectors will be trained for this purpose, and (3) Addressing the social and cultural stigmas inhibiting women's access to work, and providing them with informed narratives that promote the role of Iraqi women in the country's economic revitalization.As a result of this implementation, Iraqi women will be able to enter and remain in the workforce without fear of discrimination or harassment, allowing them to contribute toward Iraq's economic revitalization.

ShortDescription: SPECIAL PROGRAMME FOR THE MIDDLE EAST, PAKISTAN, AFGHANISTAN AND IRAQ, GERMAN ACADEMIC EXCHANGE SERVICE  (DAAD)
ProjectTitle: Special programme for the Middle East, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iraq, German Academic Exchange Service  (DAAD)
LongDescription: The measures of the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD) (e.g. assistance with new study courses, scholarships, training of university staff, conferences, networking activities) shall support academic cooperation with the region Middle East, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iraq. The goal is to use the potential of university cooperation for conflict resolution and prevention by improving university structures as well as individual capacities of partner countries by training and counselling.

ShortDescription: PROTRACTED CASELOAD IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Protracted caseload in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2014, Daesh's expansion across Iraq set ablaze a major humanitarian crisis, compelling the UK to respond to acute needs, and also to join the counter-Daesh global coalition.  Daesh has now been defeated as a territory-holding force, and increasing numbers of people have returned home.  However, the situation is precarious, and complex humanitarian needs remain for many.    From 2019-2022, DFID Iraq will respond to the acute needs of the most vulnerable, address the complex needs of high-risk protracted caseloads, promote responsible transition to national-led efforts, and fund enabling activities crucial to achieving this.   The funding envelope for this programme reflects that DFID Iraq is planning for the best, but preparing for the worst a seemingly optimistic trajectory one month may belie a precarious situation the next.  DFID Iraq will monitor any deterioration, setting trigger points to indicate if or when we will approach ministers for any critical change in approach.
Name_of_Donor: United Kingdom, Department for International Development

ShortDescription: PPRC: FY 2017 SYRIA HUMANITARIAN RESPONSE
ProjectTitle: Pprc: FY 2017 Syria Humanitarian Response
LongDescription: The U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM) allocated funding in 2017 to the International Organization for Migration (IOM) to support the Syria Humanitarian Response. IOM's efforts included providing emergency assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) and host communities in Syria, as well as facilitating the resettlement of Syrian refugees from neighboring countries, including Iraq. In Iraq, IOM's activities encompassed health awareness sessions in Ninewa and Dohuk governorates, and the rehabilitation of schools in Sulaymaniyah, Dohuk, and Erbil governorates

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN COORDINATION
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Coordination
LongDescription: In 2020, the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM) provided funding to the International Organization for Migration (IOM) to strengthen humanitarian coordination and advocacy efforts in Iraq. This initiative aimed to enhance the effectiveness of the humanitarian response by improving coordination among various actors and advocating for the needs of affected populations. The project supported activities in multiple governorates, including Ninewa, Diyala, and Salah al-Din, focusing on areas with significant humanitarian needs.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: CRS PROPOSES TO CONTINUE IMPROVING EDUCATION AND PROTECTION FOR DISPLACED CHILDREN IN IRAQ THROUGH QUALITY LEARNING AND PSYCHOSOCIAL SUPPORT IN DOHUK
ProjectTitle: Crs Proposes to Continue Improving Education and Protection for Displaced Children in Iraq Through Quality Learning and Psychosocial Support in Dohuk
LongDescription: Catholic Relief Services (CRS), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM), continued its efforts in 2016 to improve education and protection for displaced children in Iraq. In Dohuk, CRS operated child support centers that provided safe spaces for children affected by displacement. These centers offered structured activities, psychosocial support, and educational services, aiming to help children cope with trauma and reintegrate into formal education systems. CRS's initiatives in Dohuk were part of a broader strategy to address the needs of displaced populations in northern Iraq.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE WASH
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance WASH
LongDescription: In 2015, Germany, through its development cooperation agency GIZ, supported humanitarian efforts to improve water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) conditions for internally displaced persons (IDPs) in northern Iraq. This assistance aimed to address the urgent needs of displaced populations affected by ongoing conflicts, particularly in the Kurdistan Region. The initiative focused on enhancing access to clean drinking water and improving sanitation facilities to prevent the spread of waterborne diseases and ensure the well-being of vulnerable communities.

ShortDescription: ASIA AND MIDDLE EAST ECONOMIC GROWTH BEST PRACTICES (AMEG) PROJECT - FISCAL POLICY
ProjectTitle: Asia and Middle East Economic Growth Best Practices (AMEG) Project - Fiscal policy
LongDescription: The Asia and Middle East Economic Growth Best Practices project (AMEG) supports USAID bureaus and missions in Asia, the Middle East, and North Africa with activities such as assessments, strategic planning, diagnostics, and innovative pilot programs. The project focuses on a variety of key issues around economic growth and job creation: public financial management, trade and customs, access to finance, small and medium enterprise development, workforce development, and sustainable livelihoods, particularly for youth and women.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: HEALTH AND IMMUNIZATION RESPONSE SUPPORT (UNICEF POLIO, EPI GRANT)
ProjectTitle: Health and Immunization Response Support (UNICEF Polio, EPI Grant)
LongDescription: To implement activities designed to improve polio eradication efforts and routine immunization. Other MCH activities, e.g., Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI), micronutrient fortification and supplementation programs (specifically iodine and vitamin A) are supported under a separate agreement. Services Provided: This grant funds activities implemented through UNICEFs country, regional and headquarter offices in support of a wide range of MCH interventions. Country-specific proposals are needed to define the activities to be conducted in support of national programs and USAID mission strategic plans. In general, activities can focus on improving service delivery, planning and training, monitoring and evaluation, advocacy and communications, limited equipment procurement (e.g., cold chain) and policy development.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: ACF WASH NINEWA
ProjectTitle: ACF WASH Ninewa
LongDescription: In 2018, Action Against Hunger (ACF), supported by the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC), implemented a Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) project in Ninewa Governorate, Iraq. The initiative aimed to address the urgent need for water in Mosul city and surrounding areas, which had been severely affected by conflict. ACF's efforts included rehabilitating water supply systems, improving sanitation facilities, and promoting hygiene practices among displaced populations and host communities. The project reached thousands of individuals, contributing to the restoration of essential services and the improvement of public health in the region.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN INFORMATION AND COORDINATION MANAGEMENT
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Information and Coordination Management
LongDescription: The Humanitarian Coordination and Information Management (HCIM) project in Iraq, funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) in 2018, aimed to enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of humanitarian assistance during the complex emergency resulting from the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIS) conflict. Implemented by various partners, including the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), the HCIM initiative focused on improving coordination among humanitarian actors, streamlining information sharing, and supporting data-driven decision-making to address the needs of displaced and conflict-affected populations. The project operated across multiple governorates in Iraq, including Anbar, Baghdad, Basrah, Dohuk, Erbil, Kirkuk, Ninewa, Salah al-Din, and others, reflecting its nationwide scope.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING THE RESILIENCE OF CONFLICT-AFFECTED PEOPLE AND STABILISING COMMUNITIES BY CREATING RISK-SENSITIVE LIVELIHOODS
ProjectTitle: Strengthening the resilience of conflict-affected people and stabilising communities by creating risk-sensitive livelihoods
LongDescription: Projects of private German NGOs in developing and refugee-relevant countries that meet the content requirements of SIGA are to be funded.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: SUPPORT TO POPULATIONS AFFECTED BY EXPLOSIVE ORDNANCE, IRQ
ProjectTitle: Support to populations affected by explosive ordnance, IRQ
LongDescription: Support to populations affected by explosive ordnance through a comprehensive approach including Clearance, Explosive Ordnance Risk education (EORE) and increased access to and quality of specialized health Services, IRQ. Safe access to mine free land is possible and access to specialised health care granted.

ShortDescription: BUREAU OF DEMOCRACY, HUMAN RIGHTS, AND LABOR - ENERGIZING REFORM IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor - Energizing Reform in Iraq
PurposeName: Decentralisation and support to subnational government
LongDescription: The Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor (DRL) initiated the "Energizing Reform" project in Iraq in 2021 to bolster citizen engagement in legislative processes. This initiative aimed to deepen political participation, foster dialogue, and enhance the technical and advocacy capacities of marginalized communities, particularly Sunni Muslims in regions like Mosul and Hamdaniyya. Implemented by the Institute for International Law and Human Rights (IILHR), PAX, Ceasefire, and PFO, the project focused on empowering local groups to influence policy by analyzing legal drafts, conducting advocacy campaigns, and facilitating grassroots consultations with lawmakers. The program operated in both Baghdad and Erbil, reflecting its national scope.

ShortDescription: U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE: BUREAU OF NEAR EASTERN AFFAIRS (NEA) - PEACE AND SECURITY - GENERAL: PROMOTING ACCOUNTABILITY IN IRAQ FOR CRIMES AGAINS
ProjectTitle: U.S. Department of State: Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs (NEA) - Peace and Security - General: Promoting Accountability in Iraq for Crimes Agains
LongDescription: In 2020, the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs (NEA) allocated funding to support the "Promoting Accountability in Iraq for Genocide, Crimes Against Humanity, and War Crimes" initiative. This project aimed to enhance Iraq's capacity to investigate and prosecute atrocity crimes committed by ISIS, including genocide, war crimes, and crimes against humanity. The initiative focused on strengthening the Iraqi judiciary, improving legal frameworks, and providing technical assistance to ensure accountability for perpetrators of these crimes. It also supported the United Nations Investigative Team to Promote Accountability for Crimes Committed by Daesh (UNITAD) in its efforts to collect and preserve evidence for use in prosecutions.

ShortDescription: EXPORT CONTROL AND RELATED BORDER SECURITY ASSISTANCE, UNSPECIFIED
ProjectTitle: Export Control and Related Border Security Assistance, Unspecified
LongDescription: In 2019, the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of International Security and Nonproliferation allocated funding to support the Export Control and Related Border Security (EXBS) program in Iraq. This initiative aimed to enhance Iraq's capabilities in preventing the illicit trade of weapons of mass destruction (WMD), dual-use technologies, and other sensitive materials. The program provided technical assistance, training, and equipment to Iraqi border security agencies to strengthen their enforcement and compliance with international export control regimes. A notable component of this effort was the $5 million airport security program launched in 2019, which focused on improving security measures at key airports in Iraq, including Basrah International Airport and Erbil International Airport. This program aimed to bolster Iraq's capacity to detect and prevent the illicit movement of sensitive materials through its air borders.

ShortDescription: OXFAM GB - HUMANITARIAN SUPPORT 2018-2021 - OXFAM - HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE 2018-2020
ProjectTitle: Oxfam GB - Humanitarian Support 2018-2021 - Oxfam - Humanitarian Assistance 2018-2020
LongDescription: This assessment forms the basis for a new three-year agreement between Oxfam GB and Sida to support Oxfam GB's humanitarian programme from 1 April 2018 to 31 March 2021, where additional contributions will be added to the agreement, subject to funds availability, governmental appropriations and Sida needs assessments.In 2018, more than 135 million people will be in need of humanitarian assistance globally to a cost of 22.5 billion dollar, according to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). Sweden's humanitarian assistance is needs-based and Sida each year undertakes a humanitarian allocation process in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected.A number of the identified global needs for 2018 are found in protracted and forgotten crises, and Sida believes that Oxfam GB is well positioned to respond to these needs as the organization is also working with long-term development cooperation. Moreover, Oxfam GB has extensive knowledge of the local context in all proposed projects and capacity building of local actors is central to Oxfam GB's humanitarian work. In 2018-2021, it is therefore suggested that Oxfam GB receives support for emergency lifesaving activities as well as funding for longer-term activities aimed at strengthening societies' resilience to crises and disasters.Oxfam GB has in previous collaborations with Sida demonstrated that the organisation is a professional and efficient humanitarian actor, most recently in the agreements during 2011-2013 and 2014-2017. In 2016 alone, Oxfam GB managed to reach 1.2 million people with humanitarian support in the sector of WASH, 94,000 people with food security and livelihood interventions and 106,000 people with protection assistance in conflict-affected settings. In line with this, Sida believes that Oxfam GB has an added value when it comes to activities of food security and livelihoods, WASH and protection. Moreover, Sida assesses that Oxfam GB's planned projects are relevant in accordance with Sida's Humanitarian Crisis Analyses (HCA) that form the basis for the allocation of a majority of the humanitarian funds for 2018 and contribute to the achievement of the goals of the Strategy for Sweden's humanitarian aid provided through the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida) 2017??020. Sida therefore proposes to support Oxfam GB's humanitarian projects to a cost of 104 MSEK.In 2018-2021, Oxfam GB plans to reach over 280,000 people in Algeria, the Central African Republic, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Iraq and Chad. The contribution will consist of four components focusing on emergency life-saving activities, multi-year resilience building projects, the possibility to respond to sudden onset or deteriorating humanitarian emergencies during the year through the Rapid Response Mechanism, as well as support to method development of cash-based programmi

ShortDescription: SPECIAL PROGRAMME FOR THE MIDDLE EAST, PAKISTAN, AFGHANISTAN AND IRAQ, GERMAN ACADEMIC EXCHANGE SERVICE (DAAD)
ProjectTitle: Special programme for the Middle East, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iraq, German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD)
LongDescription: The measures of the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD) (e.g. assistance with new study courses, scholarships, training of university staff, conferences, networking activities) shall support academic cooperation with the region Middle East, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iraq. The goal is to use the potential of university cooperation for conflict resolution and prevention by improving university structures as well as individual capacities of partner countries by training and counselling.

ShortDescription: SUPPORT FOR SURVIVORS OF VIOLENCE IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: support for survivors of violence in Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: In 2014, Germany initiated a comprehensive program to support survivors of violence in Iraq, focusing on mental health recovery and the restoration of peaceful social cohabitation. This initiative was particularly aimed at Yazidi women and girls who had suffered under ISIS captivity. A notable component was the Special Quota Project, launched by the German state of Baden-Württemberg, which facilitated the relocation of 1,100 women and children to Germany for trauma-informed care and rehabilitation. The program provided psychological support, medical care, and social integration services, aiming to rebuild the lives of survivors and promote reconciliation

ShortDescription: RETURN AND REINTERGRATION ASSISTANCE TO VULNERABLE MIGRANTS AND IDPS
ProjectTitle: Return and reintergration assistance to vulnerable migrants and IDPs
PurposeName: Facilitation of orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobili
LongDescription: In 2022, the International Organization for Migration (IOM) Iraq implemented a comprehensive programme to support the return and reintegration of vulnerable migrants and internally displaced persons (IDPs). This initiative provided a range of services, including reception assistance, legal documentation, psychosocial support, and financial aid, to facilitate the safe and voluntary return of individuals to their communities. The programme aimed to address the complex needs of returnees, promoting sustainable reintegration and community cohesion. By the end of 2022, over 4.8 million people had returned to their areas of origin, with IOM playing a key role in supporting this process through its Assisted Voluntary Return and Reintegration (AVRR) programme.
Name_of_Donor: United Kingdom, Conflict stability and security fund

AgencyName: Royal Canadian Mounted Police of Canada
ShortDescription: IRAQ - MINISTERIAL LIAISON TEAM/PARTNER FORCE DEVELOPMENT TEAM/TASK FORCE CARABINIERI TRAINING MISSION
ProjectTitle: Iraq - Ministerial Liaison Team/Partner Force Development Team
LongDescription: Canadian police are currently deployed into the military structures of the Global Coalition Against Daesh. These deployments contribute to the Government of Canada's approach to the ongoing crisis in Iraq and Syria. By providing targeted support for a transition to a civilian policing model in liberated areas, the Canadian Police Arrangement will contribute to the Government of Canada's goal of promoting stabilization, recovery and development in Iraq.The Ministerial Liaison Team officer conducts high level engagements with officials in key leadership roles, disseminates and promotes various models of policing, and provides advice concerning the development of security sector reform strategies.Canadian police officers participated in the Partner Force Development Team where they oversaw the disbursement of Iraq Training and Equipment Funds.Officers deployed to the Task Force Carabinieri Training Mission provide training and instruction at the Italian-led training camp located within the  Iraqi National Police Academy.
Name_of_Donor: Canada, Royal Canadian Mounted Police of Canada

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY COUNTRY-SPECIFIC FUNDING - ICRC APPEALS 2014 / FINANCEMENT URGENT VISANT DES PAYS EN PARTICULIER - APPELS DU CICR 2014
ProjectTitle: Emergency Country-Specific Funding - ICRC Appeals 2014
LongDescription: The International Committee of the Red Cross s (ICRC) primary mission is to help protect the lives and dignity of people affected by war and internal violence. The ICRC provides these affected people with assistance and prevents further suffering by promoting and strengthening international humanitarian law and universal humanitarian principles.   With DFATD s support, ICRC s emergency operations aim to provide protection, food assistance, health services, livelihood support, and other essential services to populations affected by armed conflict and other situations of violence. This funding supports specific country emergency appeals.

ShortDescription: CATALYTIC CLIMATE ACTION IN IRAQ: NDC, ENERGY, WATER AND DROUGHT MANAGEMENT
ProjectTitle: Catalytic Climate Action in Iraq: NDC, Energy, Water and Drought Management
LongDescription: This programme seeks to catalyse climate action in Iraq by supporting activities to increase climate ambition.  Iraq ratified the Paris Agreement on January 14, 2021. In October 2021, the Government of Iraq (GoI) signed their first National Determined Contribution (NDC), which will be presented at COP26. The GoI has asked for support to deliver climate mitigation and adaptation objectives. This programme will support the GOI transition to a low-carbon and climate-resilient economy. Iraq is highly dependent on oil, accounting for 90% of revenue and 37% of GDP. Iraq is exposed to declining oil demand and climate impacts, including water shortages, desertification and emissions, compounded by rapid population growth.
Name_of_Donor: United Kingdom, Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office

ShortDescription: CVT PROPOSES TO ADDRESS THE TRAUMA AND REHABILITATION NEEDS OF IRAQI TORTURE, SGBV, AND WAR TRAUMA SURVIVORS IN THE KURDISTAN REGION OF IRAQ BY BUILDI
ProjectTitle: Cvt Proposes to Address the Trauma and Rehabilitation Needs of Iraqi Torture, Sgbv, and War Trauma Survivors in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq By Buildi
LongDescription: In 2016, the Center for Victims of Torture (CVT), with funding from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, initiated a project in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq to address the trauma and rehabilitation needs of survivors of torture, sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV), and war-related trauma. This project aimed to provide comprehensive mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS) services, including trauma-focused therapy, physiotherapy, and social services, to individuals and families affected by human rights violations and violent conflict. CVT collaborated with local partners in both the Kurdistan Region and Federal Iraq to build local capacity and ensure the sustainability of these services. The project also engaged in advocacy efforts to strengthen human rights and justice for survivors

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - RELIEF FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Relief for Syrian refugees
LongDescription: In 2016, Germany provided humanitarian assistance to Syrian refugees, internally displaced persons (IDPs), and host communities in northern Iraq. This support was channeled through various partners, including ACT Alliance and Diakonie Emergency Aid. The assistance focused on delivering emergency aid to these vulnerable populations in northern Iraq.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE HEALTH CARE
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance health care
LongDescription: In 2015, Germany, through its development cooperation agency GIZ, initiated a project aimed at improving healthcare for internally displaced persons (IDPs), refugees, and host communities in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq, specifically in Dohuk Province. This initiative was launched in response to the significant strain on the local health system caused by the influx of displaced populations due to ongoing conflicts.

ShortDescription: DOHUK
ProjectTitle: Dohuk
LongDescription: In 2018, Germany continued its humanitarian efforts in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq, focusing on providing aid to internally displaced persons (IDPs), refugees, and host communities in the Duhok Governorate. This assistance was part of Germany's broader commitment to support populations affected by conflict and displacement in northern Iraq. The aid encompassed various sectors, including health care, education, and infrastructure rehabilitation, aiming to improve the living conditions and resilience of vulnerable communities.

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: WORLD FOOD PROGRAMME (WFP), FOOD ASSISTANCE
ProjectTitle: World Food Programme (WFP), food assistance
LongDescription: In line with the Good Humanitarian Donorship (GHD) principles, Switzerland recognizes the necessity of predictable and flexible funding to respond to changing needs in humanitarian crises. SDC funding to WFP operations allows the World Food Programme (WFP) to respond proactively and to provide immediate food assistance in life-threatening situations and underfunded emergencies.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: FUNDING FACILITY FOR STABILIZATION OF NEWLY LIBERATED AREAS (IRAQ) / FACILIT횋 DE FINANCEMENT POUR LA STABILISATION IMM횋DIAT DES ZONES NOUVELLEMENT LIB
ProjectTitle: Funding Facility for Stabilization of Newly Liberated Areas (Iraq)
LongDescription: To provide support to the Funding Facility for Immediate Stabilization (FFIS) in order to set conditions for stabilization reconstruction of newly liberated areas in Iraq.

ShortDescription: IMPROVING PROTECTION OUTCOMES FOR IRAQI CIVILIANS
ProjectTitle: Improving Protection Outcomes for Iraqi Civilians
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: Improve protection outcomes for Iraqi civilians. We will achieve this goal through the following two objectives (1) The government and armed actors commit themselves to learning and adopting best practices on civilian harm mitigation and adhering to their international law obligations and (2) Civilians are effective agents of their own protection.

ShortDescription: INITIAL CONTRIBUTION TO INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR MIGRATION ACTIVITIES IN IRAQ IN SUPPORT OF SYRIA REGIONAL RESPONSE PLAN 6
ProjectTitle: Initial Contribution To International Organization for Migration Activities in Iraq in Support of Syria Regional Response Plan 6
LongDescription: In 2013, the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration allocated funding to the International Organization for Migration (IOM) to support activities in Iraq under the Syria Regional Response Plan 6. This initiative aimed to address the humanitarian needs of Syrian refugees and displaced persons in Iraq, focusing on sectors such as shelter, water, sanitation, hygiene (WASH), health, and protection. IOM's efforts included the establishment and maintenance of refugee camps, provision of essential services, and coordination with other humanitarian actors to ensure effective response and support to affected populations

AgencyName: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade
ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE FOR IRAQ_WHO
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian assistance for Iraq_WHO
LongDescription: In 2015, the Republic of Korea, through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), provided humanitarian assistance to Iraq in collaboration with the World Health Organization (WHO). This support aimed to strengthen Iraq's health system and improve access to essential health services for vulnerable populations, including internally displaced persons and host communities.
Name_of_Donor: Korea, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

ShortDescription: BUREAU OF DEMOCRACY, HUMAN RIGHTS, AND LABOR - ENGAGING IRAQI YOUTH THROUGH COMEDY
ProjectTitle: Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor - Engaging Iraqi Youth through Comedy
LongDescription: The U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor (DRL) initiated the "Engaging Iraqi Youth through Comedy" project in 2021 to foster political awareness and civic engagement among young Iraqis. This initiative aimed to utilize satire and comedy as tools to address social issues, challenge political apathy, and encourage active participation in democratic processes. The project focused on empowering youth to use humor as a means of expression and advocacy, thereby promoting a more informed and engaged electorate.

AgencyName: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade
ShortDescription: SUPPORT FOR UNHCR`S HUMANITARIAN ACTIVITIES IN IRAQ_UNHCR
ProjectTitle: Support for UNHCR`s humanitarian activities in Iraq_UNHCR
LongDescription: In 2018, the Republic of Korea, through its Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), contributed $1.2 million to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) to support humanitarian activities in Iraq. This funding aimed to assist approximately 1.9 million internally displaced persons (IDPs) and other vulnerable populations affected by ongoing conflicts and instability. The support focused on providing protection, shelter, and essential services to displaced families, facilitating their safe return to their homes, and promoting sustainable reintegration. The contribution underscored Korea's commitment to international humanitarian efforts and its partnership with UNHCR in addressing the needs of displaced communities in Iraq.
Name_of_Donor: Korea, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING COMMUNICABLE DISEASE PREVENTION AND CONTROL SYSTEM FOCUSING ON GOVERNORATES WITH MASSIVE POPULATION DISPLACEMENTS IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Strengthening Communicable Disease Prevention and Control System focusing on governorates with massive population displacements in Iraq
LongDescription: To reduce avoidable morbidity and mortality of people impacted by the crisis and those in need of humanitarian assistance in Iraq

ShortDescription: PROVISION OF INTEGRATED EMERGENCY REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH AND GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE RESPONSE SERVICES TO IDP, RETURNEE AND REFUGEE WOMEN IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Provision of integrated emergency reproductive health and gender-based violence response services to IDP, returnee and refugee women in Iraq
LongDescription: UNFPA aims at providing immediate humanitarian assistance to those returnees, alongside IDPs and refugees

AgencyName: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade
ShortDescription: COVID-19 HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE
ProjectTitle: COVID-19 Humanitarian Assistance
LongDescription: In 2020, the Republic of Korea, through its Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), provided humanitarian assistance to Iraq in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. This support was part of Korea's broader commitment to assist countries affected by the global health crisis. The assistance aimed to strengthen Iraq's capacity to manage and respond to the pandemic, focusing on enhancing healthcare infrastructure and providing essential medical supplies. Specific details of the assistance provided to Iraq in 2020 are not readily available; however, Korea's ongoing support underscores its dedication to international cooperation and the well-being of communities affected by the pandemic.
Name_of_Donor: Korea, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

ShortDescription: BUREAU OF DEMOCRACY, HUMAN RIGHTS, AND LABOR - ENSURING IRAQI CITIZEN ACCESS TO IDENTITY DOCUMENT
ProjectTitle: Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor - Ensuring Iraqi Citizen Access to Identity Document
LongDescription: The U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor (DRL) initiated the "Ensuring Iraqi Citizen Access to Identity Documents" project in 2021 to address the significant barriers faced by internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees in obtaining essential civil documentation. Lack of such documents impedes access to basic services, education, healthcare, and social security benefits, and can lead to restricted freedom of movement, increased risk of arrest and detention, exclusion from restitution and reconstruction programs, and the inability to participate in public affairs. In collaboration with the Iraqi Ministry of Interior and local civil society organizations, the project facilitated mobile missions to IDP camps to issue civil documents without requiring individuals to return to their areas of origin

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: IMPROVED SANITATION IN NORTHERN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Improved Sanitation in Northern Iraq
LongDescription: In 2014, Germany, through its development cooperation agency GIZ, initiated a project aimed at improving sanitation conditions for internally displaced persons (IDPs) and host communities in northern Iraq. This initiative was launched in response to the significant strain on local infrastructure caused by the influx of displaced populations due to ongoing conflicts.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: SPECIAL PROGRAM NEAR AND MIDDLE EAST, PAKISTAN, AFGHANISTAN, IRAQ, DAAD
ProjectTitle: Special program Near and Middle East, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Iraq, DAAD
LongDescription: The measures (e.g. assistance with new study courses, scholarships, training of university staff, conferences, networking activities) shall support academic cooperation with the region Near and Middle East, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iraq. The goal is to use the potential of university cooperation for conflict resolution and prevention by improving university structures as well as individual capacities of partner countries by training and counselling, German Academic Exchange Service
