ShortDescription: EMERGENCY GRANT AID FOR INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS AFFECTED BY THE ARMED CONFLICT IN NORTHERN IRAQ<THROUGH IOM>
ProjectTitle: Emergency Grant Aid for Internally Displaced Persons Affected by the Armed Conflict in Northern Iraq<through IOM>
LongDescription: Japan's Emergency Grant Aid in 2014 provided $6 million through international organizations, including the International Organization for Migration (IOM), to assist internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq affected by the armed conflict. The aid focused on critical sectors such as emergency shelter, food distribution, and health services, aiming to alleviate the immediate suffering of displaced populations and support their basic needs during the crisis.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE FOR THE DISPLACE PEOPLE IN NORTHERN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance for the Displace People in Northern Iraq
LongDescription: In 2014, the Korea International Cooperation Agency (KOICA) initiated a humanitarian assistance project in northern Iraq to support internally displaced persons (IDPs) affected by the escalating conflict with the Islamic State (ISIS). This intervention aimed to address urgent needs in the Kurdistan Region, particularly in governorates such as Erbil, Dohuk, and Sulaymaniyah, which were hosting large numbers of displaced families.

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: DRC: SUPPORTING DISPLACEMENT-AFFECTED COMMUNITIES TO REACH DURABLE SOLUTIONS IN NINEWA AND DIYALA
ProjectTitle: DRC: Supporting displacement-affected communities to reach durable solutions in Ninewa and Diyala
LongDescription: In 2021, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) allocated CHF 3 million to the Danish Refugee Council (DRC) for a multi-year project aimed at supporting displacement-affected communities in Ninewa and Diyala governorates, Iraq. The initiative focused on facilitating durable solutions for internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees by addressing key protection issues, such as lack of access to civil legal documents, and enhancing access to essential services. The project also aimed to achieve durable solutions through capacity building and advocacy, with a goal of handing over responsibilities to national agencies.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: PROTRACTED RELIEF AND RECOVERY OPERATIONS 200987. TECH-FOR-FOOD PROJECT
ProjectTitle: Protracted Relief and Recovery Operations 200987. Tech-for-Food Project
LongDescription: World Food Programme Iraq will launch a Transitionary Interim Paper in January 2018 to allow time for the preparation of the National Strategic Hunger Review which will inform the development of a full Country Strategic Plan for Iraq. The operation is currently undergoing review by executive management and it is expected to be approved in the next few weeks.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES IN THE KURDISH REGION OF IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Emergency Assistance For Syrian Refugees in the Kurdish region of Iraq
LongDescription: The challenges posed by the Syrian crisis had its impact in Iraq regarding immediate humanitarian needs for Syrian refugees. Currently, there are more than 150,000 Syrian refugees registered in Iraq. RRP 5 expects that the number of refugees in Iraq will reach 350,000 by end of 2013. This project aims at assisting extremely vulnerable Syrian refugees and affected host communities in the Kurdish region of Iraq through emergency.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

AgencyName: Department for Culture, Media and Sports
ShortDescription: IRAQ EMERGENCY HERITAGE MANAGEMENT TRAINING SCHEME
ProjectTitle: Iraq Emergency Heritage Management Training Scheme
LongDescription: The Iraq Emergency Heritage Management Training Scheme, initiated by the British Museum in 2015, aimed to bolster Iraq's archaeological capabilities in response to the widespread destruction of cultural heritage sites by Daesh (ISIS). In 2017, the programme continued its mission by training Iraqi archaeologists in advanced excavation and data retrieval techniques. Participants underwent a comprehensive six-month training cycle: two to three months at the British Museum in London, followed by a similar duration at field sites in Iraq. The training encompassed modern archaeological methodologies, including geophysical surveying, photogrammetry, and drone-assisted documentation, equipping professionals with the skills necessary to document and stabilize damaged heritage sites for potential reconstruction.
Name_of_Donor: United Kingdom, Department for Culture, Media and Sports

ShortDescription: GOAL PROPOSES TO CREATE MARKET-DRIVEN LIVELIHOOD OPPORTUNITIES FOR VULNERABLE INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS BY COMBINING SKILL DEVELOPMENT BACKED BY FI
ProjectTitle: Goal Proposes to Create Market-Driven Livelihood Opportunities for Vulnerable Internally Displaced Persons By Combining Skill Development Backed By Fi
LongDescription: In 2016, GOAL, an international humanitarian organization, launched a project in Iraq aimed at creating market-driven livelihood opportunities for vulnerable internally displaced persons (IDPs). This initiative combined skill development with financial inclusion to enhance economic resilience among displaced populations and host communities. The program focused on providing vocational training, facilitating access to microfinance, and promoting small-scale entrepreneurship, thereby enabling participants to rebuild their livelihoods and contribute to local economic recovery.

ShortDescription: SUPPORT TO 10/10 ELECTIONS ??OPERATIONAL SUPPORT TO UNAMI
ProjectTitle: Support to 10/10 Elections Operational Support to UNAMI
LongDescription: The "Support to 10/10 Elections" project was a collaborative initiative between Germany and the United Nations to assist Iraq in conducting its parliamentary elections on October 10, 2021. Germany provided funding to support the deployment of UN electoral monitors, as outlined in UN Security Council Resolution 2576 of 2021. The project involved mobilizing 157 international personnel, including 121 short-term experts, and 529 national support staff for United Nations monitoring. Additionally, 166 local observers from two civil society organizations were deployed on election day. The mission's activities included providing security training to UN experts, visiting polling stations, and conducting a strategic messaging campaign to educate and inform Iraqi voters about election preparations. The expected outcomes were increased public trust in the electoral process and improved participation across gender and communities in electoral and political processes. The project concluded in April 2022.

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: IRQ NRC INFORMATION ,COUNS,LEGAL ASSIST
ProjectTitle: IRQ NRC Information ,Couns,Legal Assist
LongDescription: In 2018, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) allocated CHF 3 million to support the Norwegian Refugee Council’s (NRC) Information, Counselling, and Legal Assistance (ICLA) program in Iraq. This initiative aimed to address the legal challenges faced by internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees, particularly those from areas formerly controlled by ISIS. A significant focus was on assisting individuals in obtaining civil documentation, such as birth certificates and national ID cards, which are essential for accessing services like education, healthcare, and legal employment. The NRC's efforts were pivotal in helping thousands of individuals reclaim their legal identity and rights, thereby facilitating their reintegration into Iraqi society.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE FOR IDPS (INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS)
ProjectTitle: Emergency assistance for IDPs (internally displaced persons)
LongDescription: Germany provided humanitarian assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq in 2017 through various initiatives aimed at addressing urgent needs in central Iraq. The German government allocated funds to support the International Organization for Migration (IOM) in its emergency operations, including the provision of winter assistance to vulnerable displaced families. This support enabled IOM to distribute essential items such as blankets, carpets, hygiene kits, and rechargeable lights to help IDPs cope with harsh winter conditions. Additionally, Germany's contribution facilitated the rehabilitation of residential areas affected by conflict and supported the restoration of basic services like water and electricity in retaken areas. The assistance also extended to mental health and psychosocial support services for IDPs, aiming to address the psychological impact of displacement.

ShortDescription: SUPPORTING HUMANITARIAN COORDINATION
ProjectTitle: Supporting humanitarian coordination
LongDescription: Germany's support to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in Iraq in 2017 focused on enhancing humanitarian coordination and advocacy efforts. This assistance aimed to strengthen the resilience of vulnerable populations in selected communities, particularly in Ninewa Governorate. The project involved providing appropriate technical and health conditions for the storage of food and relief supplies, ensuring effective distribution and support to those in need. By contributing to the operational capacity of OCHA's regional office, Germany played a vital role in facilitating coordinated humanitarian responses and promoting effective advocacy for affected communities.

ShortDescription: AWARD TO PROVIDE HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE IN IRAQ.
ProjectTitle: Award To Provide Humanitarian Assistance In Iraq.
LongDescription: The U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM) provided funding in 2021 to support humanitarian assistance in Iraq. This initiative aimed to address the ongoing needs of vulnerable populations, including internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities, by providing essential services such as shelter, healthcare, and protection. The assistance was delivered through various partners, including international organizations and non-governmental organizations, to ensure a coordinated and effective response to the humanitarian crisis in Iraq.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: SELF-RESILIENCE AND EMPOWERMENT THROUGH INTEGRATED CP, GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE, MHPSS PROJECT IN NINEWA, DOHUK, AND ERBIL GOVERNORATES OF IRAQ - PHASE I
ProjectTitle: Self-Resilience and Empowerment Through Integrated Cp, Gender-Based Violence, Mhpss Project in Ninewa, Dohuk, and Erbil Governorates of Iraq - Phase III
LongDescription: The Women Rehabilitation Organization (WRO) implemented the "Self-Resilience and Empowerment through Integrated CP, GBV, MHPSS, Livelihoods Project" in Ninewa, Dohuk, and Erbil Governorates during 2019 and 2020. This initiative, supported by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (BPRM), aimed to reduce the risk of gender-based violence (GBV) and child protection (CP) violations through comprehensive services. The project provided mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), legal assistance, and community-based activities to bolster self-resilience and promote peaceful coexistence among internally displaced persons (IDPs), returnees, and host communities

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE - COUNTRY-LEVEL FUNDING - UNHCR 2014 / ASSISTANCE D URGENCE - FINANCEMENT DANS DES PAYS SP횋CIFIQUES - HCR 2014
ProjectTitle: Emergency Assistance - Country-Level Funding - UNHCR 2014
LongDescription: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) leads and coordinates international action to protect refugees and resolve refugee problems worldwide, protect internally displaced persons and those who are stateless, and search for lasting solutions to their plight.   With the support of DFATD and other donors, this project provides assistance and protection to people of concern in 14 countries. Project activities include: (1) providing shelter, clothing and other essential non-food items, (2) providing adequate water, sanitation, and health services, (3) providing opportunities for education and livelihoods support, (4) working with governments to register asylum seekers and refugees and help issue identity documents, (5) working with governments to support refugee self-reliance and forge peaceful relations between refugees and local citizens, and (6) expanding opportunities for durable solutions for people of concern.

ShortDescription: INCREASING THE SAFETY AND SECURITY OF VULNERABLE CAMP RESIDENTS IN THE KURDISTAN REGION OF IRAQ / L'AUGMENTATION DE LA SURET횋 ET LA S횋CURIT횋 DES R횋SID
ProjectTitle: Increasing the Safety and Security of Vulnerable Camp Residents in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq
LongDescription: Upgrade key infrastructure in IDP and refugee camps to increase the safety and security of vulnerable camp residents, especially women, boys, and girls.

ShortDescription: WORLD BANK -IRAQ REFORM AND RECONSTRUCTION FUND - IRAQ REFORM AND RECONSTRUCTION FUND 2022-2027
ProjectTitle: World Bank -Iraq Reform and Reconstruction Fund - Iraq Reform and Reconstruction Fund 2022-2027
LongDescription: The World Bank s Iraq Reform, Recovery and Reconstruction Fund (I3RF) aims to create a platform for coordinated funding and dialogue for the reconstruction and development of Iraq, with focus on improving the effectiveness of public investment in socio-economic recovery, reconstruction, supporting national reform efforts for economic diversification and private sector growth. After years of armed conflict, the need for funding for the recovery and reconstruction of Iraq is big. In total, the cost of recovery and reconstruction is estimated at $ 88 billion.The Iraqi government has developed a Recovery, Reconstruction and Development Plan (RRDP), which includes the establishment of a Multi Donor Trust Fund (MTDF). Its aim is to effectively co-finance international partners to support effective investment, facilitate dialogue, share information and coordinate Iraq s reform program, which forms the basis of the I3RF, whose objectives, structure and scope are closely aligned with the RRDP.The work takes place in close contact with the Iraqi government, donors and INGOs. I3RF s activities will be carried out by the Iraqi government, organizations, and VB to enable maximum response to reforms and reconstruction needs and to ensure national political ownership. To ensure that there is also a sense and will for ownership within the framework of the fund s results, the I3RF Secretariat has facilitated the creation of a policy document (White Paper) by the Iraqi government, with feedback from donors, which will be a leading document for the government s plan to tackle reform issues within the framework of the fund.The fund has three overall areas of activity, Socio-economic recovery, with a focus on the reconstruction of urban areas, institution building, development of social capital, rehabilitation of cultural heritage, improving the provision of services to people in poverty and vulnerability, and the creation of job opportunities for vulnerable groups. Economic diversification and private sector development, including technical advice and dialogue in trade and investment policy reforms, support for the financial sector and banking reform, improving the environment for small and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups by increasing the availability of borrowing opportunities. Coordination and program support, support for strengthened capacity of the Iraqi government to plan, coordinate and follow up reconstruction programs.Within the strategy for Sweden s cooperation with the World Bank Group (VBG) 2020-2023, which Sida s support will follow, there are four priority areas:1. Inclusive, sustainable economic growth and development,2. Environment and climate,3. Gender equality,4. Peace and state building.All four areas are integrated within the framework of I3RF, and Sida will, through dialogue with VB, work to ensure that these areas are prioritized in the projects. Within the Iraq strategy, Sweden must also prioritize co-operation that promotes peaceful an

ShortDescription: UNDP/UNAMI SUPPORT TO IRAQS ELECTORAL PROCESS
ProjectTitle: UNDP/UNAMI Support to Iraqs electoral process
LongDescription: This intervention aims to support the Iraqi High Electoral Commission (IHEC) to tackle the growing mistrust towards the Iraqi government in lacking transparency and accountability and to build the capacity of the newly appointed Commissioners and the staff at different levels. Through lessons learned from previously held elections in 2018 where the election was accused of misconduct causing a wide range of protest demanding a more transparent election and a reform of the electoral processes.

ShortDescription: UN WOMEN, IRAQ NATIONAL ACTION PLAN FOR 1325 (INAPII), 2021-23 - WOMEN, PEACE AND SECURITY AGENDA IRAQ
ProjectTitle: UN Women, Iraq National Action Plan for 1325 (INAPII), 2021-23 - Women, peace and security agenda Iraq
LongDescription: The project's overall goal is to 'foster the implementation of women, peace and security commitments in Iraq through national, local and community level action'. This goal will be achieved through a two-step approach: First, the project will focus on creating an enabling institutional environment to the implementation of INAP II, Secondly, the project will support localizing the implementation of INAP II with pilot interventions in the Governorates of Duhok, ThiQar and Ninewa building on UN Women existing interventions and strong partnerships with both governmental and civil society actors in these selected areas. The project adopts an inclusive and participatory approach supporting relevant governmental and civil society actors to actively and effectively participate in all stages of INAP II implementation including planning, coordination, financing, monitoring and evaluation.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE WINTER ASSISTANCE
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance winter assistance
LongDescription: Germany's winter assistance project in 2015 aimed to provide critical support to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in northern Iraq, particularly in the Kurdistan Region. The initiative focused on enhancing shelter conditions and ensuring access to essential services during the harsh winter months. Implemented by the German Red Cross in partnership with the Iraqi Red Crescent, the project included the distribution of kerosene vouchers, provision of stoves, insulating mats, and blankets, as well as the rehabilitation of unfinished housing units to improve living conditions for displaced families. Additionally, the project supported the construction of safe housing and the installation of mobile sanitary facilities to address the basic needs of IDPs. These efforts were concentrated in the Dohuk, Sulaymaniyah, and Erbil governorates, which hosted a significant portion of the displaced population.

ShortDescription: MINES ADVISORY GROUP MINE CLEARANCE IN NORTHERN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Mines Advisory Group Mine Clearance in Northern Iraq
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: The Humanitarian Mine Clearance in Northern Iraq initiative provides funding to support humanitarian demining activities in Northern Iraq through the Mines Advisory Group (MAG). This funding will assist MAG to achieve the following outputs: 1.2 million square metres of suspected hazardous land cleared, clearance of 12 mine fields and 6 battle areas, survey and demarcation work of 20 extra minefields, and 100% of Explosive remnants of War (ERW) items identified, removed and destroyed safely. These outputs will help lead to an outcome of the reduction of physical risk for affected communities, cleared and safe land available for resettled communities, rebuilding of infrastructure including housing for refugees and Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs), and irrigation projects. The total value of this initiative is $2.5 million over 2 years, starting 2011-12.

ShortDescription: IRAQ PERSONNEL SUPPORT SERVICES (MANPOWER II) - PROGRAM DESIGN AND LEARNING
ProjectTitle: Iraq Personnel Support Services (Manpower II) - Program Design and Learning
LongDescription: The Iraq Personnel Support Services (Manpower II) program provided professional and technical support services to enhance the capacity and efficiency of Iraqi government personnel. It focused on program design, learning, and workforce development to strengthen institutional performance and public sector management during Iraq’s reconstruction phase. The program operated across multiple government ministries in Baghdad,
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: MTR-EMR-IR6-IDP IRAQ SUPPORT
ProjectTitle: MTR-EMR-IR6-IDP IRAQ SUPPORT
LongDescription: The UNICEF project titled "MTR-EMR-IR6-IDP Iraq Support," initiated in 2014, was a humanitarian intervention aimed at addressing the urgent needs of internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq, particularly in the Kurdistan Region. This initiative was part of a broader emergency response to the displacement crisis resulting from ongoing conflicts in the country. The project focused on providing essential services and support to IDPs, including access to clean water, sanitation facilities, healthcare services, and educational support. UNICEF collaborated with local authorities and partner organizations to deliver aid and ensure the well-being of displaced populations in affected areas.

ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING CIVILIAN PROTECTION POLICIES AND PRACTICE IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Strengthening Civilian Protection Policies and Practice in Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: In the long term, this program will help CIVIC to provide trainings and bring communities and security forces together in constructive dialogues aimed at re-building trust and shrinking the space for groups like ISIS to re-emerge and take hold. Civilian perspectives on protection will be shared with government and security forces so that their voices will be heard and amplified throughout research and advocacy initiatives on civilian protection.

ShortDescription: SUPPORTING ACCOUNTABILITY PROCESSES FOR THE FINANCIAL COMPONENTS OF DAESH MASS ATROCITY CRIMES
ProjectTitle: Supporting Accountability Processes for the Financial Components of Daesh Mass Atrocity Crimes
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: To contribute to holding ISIL financiers and key facilitators to account for their involvement, links to, or material benefit from mass atrocities crimes carried out by the organization during its peak campaign years 2014 - 2016.

ShortDescription: PATHWAYS TO JUSTICE: SECURING THE RIGHTS AND PROTECTION OF IRAQI INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS (INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSONS) AND REFUGEE RETURNEES
ProjectTitle: Pathways To Justice: Securing The Rights and Protection of Iraqi Internally Displaced Persons (Internally Displaced Persons) and Refugee Returnees
LongDescription: The U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM) launched the "Pathways to Justice: Securing the Rights and Protection of Iraqi Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and Refugee Returnees" initiative in 2013. This program aimed to enhance the legal and civil rights of displaced Iraqis by facilitating access to essential documentation, such as birth certificates and national IDs, which are crucial for accessing services, employment, and participating in civic life. The initiative focused on areas with significant displaced populations, including the Kurdistan Region, and worked to strengthen local institutions to support the documentation process.

ShortDescription: NATIONAL ENDOWMENT FOR DEMOCRACY GRANT TO REDACTED GRANTEE - NGO [NON UNITED STATES]
ProjectTitle: National Endowment for Democracy Grant to Redacted Grantee - NGO [Non United States]
LongDescription: The National Endowment for Democracy (NED) is a private, nonprofit foundation dedicated to the growth and strengthening of democratic institutions around the world. Each year, NED makes more than 1,600 grants to support the projects of non-governmental groups abroad who are working for democratic goals in more than 90 countries.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE WINTER HELP
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance Winter Help
LongDescription: Winter aid and other measures of livelihood security for Iraqi IDPs (internally displaced persons) and needy in the Kurdistan Region

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - FOOD AID FOR IDPS
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Food aid for IDPs
LongDescription: In 2016, Germany allocated €2.49 million to provide food aid to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq through the German NGO Help – Hilfe zur Selbsthilfe e.V. This contribution was part of Germany's broader humanitarian support to address the food security needs of displaced populations affected by ongoing conflicts. The assistance aimed to alleviate hunger and improve nutrition among vulnerable communities, particularly in areas heavily impacted by displacement

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - IMPROVEMENT OF WASH NEEDS
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Improvement of WASH needs
LongDescription: In 2017, Germany allocated €600,000 to Oxfam GB to enhance water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) conditions for internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq. This funding aimed to address critical WASH needs in conflict-affected areas, focusing on improving access to clean water, sanitation facilities, and hygiene services for vulnerable populations. The support was part of Germany's broader humanitarian assistance to Iraq during that period

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: INTEGRATED REHABILITATION OF SEVERELY TRAUMATIZED WOMEN AND DEVELOPMENT OF LOCAL PROFESSIONALS FOR MENTAL HEALTH IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Integrated rehabilitation of severely traumatized women and development of local professionals for mental health in Iraq
LongDescription: Germany supported the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in 2020 to enhance mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS) services for internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees in Iraq. This initiative focused on strengthening the capacity of local professionals to address the mental health needs of severely traumatized women, particularly survivors of conflict-related sexual violence. The program provided training for government and healthcare personnel, aiming to integrate MHPSS into community-based services and promote the reintegration of displaced populations. By building local expertise, the project sought to ensure sustainable mental health support and reduce reliance on external aid.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: SUPPORT TO RAPID RESPONSE MECHANISM (RRM) - PROTECTION AND SOLUTIONS
ProjectTitle: Support to Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) - Protection and Solutions
LongDescription: Support to Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM), responding to emergency needs when there is rapid, large-scale population displacement. RRM delivers immediate, life-saving and dignity-raising supplies to families on the move as they flee conflict, in hard-to-reach areas of Iraq, close to military frontlines, delayed at checkpoints, or stranded in between. Within 72 hours of receiving and verifying information on the movement and location of displaced individuals, the RRM is activated to rapidly assess needs and deliver the minimum package through implementing partners with previously prepositioned stocks.
Name_of_Donor: United States, Agency for International Development

ShortDescription: A LONG-RANGE INVESTIGATION AND ANALYSIS OF ISLAMIC STATE'S HOME-MADE EXPLOSIVES IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: A long-range investigation and analysis of Islamic State's home-made explosives in Iraq
LongDescription: Investigation and analysis of recovered home made explosives (HME) of the Islamis States in order to support the Iraqi government (especially the Directorate for Military Intelligence) in decision making processes and implementatio of measures to combat HME. - Baseline assessment of the use of HME for the Iraqi government, as well as real time information of current investigations and analysis outputs, - Quarterly reports for the Iraqi government on import and risks of diversion of chemical persecutors used for HME, - Public report on the use of HME by terrorist orgaisations, - Access to data for the GFFO

ShortDescription: CLEARANCE AND RISK EDUCATION ACTIVITIES FOR AFFECTED COMMUNITIES IN NEED OF PROTECTION, IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Clearance and risk education activities for affected communities in Need of protection, Iraq
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: In 2018, Germany contributed €500,000 to support clearance and risk education activities in newly liberated areas of Ninewa and Salah al-Din governorates. This funding was part of a broader initiative aimed at enhancing civilian protection and facilitating the safe return of displaced populations. The project focused on removing explosive hazards and providing risk education to affected communities, thereby reducing the risk of injury or death from unexploded ordnance. The activities were coordinated with the United Nations Mine Action Service (UNMAS) and local authorities to ensure effective implementation and sustainability.

ShortDescription: MINE ACTION INTERVENTION IN NINEWA, IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Mine Action Intervention in Ninewa, Iraq
PurposeName: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
LongDescription: In 2018, Germany allocated €500,000 to Norwegian People’s Aid (NPA) to conduct a mine action intervention in Ninewa Governorate, Iraq. This project aimed to clear areas contaminated by improvised explosive devices (IEDs) and unexploded ordnance (UXO), thereby facilitating the safe return of displaced communities and enabling the restoration of essential services. The intervention was part of Germany's broader support to the United Nations Mine Action Service (UNMAS), which received a total of €44.2 million from Germany between 2016 and 2018 for various mine action activities in Iraq.

ShortDescription: FINANCIAL INVESTIGATION UNIT
ProjectTitle: Financial Investigation Unit
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: The goal of this project is to supplement the Investigative Team's efforts to collect, analyse, and preserve evidence of crimes committed by IS, with a particular focus on the financing of ISIL, as well as the laundering (layering, placement and investment) of proceeds from crimes committed, notably the enslavement of minorities, the illegal extraction of natural resources and proceeds from the plundering of cultural heritage. Conribution to the UNITAD Trust Fund (UNITAD = United Nations Investigative Team to Promote Accountability for Crimes Committed by Da'esh/ISIS).

ShortDescription: DEPOSIT INTO THE OCHA IRAQ HUMANITARIAN FUND (OCHA = UNITED NATIONS OFFICE FOR THE COORDINATION OF HUMANITARIAN AFFAIRS)
ProjectTitle: Deposit into the OCHA Iraq Humanitarian Fund (OCHA = United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs)
LongDescription: In 2019, Germany contributed $1,137,656 to the Iraq Humanitarian Fund (IHF), a pooled fund managed by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). This contribution was part of Germany's broader support to humanitarian efforts in Iraq, aimed at addressing the needs of vulnerable populations affected by conflict and displacement. The IHF plays a crucial role in coordinating and financing humanitarian assistance in Iraq, ensuring that aid reaches those most in need.

ShortDescription: SUPPORT TO SECURITY AND JUSTICE SECTOR GOVERNANCE IN POST-CONFLICT IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Support to Security and Justice Sector Governance in post-conflict Iraq
LongDescription: The transition from stabilization to long-term security will strengthen the lasting stability of the security and justice sector in Iraq. If local police and law enforcement agencies are able to improve their services to the people of Iraq and build trust, the transition from immediate stabilization activities to providing longer term public security will strengthen the security and justice sector governance in post-ISIL Iraq (ISIL = Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant).

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: CONTRIBUTION TO UNHCR PROGRAMME BUDGET 2023-2024 (EARMARKED)
ProjectTitle: Contribution to UNHCR Programme Budget 2023-2024 (earmarked)
PurposeName: Facilitation of orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobili
LongDescription: UNHCR is one of Switzerlands key multilateral partners due to its unique mandate by the General Assembly of United Nations to provide protection and assistance to refugees, asylum seekers, refugee returnees, and stateless persons. The strategic direction 2022-26 concretise the overall mandate of UNHCR for the upcoming years. Contributing to these directions allows Switzerland to achieve in particular the human development goal defined in the Dispatch to Parliament on International Cooperation for 2021-24.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: ADDRESSING NEW DISPLACEMENT DUE TO ADVERSE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND OTHER SHOCKS IN SOUTHERN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Addressing New Displacement due to Adverse Effects of Climate Change and other Shocks in Southern Iraq
LongDescription: To address the urgent adverse effects of climate change, including new and increasing internal displacement, environmental degradation, water shortages, disease outbreaks, and rising food insecurity in Southern Iraq.

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Emergency assistance in Iraq
LongDescription: Emergency assistance for returnees, internally displaced persons and host households in northern Iraq through multi-purpose cash and cash for work assistance

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE BASIC HEALTH SERVICE
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance basic health service
LongDescription: In 2015, Germany allocated €1.5 million to Médecins du Monde (MdM) to provide essential health services to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq. This funding aimed to address the urgent medical needs of vulnerable populations affected by conflict and displacement. The support facilitated the establishment of mobile clinics and the provision of primary healthcare services, including maternal and child health, treatment for chronic diseases, and mental health support. These efforts were part of Germany's broader commitment to humanitarian assistance in Iraq during that period.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: FOOD SECURITY AND SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS FOR VULNERABLE DISPLACED FAMILIES IN URBAN AND RURAL COMMUNITIES/ NORTHERN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Food security and sustainable livelihoods for vulnerable displaced families in urban and rural communities/ Northern Iraq
LongDescription: In 2015, Germany provided €4.5 million to the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) to support food security and sustainable livelihoods for vulnerable displaced families in northern Iraq. This contribution aimed to address the urgent needs of internally displaced persons (IDPs) and host communities affected by conflict. The assistance included the distribution of in-kind food aid, food vouchers, and cash-based transfers to enhance food access and support local markets. Additionally, the program focused on promoting sustainable livelihoods through agricultural support and income-generating activities. The initiative was implemented in collaboration with local partners and targeted areas with high concentrations of displaced populations.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: FFIS (FUNDING FACILITY IMMEDIATE STABILIZATION)
ProjectTitle: FFIS (Funding Facility Immediate Stabilization)
LongDescription: In 2015, Germany contributed €1 million to the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) for the Funding Facility for Immediate Stabilization (FFIS) in Iraq. Established at the request of the Iraqi government, FFIS aimed to support rapid stabilization in newly liberated areas to facilitate the safe return of internally displaced persons (IDPs). The German contribution focused on rehabilitating essential infrastructure and providing income-generating opportunities to encourage returns and prevent further deterioration of living conditions in these areas

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: PROMOTING SELF-HELP CAPACITIES FOR BETTER LIFE-PERSPECTIVES OF IDPS AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY THE ONGOING CONFLICT IN NORTHER IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Promoting self-help capacities for better life-perspectives of IDPs and local communities affected by the ongoing conflict in Norther Iraq
LongDescription: In 2015, Germany allocated €4.5 million to the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) to support food security and sustainable livelihoods for vulnerable displaced families in northern Iraq. This contribution aimed to address the urgent needs of internally displaced persons (IDPs) and host communities affected by conflict. The assistance included the distribution of in-kind food aid, food vouchers, and cash-based transfers to enhance food access and support local markets. Additionally, the program focused on promoting sustainable livelihoods through agricultural support and income-generating activities. The initiative was implemented in collaboration with local partners and targeted areas with high concentrations of displaced populations.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: SCHOLARSHIPS FOR GRADUATES/YOUNG SCIENTISTS, DAAD
ProjectTitle: Scholarships for graduates/young scientists, DAAD
LongDescription: In 2020, Germany's support for the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD) facilitated short-term research grants for Iraqi PhD students and early-career researchers. These grants enabled recipients to conduct research in Germany for periods ranging from one to six months. The program aimed to strengthen academic collaboration between Germany and Iraq, enhance research capacities, and promote knowledge exchange.

ShortDescription: IOM HUMANITARIAN SUPPORT 2017-2020
ProjectTitle: IOM Humanitarian Support 2017-2020
LongDescription: This is a suplementary decision to the agreement with IOM on support to humanitariain interventions 1 April 2018-31 March 2019. The decision is taken based on Sida's internal rule on contribution management paragraph 3.11.3 and is the second year of a three year agreement. The contribution to IOM is to humanitarian aid projects directed to internally displaced people and migrants, including in some cases voluntary returnees with humanitarian needs and in humanitarian crises returning form neighbouring countries. The support is designed as stand-alone projects in countries where IOM has a comparative advantage and their proposed initiative has been deemed appropriate to respond to the country's most urgent humanitarian needs. IOM has a unique mandate to work with migrants and by that also targets internally displaced persons and returnees who are not targeted by other organisations. Migrants generally also have protection needs because of vulnerability related to travel. IOM has also presents a clear link between humanitarian and development issues. IOM works with migration through a multisectoral approach to assist vulnerable migrants with everything from shelter, protection to food and non-food support. IOM also has a satisfactory experience of integrating gender, conflict and environment / climate in their processes. IOM has since the previous agreement entered into agreements with the UN and is now a UN related organisation that gives it access to more forums in the United Nations. IOM interventions continues to be organised in project form which allows appeals support or core support from Sida is not possible at present. This appraisal is mainly written in English to enable NPOs to access the document.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING LOCAL PROTECTION AND COUNSELING FOR WOMEN AND GIRLS AFFECTED BY GENDER BASED VIOLENCE IN IDP SHELTERS AND HOST COMMUNITIES
ProjectTitle: Strengthening local protection and counseling for women and girls affected by gender based violence in IDP shelters and host communities
LongDescription: In 2016, HAUKARI e.V., in collaboration with medica mondiale e.V., implemented the project "Strengthening Local Protection and Counselling for Women and Girls Affected by Gender-Based Violence in IDP Shelters and Host Communities" in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. This initiative aimed to enhance the protection and support services for women and girls facing sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) in internally displaced persons (IDP) camps and host communities, particularly in the provinces of Duhok and Sulaymaniyah (Garmyan area). The project focused on improving the qualifications and organizational capacities of local governmental and non-governmental structures involved in the protection and counselling of affected individuals. It also aimed to foster cooperation between these structures to provide comprehensive support to survivors of SGBV.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE - EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE FOR IDPS
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance - Emergency Assistance for IDPs
LongDescription: In 2016, Germany provided €1 million in humanitarian assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) fleeing Mosul, Iraq, through the German Federal Foreign Office. This funding was part of a broader international response to the crisis resulting from the military offensive to retake Mosul from ISIS. The support aimed to address the urgent needs of displaced populations, including shelter, food, water, and medical care. The assistance was coordinated with various humanitarian organizations operating in the region to ensure effective delivery of aid.

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY GRANT AID FOR IDPS AND RETURNEES TO LIBERATED AREAS IN IRAQ (THROUGH IOM)
ProjectTitle: Emergency Grant Aid for IDPs and returnees to liberated areas in Iraq (through IOM)
LongDescription: In 2016, Japan extended $1 million in Emergency Grant Aid to support internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees in Iraq through the International Organization for Migration (IOM) and other partners. This assistance aimed to provide emergency shelter, protection, education, livelihood support, and health services to those affected by the conflict. The focus was on enhancing the living conditions of displaced populations and facilitating their safe return to liberated areas

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY GRANT AID FOR IDPS AND RETURNEES TO LIBERATED AREAS IN IRAQ (THROUGH ICRC)
ProjectTitle: Emergency Grant Aid for IDPs and returnees to liberated areas in Iraq (through ICRC)
LongDescription: In 2016, Japan extended Emergency Grant Aid totaling $10 million to support internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees in Iraq through the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC). This assistance aimed to provide essential humanitarian aid, including shelter, food, and other relief items, to those affected by the ongoing conflict. The support was part of Japan's broader efforts to address the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and assist in the stabilization of liberated areas.

ShortDescription: IMPROVING LOCAL POLICE
ProjectTitle: Improving Local Police
LongDescription: In 2017, Germany contributed €4 million to support the restoration of security in post-ISIS communities in Iraq, focusing on strengthening local police forces in areas such as Ramadi and Tikrit. This initiative was part of the broader Funding Facility for Immediate Stabilization (FFIS) program, which aimed to provide rapid stabilization assistance in newly liberated areas. The funding facilitated the training of approximately 4,000 police officers through an Italy-led coalition program, enhancing their capacity to maintain law and order and rebuild public trust in security institutions

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - EMERGENCY SHELTER AND RELIEF ITEMS - 2015 / CRISE EN IRAQ - ABRIS D'URGENCE ET ARTICLES DE SECOURS - 2015
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Emergency Shelter and Relief Items - 2015
LongDescription: March 2015 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced over 2.4 million people from their homes. An estimated 5.2 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. As fighting and human rights violations persist and international efforts remain to free territory controlled by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), the situation is expected to deteriorate and to cause additional displacement.   With DFATD's support, the partner is helping to reduce the vulnerability of internally displaced people affected by the civil unrest in Iraq. Project activities include: (1) providing relief items for 5,000 vulnerable households, (2) providing emergency financial support towards housing to 1,200 of the most vulnerable households, and (3) providing social and psychosocial counseling and support to 4,200 conflict-affected individuals.

ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE LIVELIHOOD SECURITY
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian Assistance Livelihood security
LongDescription: Contribution to livelihood security (cash assistance, kerosene, psychosocial interventions) for Iraqi IDPs and needy in the Kurdistan Region

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: IRK EMERGENCY WINTERIZATION RESP. UNHCR
ProjectTitle: IRK Emergency winterization resp. UNHCR
LongDescription: In late 2014, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) allocated CHF 1 million to support the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in providing emergency winterization assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. This intervention aimed to address the urgent shelter needs of approximately 1.8 million IDPs who had fled violence in central Iraq, many seeking refuge in the Kurdish region.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: SECOND ALLOCATION OF SDC FUNDING (EUROPE AND MEDITERRANEAN REGION DIVISION) TO ICRC OPERATIONS IN 2014
ProjectTitle: Second Allocation of SDC Funding (Europe and Mediterranean Region Division) to ICRC Operations in 2014
LongDescription: In line with the Good Humanitarian Donorship (GHD) principles, Switzerland recognizes the necessity of predictable and flexible funding to respond to changing needs in humanitarian crises. SDC funding to ICRC operations allows the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) to respond proactively and to provide immediate protection and assistance for people affected by armed conflict and other situations of violence.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: DIALOGUE PROCESS IRAQ - PHASE II
ProjectTitle: Dialogue process Iraq - phase II
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: In 2019, Germany contributed to the second phase of the Integrated Reconciliation Project (IRP) in Iraq, aiming to foster social cohesion and reconciliation in post-conflict communities. The project, managed by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), focused on establishing and empowering local peace mechanisms, such as Local Peace Committees (LPCs), Women Peace Groups (WPGs), and Youth Peace Groups (YPGs), to address community divisions and promote dialogue. It also provided socio-economic support services to reduce tensions and strengthen civil society capacities to become more effective partners in social cohesion and peacebuilding. The IRP aligned with Iraq's Vision 2030 for Sustainable Development and the UNDP Iraq Country Programme, complementing efforts by other UN agencies and international organizations in the region .

ShortDescription: IMPROVE THE RESILIENCE AND SELF-RELIANCE OF THE MOST VULNERABLE MEMBERS OF THE NON-CAMP REFUGEE POPULATION IN DOHUK - IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Improve the Resilience and Self-Reliance of the Most Vulnerable Members of the Non-Camp Refugee Population in Dohuk - Iraq
LongDescription: The "Improve the Resilience and Self-Reliance of the Most Vulnerable Members of the Non-Camp Refugee Population in Dohuk" project, funded by the U.S. Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM), was implemented by Première Urgence – Aide Médicale Internationale (PU-AMI) in 2015. This initiative aimed to enhance the livelihoods and resilience of Syrian refugees residing outside formal camps in the Dohuk Governorate of the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. The project provided vocational training, income-generating activities, and psychosocial support to empower refugees and integrate them into the local economy, thereby reducing their dependency on humanitarian aid.

ShortDescription: HEALTH AND PROTECTION OF THE POPULATION IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Health and protection of the population in Iraq
LongDescription: In 2018, Germany supported mental health and protection initiatives for conflict-affected populations in Ninewa Governorate, Iraq. This assistance aimed to address the psychological impact of the ISIS conflict and support the recovery of displaced and returning communities.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - EMERGENCY RELIEF ASSISTANCE - CANADIAN LUTHERAN WORLD RELIEF  2015 / CRISE EN IRAQ - ASSISTANCE DES SECOURS D URGENCE - CANADIAN LUTHERA
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Emergency Relief Assistance - Canadian Lutheran World Relief  2015
LongDescription: March 2015 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate. The violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced an estimated 2.4 million people from their homes. An estimated 5.2 million people in Iraq have been affected by the conflict and are in need of humanitarian assistance. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. As fighting and human rights violations persist and international efforts remain to free territory controlled by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), the situation is expected to deteriorate and to cause additional displacement.   With DFATD s support, Canadian Lutheran World Relief (CLWR) is helping to reduce the vulnerability of internally displaced people affected by the civil unrest in Iraq. Project activities include: (1) providing 11,200 of the most vulnerable people with essential items such as mother and infant dignity kits, wash basins, jerry cans, plastic tarps, mosquito nets, food coolers, rechargeable fans and plastic storage bins.

ShortDescription: IRAQ CRISIS - EMERGENCY BASIC HEALTH SERVICES - PLAN INTERNATIONAL CANADA 2014 / CRISE EN IRAK - SERVICES DE SANT횋 DE BASE D URGENCE - PLAN INTERNATIO
ProjectTitle: Iraq Crisis - Emergency Basic Health Services - Plan International Canada 2014
LongDescription: September 2014 - The humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to deteriorate as armed clashes continue to drive displacement. The recent surge in violence between armed groups and government forces has displaced an estimated 1.7 million people from their homes. Basic services, including health care and water infrastructure, are disrupted, resulting in acute humanitarian needs. Iraqi Kurdistan is hosting an additional 215,000 Syrian refugees, which is also placing a great strain on local infrastructure. The situation is expected to deteriorate as fighting and human rights violations persist.   With DFATD s support, Plan International Canada is helping to provide basic healthcare services including mental health services to up to 55,000 displaced persons in Dohuk and Erbil Governorates. Project activities include: (1) providing healthcare services and mental health assistance at camp-based clinics, (2) providing primary healthcare services through a mobile medical unit, and (3) provision of essential medical commodities to existing medical facilities.

ShortDescription: SCHOLARSHIPS FOR GRADUATES/YOUNG SCIENTISTS, GERMAN ACADEMIC EXCHANGE SERVICE (DAAD)
ProjectTitle: Scholarships for graduates/young scientists, German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD)
LongDescription: In 2018, the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD) offered short-term and one-year scholarships for Iraqi PhD students and early-career researchers. These scholarships aimed to support academic exchange and foster research collaboration between Germany and Iraq. The funding provided covered travel expenses, accommodation, and a monthly stipend to facilitate research stays at German institutions

ShortDescription: SUPPORT FOR TRAUMATIZED VICTIMS
ProjectTitle: Support for Traumatized Victims
LongDescription: In 2016, Germany supported initiatives aimed at assisting victims of human rights violations in Iraq, particularly focusing on survivors of sexual and gender-based violence. These efforts were part of Germany's broader commitment to humanitarian aid and stabilization in post-ISIS Iraq.

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: ICRC EMERGENCY APPEALS 2013: SECOND ALLOCATION (IRAQ, OPT)
ProjectTitle: ICRC Emergency Appeals 2013: Second Allocation (Iraq, OPT)
LongDescription: In line with the Good Humanitarian Donorship (GHD) principles, Switzerland recognizes the necessity of predictable and flexible funding to respond to changing needs in humanitarian crises. SDC funding to ICRC operations allows the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) to respond proactively and to provide immediate protection and assistance for people affected by armed conflict and other situations of violence.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: SUPPORTING THE LIFESAVING NEEDS OF IDPS AND REFUGEES IN THE NOTHERN GOVERNORATES OF NINAWA, ERBIL AND DUHOK
ProjectTitle: Supporting the lifesaving needs of IDPs and Refugees in the Nothern governorates of Ninawa, Erbil and Duhok
LongDescription: providing critical life-saving interventions to prevent avoidable morbidity,mortality, and disability

ShortDescription: WASH IN EMERGENCIES
ProjectTitle: WASH IN EMERGENCIES
LongDescription: In 2016, UNICEF's "WASH in Emergencies" initiative in Iraq was a comprehensive humanitarian response aimed at providing safe water, sanitation, and hygiene services to populations affected by conflict and displacement. This effort was part of a broader strategy to address the urgent needs of over 3 million internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees, particularly in regions such as Anbar, Ninewa, and Mosul. Key activities included the installation of Reverse Osmosis (RO) units in IDP camps like Ameriyat al-Fallujah, rehabilitation of water networks in areas like Hammam al-Alil, and the establishment of WASH Service Centres to coordinate hygiene promotion and waste management. Additionally, UNICEF provided emergency water trucking, distributed hygiene kits, and supported the construction of latrines and showers to mitigate the risk of waterborne diseases. The initiative also focused on public awareness campaigns to promote water conservation and improved hygiene practices among affected communities

ShortDescription: WASH RESP TO CRISIS AFFECTED COMMUNITIES
ProjectTitle: WASH RESP TO CRISIS AFFECTED COMMUNITIES
LongDescription: In 2014, UNICEF implemented the "WASH Response to Crisis-Affected Communities" project in Iraq, focusing on providing essential water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services to populations affected by the escalating conflict. The initiative aimed to address the urgent needs of over 2.1 million displaced individuals, including 223,000 Syrian refugees, who were facing deteriorating living conditions and limited access to basic services. Key activities included the distribution of hygiene kits, provision of safe drinking water, rehabilitation of water and sanitation facilities, and promotion of hygiene practices to prevent the spread of diseases. UNICEF collaborated with local authorities, international organizations, and community partners to ensure the timely and effective delivery of these services, particularly in hard-to-reach areas and conflict zones.

ShortDescription: SUPPORTING SURVIVORS OF HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS IN POST-ISIS (ISLAMIC STATE) IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Supporting Survivors of Human Rights Violations in post-ISIS (Islamic State) Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: A network of five rehabilitation centers in North Iraq (Erbil, Halabja, Kirkuk, Mosul, Sulaymaniyah) will offer gender-specific and age-adapted medical and psychological assistance as well as legal counseling to 2000 survivors of human rights violations, including an estimated 1000 women and 600 children. Services will include medical diagnostics and rehabilitation services, including assessments, free medication, as well as general medical, physiotherapeutic and orthopedic treatment. It will also includepsychological trauma diagnostics, individual and group psychotherapy, psychiatric treatment and consultation as well as psychoeducation. In addition it will also offer pediatric services, child and youth psychotherapy, as well as family counseling and education regarding effects of trauma and children's needs and rights and legal counseling regarding remedies and reparation.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: TRAUMA THERAPY AND REHABILITATION FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES IN NORTHERN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Trauma therapy and Rehabilitation for Syrian Refugees in Northern Iraq
LongDescription: In 2016, Germany supported trauma therapy and rehabilitation initiatives for Syrian refugees in Northern Iraq, specifically in the Kurdistan Region. These efforts aimed to address the psychological impact of displacement and conflict on Syrian refugees residing in the region. The programs provided mental health services, including psychological counseling and therapy, to help individuals cope with trauma and rebuild their lives. The support was part of Germany's broader commitment to humanitarian assistance and refugee support in the Middle East.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE: BUREAU OF NEAR EASTERN AFFAIRS (NEA) - PEACE AND SECURITY - GENERAL: FROM DOCUMENTATION TO PROSECUTIONS
ProjectTitle: U.S. Department of State: Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs (NEA) - Peace and Security - General: From Documentation to Prosecutions
LongDescription: The U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs, through its Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs (INL), supported the "From Documentation to Prosecutions" initiative in 2020. This project aimed to enhance accountability for ISIS crimes, particularly those targeting Christians in Iraq. It focused on strengthening the capacity of the United Nations Investigative Team to Promote Accountability for Crimes Committed by Da'esh/ISIL (UNITAD) to collect and preserve evidence of genocide, war crimes, and crimes against humanity committed by ISIS. The initiative also aimed to support the prosecution of individuals responsible for these atrocities, contributing to justice for victims and the promotion of the rule of law in Iraq.

ShortDescription: SRC/IFRC 2014 - 2015 - SRC/IFRC 2014-2015
ProjectTitle: SRC/IFRC 2014 - 2015 - SRC/IFRC 2014-2015
LongDescription: Support for SRC's long-term humanitarian work with local capacity     development  Building resilient communities  in 2014 continued work   to strengthen the humanitarian capacity among several national Red    Cross and Red Crescent Societies, Associations in  14 countries.

ShortDescription: STRENGTHENING RESILIENCE, RECOVERY AND DERADICALIZATION IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: Strengthening Resilience, Recovery and Deradicalization in Iraq
PurposeName: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
LongDescription: The project aims to enhance community resilience and recovery and to prevent political and religious extremism in Iraq by promoting the physical rehabilitation, mental well-being and socio-legal reintegration for those impacted by ISIS atrocities and by developing a deradicalization program for former ISIS child soldiers.

ShortDescription: MIDDLE EAST - UNICEF HUMANITARIAN APPEALS 2019-2021/MOYEN-ORIENT - APPELS HUMANITAIRES DE L'UNICEF 2019-2021
ProjectTitle: Middle East - UNICEF Humanitarian Appeals 2019-2021
LongDescription: July 2019 - Humanitarian needs stemming from the crises in Syria and Iraq remain significant throughout the Middle East. Continued violence in Syria raises little prospects for the voluntary, safe, sustainable and dignified return of over 5.6 million refugees in the region. Internally displaced persons range in the millions in Syria and Iraq, and refugees facing protracted displacement in host countries continue to face acute humanitarian needs in Jordan and Lebanon.With GAC's support, the project is providing flexible regional funding to the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) on a multiyear basis, for its emergency operations in Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon and Syria. Regional funding provides UNICEF with the flexibility to allocate funds to acute humanitarian needs that are critically underfunded, and provides the flexibility to respond to emerging needs. Project activities include: (1) providing people with access to safe drinking water and sanitation facilities, (2) treating children for severe acute malnutrition, (3) providing emergency education programming for children, (4) ensuring protection services for children, adolescent girls and women, and (5) providing basic healthcare.

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: UNHCR - NOTHILFEBEITR횆GE (AB 2015)
ProjectTitle: UNHCR - Nothilfebeitrge (ab 2015)
LongDescription: In 2015, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) allocated CHF 1 million to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) to support emergency winterization assistance for internally displaced persons (IDPs) in northern Iraq. This funding was part of Switzerland's broader commitment to humanitarian aid in the region, which included an additional CHF 30 million pledged by the Federal Council in September 2015 to bolster support for displaced people in Iraq and Syria .
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: BUILDING RESILIENCE AND COPING CAPACITY AMONGST CONFLICT-AFFECTED POPULATIONS / RENFORCEMENT DE LA R횋SILIENCE ET DE LA CAPACIT횋 D'ADAPTATION DES POPUL
ProjectTitle: Building Resilience and Coping Capacity Amongst Conflict-Affected Populations
LongDescription: This project aims to complements Canada's existing humanitarian relief efforts for internally displaced persons in Iraq, thereby leveraging greater impact of Canada's response to the crisis. The project also strengthens Iraq's resilience to withstand the impact of the current and future crises by building the capacity of local authorities, community groups, local non-profit organizations, and individuals, through training and technical assistance.   Project activities include: essential services to children of host and camp communities in the thematic areas of Education, Child Protection that integrates water sanitation and hygiene activities. These services increase access and quality to formal and non-formal education, psychosocial support, child protection and case management while ensuring children and their families have access to water sanitation and hygiene facilities in schools, child friendly spaces and community centres.

AgencyName: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
ShortDescription: VOCATIONAL TRAINING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN BFZ HOF AND THE MINISTRY OF THE KURDISTAN REGIONAL GOVERMENT AND THEIR VOCATIONAL TRAINING CENTERS IN ERBIL
ProjectTitle: Vocational Training Partnership between bfz Hof and the Ministry of the Kurdistan Regional Goverment and their Vocational Training Centers in Erbil
LongDescription: Improved and consistent basis training increases the demand for disadvantaged young people to technical careers and offers market-oriented qualifications.
Name_of_Donor: Germany, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

ShortDescription: MSB FRAMEWORK AGREEMENT 2014-2017 (OLD STRATEGY)
ProjectTitle: MSB Framework Agreement 2014-2017 (old strategy)
LongDescription: MSB (Swedish Civil Contingencies Agency) Humanitarian Frame for all humanitarian contributions financed by Sida's Humanitarian Unit. The contributions consist of secondments, base camps, medical teams etc in support of UN Organizations. Own contributions are capacity development projects in connection with the establishment of rescue services.

AgencyName: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation
ShortDescription: UNHCR MULTI-YEAR 2019-2022: EARMARKED
ProjectTitle: UNHCR Multi-Year 2019-2022: Earmarked
PurposeName: Facilitation of orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobili
LongDescription: In 2019, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) allocated CHF 16 million to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) as part of a multi-year earmarked contribution for the period 2019–2022. This funding aimed to support UNHCR's operations in Iraq, focusing on providing protection and assistance to refugees, asylum seekers, and internally displaced persons (IDPs). The contribution was part of Switzerland's commitment to predictable and flexible funding to respond to changing needs in humanitarian crises, in line with the Good Humanitarian Donorship (GHD) principles. The SDC's support enabled UNHCR to deliver essential services such as shelter, legal assistance, and access to civil documentation for vulnerable populations in Iraq.
Name_of_Donor: Switzerland, Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

ShortDescription: SYRIA CRISIS - SUPPORT TO THE NO LOST GENERATION INITIATIVE - SAVE THE CHILDREN CANADA 2015 / CRISE EN SYRIE - APPUI ? L'INITIATIVE 횂짬 NON ? UNE G횋N횋R
ProjectTitle: Syria Crisis - Support to the No Lost Generation Initiative - Save the Children Canada 2015
LongDescription: March 2015 - The humanitarian situation in Syria continues to deteriorate as a result of the civil war and intensified violence in the country. The United Nations estimates that 12.2 million people inside Syria, including 5.6 million children, are in need of humanitarian assistance. Combined with 3.8 million Syrians seeking refuge from the conflict in neighbouring countries, this is the largest number of people displaced from conflict in the world. Women and children are particularly vulnerable to the consequences of the conflict and host countries are increasingly overstretched by the influx of people fleeing the conflict.   Save the Children Canada is one of the partners leading the  Lost Generation initiative to educate and normalize the lives of conflict-affected children and their families. With DFATD's support, Save the Children is educating and protecting 55,900 children, parents and teachers, in Jordan, Iraq and Egypt. Project activities include: (1) providing early childhood care and development activities, informal education services, educational kits, alternative learning spaces, training of education authorities and teachers, and rehabilitation of public schools, benefitting up to 18,000 children and 200 teachers, (2) establishing and supporting child-friendly spaces and child protection committees and training community members on child protection, benefitting up to 5,250 children and 840 community members, and (3) providing opportunities for adolescents and children through advocating for the inclusion of refugees in community-based schools, involving adolescents in community campaigns and conducting awareness sessions.

ShortDescription: ASSISTANCE TO SYRIAN REFUGEES: REGIONAL REFUGEE AND RESILIENCE PLAN (3RP) 2019-2020
ProjectTitle: Assistance to Syrian Refugees: Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP) 2019-2020
LongDescription: The "Assistance to Syrian Refugees: Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan (3RP) 2019–2020" project, funded by the U.S. Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM), was implemented by the International Organization for Migration (IOM) in Iraq. This initiative aimed to enhance the resilience and self-reliance of Syrian refugees and host communities in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KRI). The project provided a range of services, including protection, education, livelihoods, and social cohesion programs, to support the integration of refugees into local communities and reduce their dependency on humanitarian aid. By focusing on both immediate needs and long-term solutions, the project contributed to the stabilization and development of the region

AgencyName: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade
ShortDescription: UNICEF`S HUMANITARIAN ACTION FOR CHILDREN IN IRAQ_UNICEF
ProjectTitle: UNICEF`s Humanitarian Action for Children in Iraq_UNICEF
LongDescription: In 2017, UNICEF's Humanitarian Action for Children (HAC) in Iraq, supported by Korean funding, aimed to address the urgent needs of children and families affected by conflict and displacement. The program focused on providing essential services in sectors such as child protection, education, nutrition, water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH). UNICEF led the coordination of the Child Protection sub-cluster, the WASH cluster, and the Education cluster, working closely with local and international partners to ensure a comprehensive response to the humanitarian crisis. The program targeted both displaced populations and returnees, delivering services in camps, host communities, and newly retaken areas to ensure that children and families received the support they needed during the crisis.
Name_of_Donor: Korea, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

AgencyName: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade
ShortDescription: SUPPORT FOR UNFPA`S HUMANITARIAN PROGRAMME IN IRAQ_UNFPA
ProjectTitle: Support for UNFPA`s humanitarian programme in Iraq_UNFPA
LongDescription: In 2017, the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) received Korean funding to support its humanitarian programme in Iraq, focusing on reproductive health services and gender-based violence prevention for displaced and vulnerable populations. The programme delivered maternal health care, family planning, and GBV response services primarily in conflict-affected and high-displacement areas
Name_of_Donor: Korea, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

ShortDescription: NATIONAL PROGRAMME FOR THE REHABILITATION AND REGULARIZATION OF INFORMAL SETTLEMENTS/IDP AREAS IN IRAQ ??PHASE II
ProjectTitle: National Programme for the Rehabilitation and Regularization of Informal Settlements/Idp Areas in Iraq Phase II
LongDescription: The "National Programme for the Rehabilitation and Regularization of Informal Settlements/IDP Areas in Iraq – Phase II," implemented by UN-Habitat with funding from the U.S. Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM), aimed to address the challenges faced by internally displaced persons (IDPs) and residents of informal settlements in Iraq. Initiated in 2015, this program focused on upgrading infrastructure and improving living conditions in informal settlements, particularly in the aftermath of the ISIS conflict. Key interventions included the provision of basic services such as potable water, sanitation, and stormwater drainage systems, as well as the establishment of community development councils to ensure local participation in the planning and implementation processes. The program's efforts contributed to enhancing the resilience and self-reliance of vulnerable populations in Iraq.

ShortDescription: U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE: BUREAU OF NEAR EASTERN AFFAIRS (NEA) - STABILIZATION OPERATIONS AND SECURITY SECTOR REFORM: PROMOTING ACCOUNTABILITY IN IRAQ
ProjectTitle: U.S. Department of State: Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs (NEA) - Stabilization Operations and Security Sector Reform: Promoting Accountability in Iraq
LongDescription: The "Promoting Accountability in Iraq" project, supported by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs (NEA) and implemented by the United Nations Investigative Team to Promote Accountability for Crimes Committed by Da’esh/ISIL (UNITAD), aimed to support Iraq's efforts to hold perpetrators of ISIS crimes accountable. In 2019, UNITAD focused on collecting and preserving evidence of international crimes committed by ISIS, including genocide, war crimes, and crimes against humanity. The team conducted field investigations in areas such as Sinjar, Mosul, and Tikrit, gathering documentary, forensic, and testimonial evidence. UNITAD also provided technical assistance to Iraqi authorities, including support for mass grave excavations and DNA analysis, and collaborated with third states to facilitate prosecutions of ISIS members for crimes committed in Iraq. Despite challenges, including the absence of specific legislation in Iraq criminalizing international crimes, UNITAD's efforts contributed to the documentation and prosecution of ISIS crimes both domestically and internationally.

AgencyName: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade
ShortDescription: HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE FOR IRAQ_WFP
ProjectTitle: Humanitarian assistance for Iraq_WFP
LongDescription: In 2015, the Republic of Korea contributed $1 million to the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) to support food assistance for vulnerable populations in Iraq. This funding aimed to provide critical aid to those affected by ongoing conflicts and displacement. The contribution was part of a broader humanitarian effort by the Republic of Korea, which included a total of $6 million in aid to Iraq that year, supporting various UN agencies and initiatives
Name_of_Donor: Korea, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

ShortDescription: SUPPORTING SYRIAN REFUGEES IN BARDARASH CAMP IN IRAQ AND ENSURING THEIR ACCESS TO WATER, HYGIENE AND SANITATION SERVICES
ProjectTitle: Supporting Syrian Refugees in Bardarash Camp in Iraq and Ensuring Their Access to Water, Hygiene and Sanitation Services
LongDescription: The U.S.-funded project "Supporting Syrian Refugees in Bardarash Camp in Iraq and Ensuring Their Access to Water, Hygiene, and Sanitation Services," implemented by Solidarités International in 2020, aimed to improve living conditions for Syrian refugees in Bardarash Camp, located in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. The camp had been reopened in October 2019 to accommodate refugees fleeing northeast Syria due to escalating conflict. Upon arrival, many refugees faced inadequate access to clean water and sanitation facilities, exposing them to waterborne diseases. Solidarités International's intervention focused on rehabilitating the camp's water and wastewater infrastructure, ensuring that each refugee received over 80 liters of water per day. Additionally, the organization provided hygiene kits, conducted awareness campaigns on disease prevention, and offered employment opportunities to refugees, thereby enhancing their self-reliance and dignity. By mid-2020, more than 12,000 refugees had benefited from these services

AgencyName: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade
ShortDescription: SUPPORT FOR WHO`S HUMANITARIAN HEALTH ACTIVITIES IN IRAQ_WHO
ProjectTitle: Support for WHO`s humanitarian health activities in Iraq_WHO
LongDescription: In 2017, the Republic of Korea contributed $1 million to the World Health Organization (WHO) to support its humanitarian health activities in Iraq. This funding was part of a broader $7 million commitment by Korea to assist Iraq's humanitarian response, which included support for the World Food Programme (WFP), the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) . The WHO utilized this contribution to provide essential medical supplies and services to populations affected by conflict and displacement. This support included the distribution of interagency emergency health kits, surgical kits, and trauma kits, as well as the provision of wheelchairs to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Anbar governorate. Additionally, WHO supported medical consultations and vaccinations in various governorates, including Ninewa, Erbil, Kirkuk, Dahuk, Sulaymaniyah, Salahaddin, Baghdad, and Anbar
Name_of_Donor: Korea, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

ShortDescription: EMERGENCY GRANT AID FOR IRAQ TO IMPROVE HUMANITARIAN SITUATION AND ENHANCE STABILIZATION<THROUGH UNDP>
ProjectTitle: Emergency Grant Aid for Iraq to improve humanitarian situation and enhance stabilization<through UNDP>
LongDescription: In 2015, Japan provided $10 million in Emergency Grant Aid to support humanitarian efforts in Iraq, focusing on improving the situation of internally displaced persons (IDPs) and facilitating stabilization in newly liberated areas. Through the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), $2 million of this aid was allocated to livelihood assistance initiatives, specifically targeting the newly arrived IDPs. These efforts aimed to create emergency livelihood opportunities, thereby enhancing the resilience and self-reliance of displaced populations.

AgencyName: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade
ShortDescription: ADDITIONAL HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE FOR DISPLACED PEOPLE BY ARMED ATTACK
ProjectTitle: Additional Humanitarian assistance for displaced people by armed attack
LongDescription: In 2014, the Republic of Korea provided humanitarian assistance to Iraq in response to the escalating displacement caused by armed attacks, particularly those by ISIS. The Korean government contributed $1 million to support the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in delivering essential aid to internally displaced persons (IDPs) and refugees. This funding was part of a broader international effort to address the humanitarian crisis resulting from the conflict. The assistance focused on providing shelter, food, water, and medical supplies to those affected by the violence.
Name_of_Donor: Korea, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

ShortDescription: EXPANDING SECONDARY EDUCATION FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES IN IRAQ
